Speaker: NA
Text: Monday, 27 November 1995

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. Stephen Martin) and

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: DELEGA TION REPORTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Delegation to Slovenia and the 94th

Speaker: NA
Text: Inter-Parliamentary Conference held in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bucharest

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I present the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia and the 94th Inter-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference held in Bucharest, October 1995.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Slovenian section of the program was

Speaker: NA
Text: lead by my friend and colleague the honourinto

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Watson ( Mr Leo MCLeay).

Speaker: NA
Text: I will therefore let him make any comment

Speaker: NA
Text: that section he would like to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 94th Inter-Parliamentary Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: was held in Bucharest between 9 and 13

Speaker: NA
Text: October. It was an extremely well-organised

Speaker: NA
Text: conference set in the stunningly opulent

Speaker: NA
Text: Palace of Parliament, the former Ceaucescu

Speaker: NA
Text: Palace. The location of the conference in

Speaker: NA
Text: palace underscored the contrast which is still

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious in Bucharest as Romania makes a

Speaker: NA
Text: transition to a modem and democratic society.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, much has been achieved since 1989,

Speaker: NA
Text: but there are still many challenges ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased while in Romania to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet with both the Presiding Officers

Speaker: NA
Text: the Romanian parliament and with the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. Each commented on the warmth

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing relationship between Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and Romania and the potential for further

Speaker: NA
Text: development, especially in trade. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: they noted that the Romanian government had

Speaker: NA
Text: recently approved the privatisation of around

Speaker: NA
Text: 4,000 of Romania's leading state companies,

Speaker: NA
Text: a move which in their view will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: significant opportunities for further Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and joint ventures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The conference agenda itself is covered

Speaker: NA
Text: detail in the report. I just comment that

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary item dealt with nuclear testing

Speaker: NA
Text: issues. We were pleased as a delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: lend our support to New Zealand and Chile in House.

Speaker: NA
Text: putting that particular item forward for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration as a supplementary item.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the conference, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Watson was appointed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: drafting committee charged with the difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: very lengthy task of drafting a resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: on the supplementary topic of nuclear testing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is a great tribute to his ability that

Speaker: NA
Text: the particular draft resolution that came

Speaker: NA
Text: forward was in fact carried by the conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Ports ( Mr Holding) attended the conference as

Speaker: NA
Text: a substitute member on the Committee for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Human Rights of Parliamentarians. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to report to the parliament that in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bucharest he was elected to fill the Asia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific vacancy on that committee and will

Speaker: NA
Text: thus continue the excellent work he has put

Speaker: NA
Text: this committee over several years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our delegation attended many meetings

Speaker: NA
Text: on during the conference. They included the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia-Pacific and 12+ groups, the Inter-Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Council, the Committee to Monitor

Speaker: NA
Text: the Situation in Cyprus and the Meeting of

Speaker: NA
Text: Women Parliamentarians. Details of all those

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberations can be found in our report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to thank the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: the delegation: the Deputy Leader, Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Calvert, Senators Denman and Woods and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members for Melbourne Ports and

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson for their commitment to the delegat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion's program. I also thank the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary, Peter Keele, whose assistance and

Speaker: NA
Text: genial company were greatly appreciated by

Speaker: NA
Text: of us all. I also extend thanks to my personal

Speaker: NA
Text: adviser, Geraldine Skinner, for her continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: of dedication to the work of the IPU.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also record our appreciation of the assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance provided by Ambassadors Walker and

Speaker: NA
Text: Campbell, the Australian embassy staff in

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia and Romania, particularly Margaret

Speaker: NA
Text: Newman and Pam MCDonald of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Foreign Affairs and Trade, who

Speaker: NA
Text: accompanied us to the conference. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the Parliamentary Library, the Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: based staff of the Department of Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: in Affairs and Trade and staff of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: the of Housing and Regional Development for the

Speaker: NA
Text: invaluable briefings they provided to the

Speaker: NA
Text: to delegation. I commend the report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LEO MCLEA Y (Watson) (12.35

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I would like to make a few remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the VISIt of the delegation to

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia. As members might be aware,

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia is one of the newer countries of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, only becoming independent from the

Speaker: NA
Text: fonner Yugoslavia on 25 June 1991. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was one of the first countries in the world to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise Slovenia as an independent state,

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so on 16 January 1992. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: something for which the Slovenes have

Speaker: NA
Text: always held Australia especially in their

Speaker: NA
Text: hearts, and the wannth of the people upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: visit of the Australian delegation was very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasing to us all.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is estimated that there are about 30,000

Speaker: NA
Text: fonner Slovenes living in Australia at present,

Speaker: NA
Text: which shows that the ties between the two

Speaker: NA
Text: countries are more than just the economic ties

Speaker: NA
Text: that countries are generally interested in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia is a very small country, about one-

Speaker: NA
Text: third the size of Tasmania, with a population

Speaker: NA
Text: of about two million people. For Australia, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is situated at a very useful place in Europe in

Speaker: NA
Text: that the port of Koper, which is on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Adriatic, would obviously be of use for

Speaker: NA
Text: people who wish to export directly into

Speaker: NA
Text: central and eastern Europe from the Asia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific region. As Slovenia arranges its

Speaker: NA
Text: transportation links to become a crossroad of

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, that port facility I think will become

Speaker: NA
Text: much more interesting for Australian export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers who could take a couple of days off their

Speaker: NA
Text: transportation time by using that port rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than the western European ports that they now

Speaker: NA
Text: use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Slovenian government is moving down

Speaker: NA
Text: the track towards privatisation and towards

Speaker: NA
Text: integrating their economy with western

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. They are on the way to becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the European Union. In Slovenia,

Speaker: NA
Text: one gets the impression of a small country

Speaker: NA
Text: which has come to grips with independence

Speaker: NA
Text: from the old Yugoslavia and which has set

Speaker: NA
Text: itself on the road to progress. After visiting

Speaker: NA
Text: the country, one is certain that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve the goal they have set themselves,

Speaker: NA
Text: that of becoming a modern European state in

Speaker: NA
Text: the middle of the new Europe.

Speaker: NA
Text: The delegation was very well looked after

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Slovene parliament, and we had some

Speaker: NA
Text: very good meetings with both officials and

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers of the country. I was particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to again make the acquaintance of my

Speaker: NA
Text: friend Zoran Thaler, the foreign minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia, who assured the delegation that

Speaker: NA
Text: Slovenia would be supporting Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: candidature for the UN Security Council. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the bonds between our two countries-and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are bonds which go both ways-are very

Speaker: NA
Text: good.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think there are increasing opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: trade between Australia and Slovenia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: there are even greater opportunities for trade

Speaker: NA
Text: that transits Slovenia destined for other parts

Speaker: NA
Text: of eastern and central Europe. Now that the

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict in Bosnia looks like being resolved,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that port of Koper will become even

Speaker: NA
Text: more important.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might just mention in passing, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that the Speaker remarked upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: IPU conference and our participation there. I

Speaker: NA
Text: found the drafting committee which came up

Speaker: NA
Text: with the resolution on nuclear testing to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very interesting contest which, in the end, got

Speaker: NA
Text: down to a contest between Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: France. The French were very well represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed by M. Baumel, who is an RPR party

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the French National Assembly,

Speaker: NA
Text: who put their case strongly. I must say that

Speaker: NA
Text: M. Baumel believed very much in nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: issues. I might conclude by reminding the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament of something he said last Thursday

Speaker: NA
Text: in Paris when he delivered a report as the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary representative of the French

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Commission. He said he doubts that

Speaker: NA
Text: the new generation of French warheads can be

Speaker: NA
Text: perfected in the current series of underground

Speaker: NA
Text: tests and that more tests may be needed. M.

Speaker: NA
Text: Baumel, unfortunately, has learned nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital and External Territories

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: Dunkley) (12.40

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-On behalf of the Joint Standing Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on the National Capital and External

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories, I present the committee's report,

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporating a dissenting report, on the Nat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ional Capital Plan-Draft amendment No. 14

Speaker: NA
Text: (Broadacre Areas) to the National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan, together with the evidence received by

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: On 10 November

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994, the Hon. Brian Howe MP, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Housing and Regional Development and

Speaker: NA
Text: the then Deputy Prime Minister, invited the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee to inquire into, and report on, draft

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment No. 14 to the National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Draft amendment No. 14 of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Plan seeks to expand the range of

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted land uses from the current 'offen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive and hazardous industries' to just the more

Speaker: NA
Text: general 'industries' covering four sites identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied as sites A, B, C, and D. The area under

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration lies within broadacre areas in

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Capital Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The area of land is bounded by Oaks Estate,

Speaker: NA
Text: the ACT-NSW border, Canberra Avenue and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Molonglo River corridor. It includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: sites currently occupied by the Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: abattoir and the Canberra tannery.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee conducted a site inspection

Speaker: NA
Text: of the area covered by draft amendment No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 on 27 February 1995. In addition, the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee took evidence from key interested

Speaker: NA
Text: parties at public hearings on 27 February and

Speaker: NA
Text: 6 March 1995. Written submissions were also

Speaker: NA
Text: received as evidence for the inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry took longer than anticipated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The investigation process raised a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: contentious issues which were debated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee over a considerable period of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This inquiry highlighted some of the diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties in looking at land use purposes operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing under two planning regimes in the nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: al capital. In the Australian Capital Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: both Commonwealth and ACT legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: operate and there are two 'plans' known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Capital Plan and the Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan, which are the responsibility of the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Capital Planning Authority and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT Planning Authority, respectively. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is inevitable that differences between the

Speaker: NA
Text: plans will occur. From time to time I wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: why land in the ACT has to be treated differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ently from land in the rest of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only reason the committee received this

Speaker: NA
Text: reference was that there was an anomaly

Speaker: NA
Text: between the National Capital Plan and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory Plan. The National Capital Plan only

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted 'hazardous and offensive industries'

Speaker: NA
Text: on the sites, while the Territory Plan permit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted 'industries' for all but one site within the

Speaker: NA
Text: draft amendment area. However, the Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan has no effect if it is inconsistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The impetus for draft amendment No. 14

Speaker: NA
Text: was an application by P.D. Mulligan (Hold-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings) Pty Ltd, the parent company of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proprietors of the Canberra abattoir, to vary

Speaker: NA
Text: its lease in the hope it could develop the site

Speaker: NA
Text: into an industrial estate of some 50 blocks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Draft amendment No. 14 does not itself

Speaker: NA
Text: result in an automatic change in land use on

Speaker: NA
Text: the abattoir site as there are mandatory pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cesses required by the ACT government

Speaker: NA
Text: before any change in land use, or any devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment application, can be approved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Draft amendment No. 14 raised several

Speaker: NA
Text: important issues which are dealt with in detail

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report. The committee considered the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of the area of sites A, B, C, and D

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed in draft amendment No. 14. An

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of the issues, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: amenity of nearby residents; the need for an

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate buffer zone to allow screening

Speaker: NA
Text: between any development in the area and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra Avenue; and the concerns of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queanbeyan City Council. The need to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies between the National Capital Plan

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Territory Plan led the committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: conclude that it would be more appropriate if

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of draft amendment No. 14 was

Speaker: NA
Text: confined to sites A, Band D, thereby exclud-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing site C. Consequently, the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: recommends that draft amendment No. 14, as

Speaker: NA
Text: originally proposed, not be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, the committee recommends that the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital Plan's range of permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: land use be expanded to permit industry on

Speaker: NA
Text: sites A, Band D, the details of which are

Speaker: NA
Text: given in the report, and that any industry

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed be subject to environmental assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. This recommendation is conditional on

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of undertakings being fulfilled, and

Speaker: NA
Text: these undertakings are outlined in the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee recommends that site C not

Speaker: NA
Text: be used for industry but permits the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: range of non-special uses for broadacre areas

Speaker: NA
Text: in the National Capital Plan. In conclusion, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to thank the committee members for

Speaker: NA
Text: their participation in the committee's deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations. I particularly thank the secretariat and

Speaker: NA
Text: those people who worked on this very com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex issue. On behalf of the committee, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to thank all those who gave

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence to this inquiry in submissions and

Speaker: NA
Text: those who also gave evidence at public

Speaker: NA
Text: hearings.

Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Text: Fraser) (12.45 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Even though there was some dispute in this

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry on the National Capital Plan, the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on the National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: and External Territories nevertheless con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues to work harmoniously in its processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a dissenting report from this inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the chair, the member for Dunkley ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chynoweth), has said. Five of the members

Speaker: NA
Text: signed the dissenting report, and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: unusual. The issue in the inquiry was really

Speaker: NA
Text: about the process through which planning

Speaker: NA
Text: should take place in the ACT. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: signed the dissenting report considered that

Speaker: NA
Text: the process should involve, in this case,

Speaker: NA
Text: deciding on the needs for industrial land and

Speaker: NA
Text: deciding where in the city industrial estates

Speaker: NA
Text: should be best located and then planning it

Speaker: NA
Text: properly. That is not what happened in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this case an abattoir owner decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: he wanted to move his abattoir elsewhere and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to make as much out of the land that

Speaker: NA
Text: he occupied as possible, asked for permission

Speaker: NA
Text: to redevelop that land as an industrial estate.

Speaker: NA
Text: If he had received the agreement he had been

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking, he would have been driving the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of industrial development in the ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: at his own convenience rather than in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the best planning process and the best

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics of the location for an industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: estate in the ACT.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the dissenting members considered that

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate evidence had been given to judge

Speaker: NA
Text: whether this was the best location for an

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial estate, that it was therefore inappro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate to give approval for this application and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the land should have been returned to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT government for it to then consider what

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate use should be. In a very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully worded dissent, we said:

Speaker: NA
Text: While recognising that there would be risks in its

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed investment as a developer, and acknow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledging that betterment would be payable to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT Government, there is no justification for the

Speaker: NA
Text: present lessee potentially to profit from such a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial change of use-

Speaker: NA
Text: as he was proposing or requesting-

Speaker: NA
Text: nor for it automatically to become the developer of

Speaker: NA
Text: what would be effectively a new industrial suburb

Speaker: NA
Text: without competing for that right.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a question of the balance of return to an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual lessee as against the whole com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity and also about the role for individual

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative as against the proper planning

Speaker: NA
Text: process in the interests of the whole com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity of the territory and in this case the

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding town of Queanbeyan.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore oppose the recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: in its original form, or its amended form, and

Speaker: NA
Text: propose that the land be returned to the ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: government. If there were a need for an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional industrial estate-about which quite

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient evidence was given to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee-then the ACT government could

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to that in the appropriate way. In

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, I would like to thank the chair for

Speaker: NA
Text: his effective role in this quite difficult inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee secretariat and, in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee secretary, Meg Crooks, for her

Speaker: NA
Text: very impartial handling of this inquiry.

Speaker: Mr SMYTH
Text: Canberra) (12.50 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the House for this opportunity to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: on the report entitled Draft amendment No. 14

Speaker: NA
Text: (Broadacre Areas) to the National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan. The Joint Standing Committee on the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital and External Territories has

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that the original draft amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment not be agreed to. The committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken great care in its deliberations to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the residents of Oaks Estate were protect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed from both environmental degradation and

Speaker: NA
Text: various pollutants, such as noise and odours,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are common hazards of industrial sites

Speaker: NA
Text: and also to ensure that there is a buffer zone,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is marked C on the maps.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has also noted that the

Speaker: NA
Text: process by which draft amendment No. 14

Speaker: NA
Text: was conceived and developed raises some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about land use and planning in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT and some of the ad hoc nature of how

Speaker: NA
Text: that goes about. Indeed, before the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Public Works at this very

Speaker: NA
Text: moment are other works that highlight the

Speaker: NA
Text: process that faces the development of Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra.

Speaker: NA
Text: With that in mind, I am pleased that the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT government and the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: have established the metropolitan Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: growth strategy review to see whether some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these dilemmas that led to the dissenting

Speaker: NA
Text: report can be ironed out. As the chair of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, the member for Dunkley ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chynoweth) has said, the time spent on this

Speaker: NA
Text: report indicates the difficulties that the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee experienced. Hopefully, the new review

Speaker: NA
Text: will overcome some of those anomalies and

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties. But before this process even

Speaker: NA
Text: continues the applicant will now have to

Speaker: NA
Text: become involved in the ACT planning pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: broad range of uses permitted in broadacre

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in the National Capital Plan be amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. It wants to limit an expanded range of

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted industry to sites A, Band D only,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land to the west of Oaks Estate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: north side of Canberra A venue and to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that industry proposed for sites A, Band D is

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to environmental assessment and is all

Speaker: NA
Text: conditional on the undertakings put before it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has also recommended that all

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, including hazardous or offensive

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, not be permitted on site C but that

Speaker: NA
Text: the normal range of non-special area uses for

Speaker: NA
Text: broadacre areas in the National Capital Plan

Speaker: NA
Text: be permitted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the secretariat staff, and in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: Meg Crooks, of the Joint Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on the National Capital and External Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies for all their hard work in the writing and

Speaker: NA
Text: deliverance of this report. I would also like

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the work of the chairman, in

Speaker: NA
Text: working both sides to an agreeable report that

Speaker: NA
Text: is now before this House. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: report to the House.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: Dunkley)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jenkins)-

Speaker: NA
Text: In accordance with standing order 102B, the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is adjourned. The resumption of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate will be made an order of the day for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sitting Monday and the member will

Speaker: NA
Text: have leave to continue speaking when the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Securities Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: Perth) (12.53

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-On behalf of the Joint Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Securities, I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report on limitation on institution

Speaker: NA
Text: of criminal proceedings under section 1316 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Corporations Law, together with the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence received by the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: One of the tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Joint Committee on Corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities since its formation in 1991 has

Speaker: NA
Text: been monitoring the investigation and pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: ecution of breaches of corporate law in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s, with a particular concern about delay

Speaker: NA
Text: in resolving these matters. These events and

Speaker: NA
Text: the investigations resulting from them are now

Speaker: NA
Text: up to eight years old, with a number still to

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought before the courts. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of the Attorney-General ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lavarch), pursuant to section 1316 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations Law, to consent to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mencement of proceedings against Mr Bond,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Oates and Mr Mitchell in relation to a

Speaker: NA
Text: Bell Resources matter is a reminder that

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of great complexity requiring very

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable application of the resources of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Securities Commission, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Director of Public Prosecutions and the courts

Speaker: NA
Text: are still to be resolved.

Speaker: NA
Text: In October 1993, the Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australian Securities Commission, Mr Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, commented publicly that 'Section

Speaker: NA
Text: 1316 of the Corporations Law may impede

Speaker: NA
Text: the prosecution of corporate crime, particular-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly in complex cases'. The committee raised

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue with Mr Cameron when he appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: before a public hearing of the committee in

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1994. Mr Cameron said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The difficulty is that any such decision is itself

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of being reviewed ... The only thing that

Speaker: NA
Text: is certain is that an aggressive defendant's first ploy

Speaker: NA
Text: will be to tie us up, potentially for years, in admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istrative review of the Attorney-General's decision

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend the time. That is the reason we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: sure why there needs to be a special rule for

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate crime.

Speaker: NA
Text: Options considered by the committee in its

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry included: repealing the present limita-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion period in relation to indictable offences;

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the limitation period from five to

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years or retaining the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's discretion, with the removal of any

Speaker: NA
Text: right of review of the exercise of the discre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; or no change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Evidence before the committee focused on

Speaker: NA
Text: the distinction between indictable offences,

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to no general limitation period under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Crimes Act 1914, and summary offences,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are subject to a 12-month limitation

Speaker: NA
Text: period under the Crimes Act. Arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: favouring the abolition of the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's consent were that it will put corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate criminal prosecutions on the same basis

Speaker: NA
Text: as the general criminal law and it is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate role for the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: under the current independent prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Arguments advanced advocating retention

Speaker: NA
Text: of section 1316 stressed that the limitation

Speaker: NA
Text: period should apply to indictable offences

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Corporations Law as limitations in

Speaker: NA
Text: general act as a discipline on agencies to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure expeditious investigatory and prosecu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion processes. The committee found that

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be no limitation period for

Speaker: NA
Text: serious or indictable offences under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations Law and that section 1316 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Corporations Law should be amended

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the case of summary offences, the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee decided that these offences should be

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to a limitation period of five years

Speaker: NA
Text: without any capacity on the part of the Attor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney-General to extend. The committee found

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Crimes Act limitation period of 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months would not allow proper investigation

Speaker: NA
Text: of summary offences under the Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Law, some of which involve quite serious

Speaker: NA
Text: breaches of corporate behaviour. I draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: House's attention to the opinion tabled in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of this matter by Senator Cooney.

Speaker: NA
Text: A central point in the submissions advocat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing retention of the limitation period and the

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion in the Attorney-General was that

Speaker: NA
Text: such a discretion provided enhanced accounta-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for the exercise of the already wide

Speaker: NA
Text: powers of the ASC and the DPP. Contrary

Speaker: NA
Text: arguments to the committee stressed two

Speaker: NA
Text: important points of accountability: judicial or

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative review of a prosecution deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and the courts limiting the commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of prosecutions due to abuse of process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recent decisions indicate that suspect pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings will not easily escape the court's

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutiny. The committee does not agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: the addition of a discretion in the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General to allow an extended period of

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution will enhance this protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee concluded that the current

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion of the Attorney-General does not

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly add to the proper and desirable

Speaker: NA
Text: level of protection of persons accused under

Speaker: NA
Text: various provisions of the Corporations Law.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well, since the creation of the office of the

Speaker: NA
Text: DPP-a statutory independent prosecuting

Speaker: NA
Text: authority-it would be anomalous for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General to retain an effective

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecutorial discretion such as that currently

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in section 1316. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that serious corporate criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: offences should be placed on the same basis

Speaker: NA
Text: as serious general criminal offences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does, however, believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the DPP and the ASC should include extra

Speaker: NA
Text: information in their annual reports to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: some better information on the DPP's deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions in relation to corporate offences. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee is concerned that in future a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: picture be presented each year of the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of current matters in the hands of the DPP,

Speaker: NA
Text: the time that has elapsed since the alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: commission of offences that may be involved

Speaker: NA
Text: but in each matter, and the state each matter has

Speaker: NA
Text: reached in the investigation, assessment and

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution process. The committee believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that such a picture will allow the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and the parliament to better ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is appropriate public information on

Speaker: NA
Text: the ASC's and the DPP's administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: this area of their responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has formally recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: in its report that future annual reports of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Securities Commission and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions provide detailed information showing

Speaker: NA
Text: the time that has elapsed since the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of alleged offences under the Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Law and the time that has elapsed since

Speaker: NA
Text: the commencement of active investigative and

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecutorial processes. I commend the report

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (12.58

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-The report on limitation on institution

Speaker: NA
Text: of criminal proceedings under section 1316 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Corporations Law of the Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Corporations and Securities just tabled by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Perth ( Mr Stephen

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith) has my endorsement. I want to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on several aspects of the report. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important that people understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: aftermath of all the disasters of the entrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: neurs of the 1980s should not generate an

Speaker: NA
Text: undue legislative response from this parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, nor should it create the expectation that

Speaker: NA
Text: every company dealing is illegal or improper.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this reference was first given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee I was concerned that this was just

Speaker: NA
Text: another instance of the ASC attempting to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend jurisdiction in a way which was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to prejudice the proper functioning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketplace and, in particular, of companies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Australian financial structure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am convinced that that is not so. My own

Speaker: NA
Text: view had been that the period of five years

Speaker: NA
Text: within which the ASC should initiate proceed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings should be retained, basically because I

Speaker: NA
Text: felt that for both summary and indictable

Speaker: NA
Text: offences it was necessary for a party at arms

Speaker: NA
Text: length to ensure that every attempt had been

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the ASC to initiate proceedings as

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as possible. Having heard the evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: and having considered the matter, however, I

Speaker: NA
Text: concur with the conclusions of this report.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been only four years since the Directhat

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of Public Prosecutions, the DPP, has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: over from the Attorney-General responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for prosecutions. I believe that the manner of

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment by the DPP replaces the role

Speaker: NA
Text: previously exercised in the prosecution sense

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Attorney-General. Accordingly, I

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the fact that this is an appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: deletion. Therefore, the committee's recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation that there should no longer be a

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity for the minister, or the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General in this instance, to give approval after

Speaker: NA
Text: five years should be proceeded with. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendation of both the DPP and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ASC. For that reason, I think there is now a

Speaker: NA
Text: better practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note the dissenting report of Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Cooney. I do not agree with that because I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it is difficult for summary offences to

Speaker: NA
Text: be prosecuted at too early a stage. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee report stated that there would still be

Speaker: NA
Text: a time within which it would be possible for

Speaker: NA
Text: summary offences to be prosecuted and be

Speaker: NA
Text: retained but that they be removed altogether

Speaker: NA
Text: for indictable offences. I believe it is appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate that the indictable offence removal be

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeded with. At the same time, I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the DPP has a responsibility to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the normal procedures and practices

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the reasonableness of prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: be considered very carefully.

Speaker: NA
Text: My worry has been, and it is a fact that was

Speaker: NA
Text: presented in evidence to the committee, that

Speaker: NA
Text: after seven years it is no longer necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep records. While there have been a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of incredible abuses of proper accounting and

Speaker: NA
Text: prudential responsibility by a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate figures, that does not mean that all

Speaker: NA
Text: have done so. It would be unreasonable if a

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution were initiated against a person

Speaker: NA
Text: simply on the basis that time has lapsed,

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution was not commenced at a reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able time and records had been destroyed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that seven-year period within which

Speaker: NA
Text: people are required to keep records needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: be kept in mind.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time I think the five-year

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation for summary offences is reasonable.

Speaker: NA
Text: For that reason I believe it is appropriate for

Speaker: NA
Text: it to be retained, as the committee has recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended. Its removal altogether does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: unlimited time will be available. It means

Speaker: NA
Text: that in any instance where the ASC recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mends prosecution the officers of the Director

Speaker: NA
Text: of Public Prosecutions will be available to

Speaker: NA
Text: supervise the exercise of that prosecution. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in that instance the report makes

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. For that reason, I support the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations of the committee and commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the chairman and the members of the secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tariat for the work they have undertaken in

Speaker: NA
Text: the preparation of this report.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Rocher)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The time allotted for statements on the

Speaker: NA
Text: report has expired. Does the member for Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to move a motion in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: report to enable it to be debated on a future

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion?

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: Perth)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! In

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with standing order 102B, the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is adjourned. The resumption of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate will be made an order of the day for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sitting Monday and the member will

Speaker: NA
Text: have leave to continue speaking when the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, Communications and

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Reports

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-On behalf of the Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Transport, Communications and Infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure, I present the following reports of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee entitled Warehouse to whaif:

Speaker: NA
Text: Efficiency of the inteiface between seaports

Speaker: NA
Text: and land transport-Final report; and Oil

Speaker: NA
Text: spills: A response strategy: Review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General's audit report-Is Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: ready to respond to a major oil spill? to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether with the minutes of proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Warehouse to whaifwas tabled in April 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: It highlighted the benefits that could be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved if Australian firms better coordinated

Speaker: NA
Text: their services along the transport chain to the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront. It revealed an 'appalling apathy,

Speaker: NA
Text: ignorance and inertia on the part of users of

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront services'. Three and a half years

Speaker: NA
Text: on there has been little change, although we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen improvements in some areas, with

Speaker: NA
Text: some service providers having shown a

Speaker: NA
Text: willingness to improve communication and

Speaker: NA
Text: coordination between parties operating at the

Speaker: NA
Text: port interface. Outdated financial, documen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary and logistic practices are continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: impediments to Australian products becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: more competitive abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: Waterfront productivity is important, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient use of transport services to the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront is even more important to export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, importers, and Australia's international

Speaker: NA
Text: competitiveness. Service providers and their

Speaker: NA
Text: customers need to develop a team approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to maximising the productivity and efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: of port related services. The committee is

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced that much greater progress would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made if the interface efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: councils, recommended in the 1992 report,

Speaker: NA
Text: had been established at all of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: major ports. Accordingly, the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: again recommended they be established in all

Speaker: NA
Text: major ports to facilitate the efficient move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of cargo to and from the waterfront and

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure effective communication and coordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation at the port interface.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now tum to electronic data interchange.

Speaker: NA
Text: The national consultative group has been

Speaker: NA
Text: successful in developing a common approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to the promotion of electronic commerce in

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport industry. However, a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: impediment to the use of electronic commerce

Speaker: NA
Text: by small business in all industries as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport sector has been the availability

Speaker: NA
Text: of cost-effective electronic data interchange

Speaker: NA
Text: softwa.re. The committee has recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth government, through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Industry, Science and

Speaker: NA
Text: Technology, fund a detailed assessment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current environment for software develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport costs to the wharf are not a

Speaker: NA
Text: priority for small exporters. However, taken

Speaker: NA
Text: together, they constitute a major factor in

Speaker: NA
Text: improving Australia's international competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness. By focusing public debate solely on

Speaker: NA
Text: the waterfront, industry associations, govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and politicians mask the many prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems which remain in the transport chain to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wharf. This is a lazy and obstructive

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to a difficult and complex logistics

Speaker: NA
Text: problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the deputy chairman, Mr Stewart

Speaker: NA
Text: MCArthur, and my fellow committee members

Speaker: NA
Text: for their cooperation in the conduct of this

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry. I thank also the committee secretariat,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the secretary, Mr Malcolm Aldons;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Les Dunn; and administrative officer, Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: June Murphy. Special thanks are due to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: John Jenkins, consultant, and Mr Robert

Speaker: NA
Text: Tranter of the Department of Transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tum now to the report in respect of oil

Speaker: NA
Text: spills. Given the adverse effect of oil spills

Speaker: NA
Text: the marine environment and the significant

Speaker: NA
Text: public interest in the Ships of shame report,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee welcomed the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: review the report of the Auditor-General: Is

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ready to respond to a major oil

Speaker: NA
Text: spill? Our work complements the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: work earlier on ship safety. Pollution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sea by oil is a major world problem. Given

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's 37,000 kilometres of coastline, and

Speaker: NA
Text: our diverse marine environment, the threat of

Speaker: NA
Text: an oil spoil is particularly significant. Thus,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is essential that Australia has an adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: resourced oil spill prevention strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The audit report focused on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime Safety Authority's management of

Speaker: NA
Text: a national oil plan to combat pollution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sea by oil. The committee notes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Maritime Safety Authority has

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to 15 of the 18 recommendations in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor's report. The committee adjudicat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed on those areas of disagreement. The key

Speaker: NA
Text: feature of an oil spill strategy is prevention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fundamental to prevention is crew competen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cy.

Speaker: NA
Text: As mentioned in the committee's Ships of

Speaker: NA
Text: shame report, human factors are the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of shipping incidents and accidents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Public and media attention focuses too often

Speaker: NA
Text: on isolated tanker collisions, ruptures and

Speaker: NA
Text: spillages. Tanker accidents, however, account

Speaker: NA
Text: for only 12 per cent of oil pollution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: marine environment. General vessel oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations account for 33 per cent and industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: discharge and urban run-off account for 37

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. The committee is concerned that

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient attention is given to other marine

Speaker: NA
Text: pollutants such as hazardous and noxious

Speaker: NA
Text: substances. Many chemicals transported by

Speaker: NA
Text: sea present greater danger to people and to

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment than crude oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has made four recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions relating to the development of shore line

Speaker: NA
Text: clean-up standards, crew competency, oil

Speaker: NA
Text: sampling practices and risk assessment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: port of Newcastle is the only authority in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia which collects samples of ships' oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Newcastle program is intended to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: awareness about the impact on the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of marine pollution and to gather oil

Speaker: NA
Text: samples as potential evidence which in the

Speaker: NA
Text: on case of prosecution may become necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the port of Newcastle commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: collecting samples of on board fuel and bilge

Speaker: NA
Text: oil from ships in harbour, there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: marked decrease in pollution incidents. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee recommended that the national

Speaker: NA
Text: plan advisory committee, as a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency, request that all its members intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce oil sampling practices similar to those in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation in Newcastle. The grounding of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iron Baron, resulting in a spillage of 350

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes of fuel oil, occurred during the review.

Speaker: NA
Text: Due to time limitations and inquiries that are

Speaker: NA
Text: under way elsewhere, only brief reference has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made to the Iron Baron in this report. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a matter that should be examined more

Speaker: NA
Text: closely by this committee in the next parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee's interim assessment sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gests that the risk assessment criteria under-

Speaker: NA
Text: rated the navigational difficulty in the River

Speaker: NA
Text: Tamar area of the Tasmanian coast where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iron Baron came to grief. In conclusion, I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the deputy chairman, Mr Stewart

Speaker: NA
Text: MCArthur, and my fellow committee members

Speaker: NA
Text: for their cooperation and support in the

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct of this inquiry. I also thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee secretariat, including the secretary,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Malcolm Aldons; the inquiry secretary,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Stephen Boyd; and the administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: officers, Mrs June Murphy and Mrs Sue Cox,

Speaker: NA
Text: for their dedicated efforts in the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: this report.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Throsby) (1.11 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to add a few words to those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: two reports just tabled by the Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Transport, Communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations and Infrastructure. As the chairman

Speaker: NA
Text: has so rightly said, little has changed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront since we reported a couple of years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. There is too much blaming others on the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront. Everyone seems to be protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: their own bailiwick. It is all very well to

Speaker: NA
Text: blame one sector but it is not as if there is

Speaker: NA
Text: one entity; it is a whole conglomerate. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a chain-and every link plays an important

Speaker: NA
Text: part. We have found too often that, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront, everyone blames the other person

Speaker: NA
Text: or the other group instead of looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. Until we can realistically come to

Speaker: NA
Text: grips with that and look at the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront-not just sectional interests-we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not going to make great strides towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the reforms that we all want.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to oil spills, in which I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular interest. Being an island continent,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is very important that we protect our coast-

Speaker: NA
Text: line. People think that when oil spills occur

Speaker: NA
Text: it is always great tankers that have come to

Speaker: NA
Text: grief. As the chairman of the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: said, it concerns such things as urban run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: and spillage from ships. In my own electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Throsby, at Shell harbour a coastal ship

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying blue metal from Bass Point to Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney two or three weeks ago ran aground

Speaker: NA
Text: through, I believe, crew incompetence-

Speaker: NA
Text: although I suppose I will get the usual angry

Speaker: NA
Text: letters for saying that. Had the wind not

Speaker: NA
Text: changed dramatically when it did, the ship

Speaker: NA
Text: would have broken on the rocks. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been an oil spill for many miles along

Speaker: NA
Text: the beaches of the south coast. We are finding

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly that, with the number of vessels

Speaker: NA
Text: coming onto the Australian coastline, the

Speaker: NA
Text: competence of the crew is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was horrified to hear on the ABC news

Speaker: NA
Text: just this morning as I was driving to Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: that a Korean ship, the Cape Star, went

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Great Barrier Reef-the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite)

Speaker: NA
Text: would be well aware of the necessity to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect that pristine area-without a pilot

Speaker: NA
Text: when there is compulsory pilotage in that

Speaker: NA
Text: region. It was a sugar ship-and the member

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: some examples of sugar ships that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with recently. This ship is under arrest

Speaker: NA
Text: in Cairns at the moment. Interestingly, no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: quite knows who owns the sugar. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: split up between 11 people. It is quite amaz-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The captain decided to go through that

Speaker: NA
Text: area without a pilot-even though there is

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory pilotage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hear from the unions-they are contacting

Speaker: NA
Text: me again later today-that there is a question

Speaker: NA
Text: about crew wages. How many times do we on

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee hear that story. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: underpaid, underfed and physically abused

Speaker: NA
Text: crews on these ships. It all comes down to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of crew competence. It is time that

Speaker: NA
Text: we looked at the competence of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: crews that are coming to Australia. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: coastline is at risk. Despite recent changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the law, the final person who will pay for the

Speaker: NA
Text: clean-up to the Australian coastline when it is

Speaker: NA
Text: polluted with dirty, greasy oil is the Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian taxpayer. We will be paying for it. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the captain of the Cape Star is fined

Speaker: NA
Text: severely and put in gaol and that this non-

Speaker: NA
Text: sense will stop. I commend the report. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the chairman for his exemplary

Speaker: NA
Text: leading of that committee. I also commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee staff for their work.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Rocher)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The time allotted for statements on

Speaker: NA
Text: reports has expired. Does the chairman wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to move a motion in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: reports to enable them to be debated on a

Speaker: NA
Text: future occasion?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! In

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with standing order 102B, the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is adjourned. The resumption of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate will be made an order of the day for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sitting Monday. The member will

Speaker: NA
Text: have leave to continue speaking when the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUBCONTRACTORS

Speaker: NA
Text: (COMMONWEALTH DEPARTMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: AND AUTHORITIES PAYMENTS)

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGIS LA TION

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: Dawson) (1.17

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I fix the next sitting Monday as the

Speaker: NA
Text: day on which I will present the Subcontrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors (Commonwealth Departments and Auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: orities Payments) Bill 1995. Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, in doing so, I seek your indulgence

Speaker: NA
Text: to explain to the House that I propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: circulate a draft copy of the bill and a draft

Speaker: NA
Text: explanatory memorandum I have prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: various organisations, such as industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: professional groups, consumer bodies and

Speaker: NA
Text: individual subcontractors, et cetera. I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking the maximum possible degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel that, if it is to succeed, this bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: require a detailed analysis not only of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legal and constitutional ramifications and

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements but also of those associations

Speaker: NA
Text: and individuals who have the day-to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of proposing, financing, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structing and servicing in Australia's contract-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industries, the main one of which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: building industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also recognise the interest in this matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members and staff of the Ioint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Public Works and, more particularly, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the constituent subcontractor Mr Ken Weir.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is a plumber in Mackay who has seen me

Speaker: NA
Text: regularly over many years on this matter. I

Speaker: NA
Text: also thank the clerks of the House for their

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in framing the draft bill. Without

Speaker: NA
Text: their help, and at times their inspiration, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill would not have advanced even to this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: KENNETT GOVERNMENT

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: MCEwen) (1.19 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House take note of the devastation

Speaker: NA
Text: caused to small business and rural communities by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government's policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: In all the discussions of the effects and

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of privatisation its effect on the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual lives and communities of rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians has been totally overlooked. That

Speaker: NA
Text: also applies to the effect on individual lives

Speaker: NA
Text: in communities of rural Victoria following the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction and doubling of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: electronic gaming machines in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social policies since 1945 combined with

Speaker: NA
Text: other features like population mobility and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and technological factors more

Speaker: NA
Text: generally have all improved the status of rural

Speaker: NA
Text: people. Whilst there is a convergence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of rural and metropolitan people, and

Speaker: NA
Text: similarities concerning disadvantage such as

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty and isolation, rural disadvantage is

Speaker: NA
Text: found across a number of social, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and service indices compared with urban

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These disadvantages include higher poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: and unemployment levels in rural Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: more extensive mortality and morbidity

Speaker: NA
Text: rates-for example, the VFF has claimed that

Speaker: NA
Text: children on farms are three times more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to die from an accident than their city

Speaker: NA
Text: counterparts-higher price levels in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, reduced educational and occupational

Speaker: NA
Text: attainment and expectations, and reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: access to health and welfare services. They

Speaker: NA
Text: also must face additional factors such as

Speaker: NA
Text: flood, fire, drought and extremes of tempera-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture sometimes destroying both life and means

Speaker: NA
Text: of livelihood, yet the Victorian government is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally ignoring the needs of rural Victorians

Speaker: NA
Text: and rural business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The divisions between people, wealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: decision makers mirror the division between

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and rural Australia. Australia's cities

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided ideal locations for capital-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, population size, communications for

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, transport, markets, consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: and labour but there has been no serious

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt since the 1970s to tackle regional

Speaker: NA
Text: development. Meanwhile, the rural sector has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in long-term relative decline-farming

Speaker: NA
Text: and small towns.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February 1995 the National Rural Out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look Conference heard that farmers of beef,

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep, wool and wheat could not expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase their resource base. Condliffe states

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of farmers fell by 15,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 15 years to 1989, the farm work force by

Speaker: NA
Text: 32,000 and the total rural work force by

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000. Lawrence predicted that 45,000

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers would leave the land in the decade

Speaker: NA
Text: following 1987. Condliffe argues that:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the increasing rationalisation and privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: of government services to country towns further

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasises the decline of employment opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, and furthers the exodus to the cities. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: rural towns rely upon such services not only for the

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs provided but the income input into the local

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. This, coupled with the restructuring of

Speaker: NA
Text: other industries like meatworks, many of which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been closed across rural Australia ...

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also argued that:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... new technologies, in communications, ration-

Speaker: NA
Text: alisation of the transport industry, and continued

Speaker: NA
Text: decline of manufacturing further exacerbates the

Speaker: NA
Text: plight of these communi tie.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Evatt Research Centre has found that the

Speaker: NA
Text: pivotal role of the public sector as a major

Speaker: NA
Text: employer in rural Australia 'is increasingly no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer the case'. Given that in rural towns the

Speaker: NA
Text: public sector was the largest employer, tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally providing stability through seasonal

Speaker: NA
Text: and other variations in the local economy, the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of privatisation can be disturbing for a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of reasons.

Speaker: NA
Text: Communities are hit twice when the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment opportunities as well as the services

Speaker: NA
Text: are privatised and rationalised away from

Speaker: NA
Text: local control. On the question of privatisation

Speaker: NA
Text: of electricity, there is no definitive answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to whether the service wiIl be cheaper. In fact

Speaker: NA
Text: rural community rating in Victoria is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished, effective from the year 2000. In

Speaker: NA
Text: some overseas cases it has become more

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive to the consumers while a minority

Speaker: NA
Text: of executives and captains of industry realise

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is what is happening in Victoria. The

Speaker: NA
Text: top end of town is doing very well. If you are

Speaker: NA
Text: a mate of Kennett, a mate of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, you get appointed to all the boards, you

Speaker: NA
Text: get appointed to run the amalgamated coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cils and you get increased licences to run

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger casinos-more poker machines and

Speaker: NA
Text: more gaming machines-without inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: without examination, while in rural Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the rural areas I represent, devastation is

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, if you look at my own elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate you will see that the area around Lake

Speaker: NA
Text: Eildon is well known in Australia. It is at the

Speaker: NA
Text: foothills of the southern alps. It is well

Speaker: NA
Text: for tourism and is a very diversified farming

Speaker: NA
Text: area. If you take the towns of Mansfield,

Speaker: NA
Text: Eildon, AlexandrC' and Yea, you wiIl find that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last two years over 100 public sector

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs have gone. They have gone from the

Speaker: NA
Text: state Rivers and Water Supply Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Department of Conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Natural Resources, from Vic Roads and from

Speaker: NA
Text: education. They have gone from every Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: torian public sector; they have vanished.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some 50 houses now for sale in

Speaker: NA
Text: Eildon. You cannot sell a house there. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: in Alexandra a week ago and five businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: were closing in the main street there. Small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses in Yea despair. This is the direct

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the Kennett government. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct result of a lack of concern and a lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of care for small rural communities, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will hear opposition members get up

Speaker: NA
Text: and support Kennett. They have never been

Speaker: NA
Text: to a country town and talked to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: there. They have never been there and have

Speaker: NA
Text: not spoken to people. They will not deny that

Speaker: NA
Text: 68,000 jobs in the public sector have gone

Speaker: NA
Text: from Victoria. With the amalgamation of local

Speaker: NA
Text: government in Victoria, it is now estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that a further 10,000 jobs are going to vanish.

Speaker: NA
Text: as That is devastating, but on top of that deva-

Speaker: NA
Text: station caused by the so-called economic

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalism-I call it economic stupidity-we

Speaker: NA
Text: now have in Victoria a doubling of the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of electronic gaming machines-a

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling, without any examination or inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you talk to people in small business in

Speaker: NA
Text: rural areas, they will tell you what is happen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. About 13 per cent of a family's spending

Speaker: NA
Text: is called discretionary spending. With the now

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling of electronic gaming machines-new

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria-the number of people using that

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary spending on gaming is increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and the amount of that spending going

Speaker: NA
Text: into small business is diminishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Victoria it has been a double whammy

Speaker: NA
Text: for country towns. They have got to cope

Speaker: NA
Text: with Kennett and the lack of National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: concern for them; they have got to cope with

Speaker: NA
Text: the quite massive job losses from the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, which are factual and unarguable. If

Speaker: NA
Text: small business loses two or three wages in the

Speaker: NA
Text: known town, that is less income coming into the

Speaker: NA
Text: business. It is palpable, it is evidential, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, on top of that, people cop an uncar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Liberal government. It has said, 'Let's

Speaker: NA
Text: double the number of electronic gaming

Speaker: NA
Text: machines; let's not ask whether that is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be effective or what the social conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences are; let's not ask whether small

Speaker: NA
Text: business in rural areas can cope with it.' It

Speaker: NA
Text: says, 'No, we'll just do it.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'Connor-Double-barrelled.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: That's right. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett's rural bush recession, and boy is it

Speaker: NA
Text: out there! I am always amused when I hear

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition members-and we are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to them today-say that economic

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalism is good. I am pleased to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo ( Mr Reid) in the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber and I will make sure what he says is

Speaker: NA
Text: circulated in Bendigo. People in Bendigo, like

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the small towns in my electorate, know

Speaker: NA
Text: full well that the massive job losses caused by

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett and MCNamara are hurting small

Speaker: NA
Text: business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural Victoria is bleeding. Rural Victoria is

Speaker: NA
Text: being devastated. Fifteen schools in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate have gone to history. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers, 15 wages. Fifteen families have

Speaker: NA
Text: from my rural areas. Yet Kennett only says,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'So what?' We will get from the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about how this is good because the public

Speaker: NA
Text: sector has to be rationalised and the private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector is going to pick up the jobs. Rubbish!

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple fact in Victoria is that, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: 68,000 to 70,000 public sector jobs gone,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are still over 8,000 people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been picked up by the private sector. This

Speaker: NA
Text: trickle-down effect we hear the Reagan

Speaker: NA
Text: economists talk about is one of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: myths. Newt Gingrich, the great ally of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, talks about the trickle-down

Speaker: NA
Text: effect: 'If we make people suffer a lot we

Speaker: NA
Text: all be better off.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The evidence is clear, unarguable and

Speaker: NA
Text: factual: rural Victoria is bleeding; rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria is being devastated. The whole and

Speaker: NA
Text: sole reason for that is the massive cut to

Speaker: NA
Text: public sector and the massive impost of

Speaker: NA
Text: gaming on small rural towns. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'Connor-1 second the motion and allocated

Speaker: NA
Text: reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Text: La Trobe) (1.30 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: am delighted to rise to respond to that bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: dri vel by the member for MCEwen ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cleeland). I note that the motion before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House takes note of the devastation

Speaker: NA
Text: caused to small business and rural communities

Speaker: NA
Text: I did not hear much about small businessincrease

Speaker: NA
Text: not much at all. Recently it has been a generstrong

Speaker: NA
Text: al tactic of the member for MCEwen and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dunkley ( Mr Chynoweth) to

Speaker: NA
Text: come into this House and spend all of their

Speaker: NA
Text: time talking about the Kennett state governdollar

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and state policies, as is in fact the tactic

Speaker: NA
Text: of the candidate standing against me in the

Speaker: NA
Text: seat of La Trobe in Victoria, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: frightened to death to talk about federal

Speaker: NA
Text: issues. They will not talk about Paul Keating.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will not talk about Keating policy or

Speaker: NA
Text: inept, invisible and unfunctioning cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: this Keating government. They want to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about Kennett and the state of Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me tell you a little bit about Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: and the state of Victoria. Let us talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 small business investment in Victoria so far

Speaker: NA
Text: gone in 1995-96-four months. Doosan Farmland

Speaker: NA
Text: products have a $36 million project for a

Speaker: NA
Text: malting plant in Geelong. Murray Goulburn

Speaker: NA
Text: at Cobram have a $40 million joint venture

Speaker: NA
Text: with Mitsubishi and Meiji Milk products of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan to supply infant formula to Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bonlac have a $150 million investment to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a world-class dairy powder plant in

Speaker: NA
Text: not Gippsland leading to 120 jobs. Olivetti have

Speaker: NA
Text: a $27 million investment to establish a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional headquarters in Melbourne that will

Speaker: NA
Text: create 48 jobs. The Holden's Engine Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany have a $315 million investment creating

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 permanent jobs. Ford Australia have a

Speaker: NA
Text: will $1,000 million investment, including design

Speaker: NA
Text: and tooling for the new Falcon.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Access Economics investment monitor

Speaker: NA
Text: records the value of publicly known invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment projects. The value of listed projects in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victoria increased from $13.9 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1994 to $15.4 billion in September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995, a rise of 11 per cent. Victoria had 14

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the total for projects which are

Speaker: NA
Text: to particular states; however, Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria has a higher share, 25 per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: committed projects as distinct from possible

Speaker: NA
Text: or potential projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that Victoria's business investment has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: bounded strongly, particularly since we got

Speaker: NA
Text: rid of the Cain and Kirner governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment in equipment has risen 44 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past three years, including a 12 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1994-95. The upturn has included

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in manufacturing investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment growth in Victoria for 1995-96 is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be above the national average.

Speaker: NA
Text: The launch last week of the multimillion

Speaker: NA
Text: technology park at Ballarat University

Speaker: NA
Text: has huge potential for rural Victoria and the

Speaker: NA
Text: many small businesses that are actively invol-

Speaker: NA
Text: are ved in information technology and telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications. That site alone is expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ around 350 people within three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: the With the university offering an information

Speaker: NA
Text: of technology degree, complete with 20 higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education contribution scheme exempt schol-

Speaker: NA
Text: arships as well as 10 traineeships, rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria is well on the way to greater employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment opportunities for rural youth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Projects such as the Ballarat University

Speaker: NA
Text: technology park have been actively pursued

Speaker: NA
Text: by the state government. That is the Kennett
