Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian state government, I tell the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for MCEwen. They generate jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural Victoria during the construction

Speaker: NA
Text: stages and offer employment in the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: for rural graduates from our regional universi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. Victoria is open for business-small,

Speaker: NA
Text: medium and international businesses that are

Speaker: NA
Text: employing our youth and providing education-

Speaker: NA
Text: al opportunities that the Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not even begin to understand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the change of government in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: in October 1992, we have seen a real change

Speaker: NA
Text: in the outlook of many Victorians. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly evident in the area of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business. The member for MCEwen reckons

Speaker: NA
Text: we are losing small businesses rapidly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: facts are that 12,000 new small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: have been started in Victoria since October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992 across all business sectors-from manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing and processing to services ranging

Speaker: NA
Text: in size from a large plant or factory to the

Speaker: NA
Text: small comer shop. Thirty thousand new jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: have been created in small business in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria since October 1992. There are now close

Speaker: NA
Text: to 210,000 small businesses in Victoria-

Speaker: NA
Text: some 96 per cent of all enterprises, employing

Speaker: NA
Text: 760,000 Victorians and making up over 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the private sector work force.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Victorian government is continuing its

Speaker: NA
Text: program of cutting red tape for small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness-something the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: could well take as an example. Some 450

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations were repealed or sunsetted in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1993, while the rate of new regulation making

Speaker: NA
Text: is at its lowest level since the 1960s. Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business Victoria handles around 70,000

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries a year, and it is focused on facilitasmall

Speaker: NA
Text: ting service delivery to ensure optimal service

Speaker: NA
Text: to small business operators throughout Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria.

Speaker: NA
Text: An important point that needs to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the Yellow Pages small business health

Speaker: NA
Text: index published in May of this year showed

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming support by small business for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government-a point that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for MCEwen and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Dunkley constantly

Speaker: NA
Text: miss. Sixty-five per cent of small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the coalition can best look after

Speaker: NA
Text: their interests; only five per cent believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: ALP would do the right job for small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness. In Victoria, the coalition is ranked ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ALP on all factors-including handling

Speaker: NA
Text: the state economy overall, 80 per cent; reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing unemployment, 61 per cent; minimising

Speaker: NA
Text: strikes, 43 per cent; workplace reform, 73 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; reducing taxes and charges, 42 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: and reducing red tape, 40 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Yellow Pages survey went on to show

Speaker: NA
Text: that nearly six out of 10 of the small busines-

Speaker: NA
Text: ses surveyed believe the federal Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government's economic policies work against

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of small business. Got that?

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal government policies, the policies this

Speaker: NA
Text: mob over there do not want you to know

Speaker: NA
Text: about, work against the interests of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business. This includes taxes, bureaucracy,

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of incentives, lack of understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: the needs of small business, industrial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions policies including unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: policies, government charges and superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the latest Yellow Pages survey

Speaker: NA
Text: released at the end of August, Victorian-and

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australian-small businesses lead the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation in confidence about their prospects for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 12 months. The index found that a

Speaker: NA
Text: net 52 per cent of Victorian small business

Speaker: NA
Text: proprietors were confident about their per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance in the next 12 months; that expecta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for sales, employment and profitability

Speaker: NA
Text: growth for the current quarter have improved,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that perceptions of the current state of the

Speaker: NA
Text: national economy have, on the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: slumped dramatically.

Speaker: NA
Text: An article on 15 November in, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Morning Herald, talked about

Speaker: NA
Text: to medium sized business enterprises

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to federal government purchasing

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. I note the article by Nina Field says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's dynamic small to medium-sized enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prises are still confronted by major hurdles when

Speaker: NA
Text: selling to the $30 billion government market,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to a study to be released today by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Minister for Administrative Services, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Walker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Walker essentially says that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's reforms and purchasing policy still

Speaker: NA
Text: have not got around to doing the job for small

Speaker: NA
Text: business. We brought down this report some

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 months ago, and we made major recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations in this House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government should do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about controlling its 30,000 employees who

Speaker: NA
Text: place orders for government business-at least

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 million worth of purchasing by the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government. Something like 13,000

Speaker: NA
Text: government credit cards float around all over

Speaker: NA
Text: the place, and we expect small and medium

Speaker: NA
Text: sized businesses to try to get their fair share

Speaker: NA
Text: of government business. It does not work. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: The study found that locating the right

Speaker: NA
Text: buyer for goods and services was the single

Speaker: NA
Text: most important barrier to almost one-fifth of

Speaker: NA
Text: all small and medium sized business enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prises. The main reason they had difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: finding government buyers was generally that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had very few sales staff who could

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that small and medium sized busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses cannot afford a lot of overheads,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot afford the marketing spent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: direct sales people.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does the government do to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: easier? It has 30,000 individuals who can

Speaker: NA
Text: place purchase orders. I might add that these

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000 individuals do not pay much attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to common use contracts, either. In recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times I have had personal experience where

Speaker: NA
Text: the government signs a common use contract

Speaker: NA
Text: at a price, and then the buyers go out to try

Speaker: NA
Text: to knock down the individual supplier still

Speaker: NA
Text: further, destroying the whole concept of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that Melbourne in Victoria is a

Speaker: NA
Text: true gateway to Australia. It is the home of

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry. My electorate of La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe has particularly good examples of high

Speaker: NA
Text: tech industries dealing with high tech elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tronics and communications. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Text: Corio) (1.40 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the member for MCEwen ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cleeland) for the motion before the House. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a member representing a rural and provincial

Speaker: NA
Text: area, he fully understands the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett's bush recession is having on his

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me say the

Speaker: NA
Text: damage is not confined to the electors of

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen. In Geelong the city has been se-

Speaker: NA
Text: verely hit by the Kennett government's

Speaker: NA
Text: regressive policies. While small and medium

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses bleed with gambling revenues

Speaker: NA
Text: syphoning off money from the income stream

Speaker: NA
Text: in the city, Jeff Kennett has lined the pockets

Speaker: NA
Text: of his Liberal mates in Melbourne with

Speaker: NA
Text: obscene concessions to the Crown Casino.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kennett government has destroyed over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,000 public sector jobs in Geelong. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent to an enterprise as large as

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong's second largest employer, Godfrey

Speaker: NA
Text: Hirst. The result of those cutbacks has been

Speaker: NA
Text: that not only the quality services to Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: residents in health, education, community

Speaker: NA
Text: services and transport have all declined but,

Speaker: NA
Text: in addition to that, some $30 million to $40

Speaker: NA
Text: million has been sucked out of Geelong's

Speaker: NA
Text: income stream in wages-a major part of

Speaker: NA
Text: which would have been spent in small and

Speaker: NA
Text: medium private businesses in Geelong.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not the only area where the residents

Speaker: NA
Text: of Geelong have been hit. For too long

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong residents were denied their democrat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic right to elect their local government repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives by the Kennett government, ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed with centralising power in Spring

Speaker: NA
Text: Street. All over Victoria, in the seats of

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan, Ballarat, Bendigo, MCEwen and

Speaker: NA
Text: Dunkley, councils have been abolished and

Speaker: NA
Text: municipalities are currently being adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered by Kennett's commissars-people who

Speaker: NA
Text: owe their loyalty to their political masters in

Speaker: NA
Text: Spring Street and certainly not to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of their municipalities, nor the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. Victoria in 1995 is somewhat remi-

Speaker: NA
Text: niscent of Stalin's Russia in the 1950s, with

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole strata of local government abolished

Speaker: NA
Text: and highjacked and now controlled by Spring

Speaker: NA
Text: Street puppet masters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The workers of Geelong have also been hit

Speaker: NA
Text: by this state government. They remember Jeff

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett's pre-election promise that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be no worse off under the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations policy of his government. They

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the awful betrayal as they were

Speaker: NA
Text: given the option of the contract or the sack by

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett. They remember the example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: librarian who had her wages cut by over

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 by the policies of this state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. And they fled in droves to the protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the federal industrial award system

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by Paul Keating and this Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government. They know that John Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: and the federal coalition have always support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed Kennett's regressive labour market poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies. They remember Jeff Kennett's recent

Speaker: NA
Text: pronouncement that with the election of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government workers in Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: would have nowhere else to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not only the fact that Jeff Kennett has

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted to cut their wages and conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not only the fact that their businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: have suffered with the proliferation of gam-

Speaker: NA
Text: bling. It is not only the fact that their schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: kids and hospitals have been cut back while

Speaker: NA
Text: Jeff Kennett has lined the pockets of his

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal mates in Melbourne. It is the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government has waged an unprin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipled war against the individual democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of the citizens of the state. It is this

Speaker: NA
Text: that really has made decent Liberals sick to

Speaker: NA
Text: their stomachs. Kennett has: sacked local

Speaker: NA
Text: councils, installed unelected commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: and delayed local government elections;

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked the independence of the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: judiciary; removed the legal right of appeal of

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens in over 100 pieces of legislation;

Speaker: NA
Text: removed their planning rights; restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the Administrative Appeals Tribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal; and more.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is this unprincipled attack on the legal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of individual Victorians which has

Speaker: NA
Text: shamed decent Liberals who expected more

Speaker: NA
Text: from their state government. Indeed, we

Speaker: NA
Text: expect more from the Liberal member for La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe ( Mr Charles), the member for Isaacs

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Atkinson) and the member for Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Reid) in this House today and in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. The honourable member for La Trobe

Speaker: NA
Text: defends the Kennett government as the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: pion of small business. Who has lowered the

Speaker: NA
Text: business taxes in this country? Who has got

Speaker: NA
Text: the inflation rate under two per cent? Who

Speaker: NA
Text: has promoted growth to the extent of four per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent a year? Who has got interest rates to

Speaker: NA
Text: manageable levels? Who has reduced indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial disputation to the lowest level in 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years? A federal Labor government! All of

Speaker: NA
Text: those elements have assisted small and medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: um businesses in Geelong. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Bendigo) (1.45 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: political language, this motion is known as a

Speaker: NA
Text: boomerang motion. The member for MCEwen

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Cleeland) has thrown the boomerang out,

Speaker: NA
Text: it has gone around, and it is going to come

Speaker: NA
Text: back and smack him right behind the ear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fancy having the gall and the hypocrisy to

Speaker: NA
Text: accuse Victoria of causing the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian small business and the rural sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: How gross can you be?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labor Party has had high

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing governments, like the Keating govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It has had high interest rate govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, like the Keating government. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: go back a few years to when interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: were eight and nine per cent. What did this

Speaker: NA
Text: government do? It pushed the interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: from eight and nine per cent right up to 21

Speaker: NA
Text: and 23 per cent. The Keating government-

Speaker: NA
Text: through the 'recession we had to have'-

Speaker: NA
Text: fact bankrupted hundreds and hundreds. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Keating) forced up interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: and bankrupted hundreds and hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Corio ( Mr O'Connor) and

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for MCEwen have the gall to get

Speaker: NA
Text: up here and say that this was caused by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian state government-a government

Speaker: NA
Text: which had to take over from the Cain-Kirner

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor governments, the Keating government's

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor mates, which had incurred debts and

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities of $42,000 million in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: What a disgrace! You should be ashamed to

Speaker: NA
Text: even be in this House. Fancy bringing for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward a motion like this-'devastation caused

Speaker: NA
Text: to small business and rural communities'.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did you care when my rural com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity in Bendigo in central Victoria had the

Speaker: NA
Text: second worst drought in our history? There

Speaker: NA
Text: was not one dollar of drought relief from the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government-not one cent, nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet you have the gall to get up and say that

Speaker: NA
Text: you are supporting small business and rural

Speaker: NA
Text: communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Did the member for MCEwen know that his

Speaker: NA
Text: policies bankrupted hundreds of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates like mine when interest rates went

Speaker: NA
Text: from nine per cent to 21 and 23 per cent?

Speaker: NA
Text: You acknowledged that we had a drought

Speaker: NA
Text: which was the second worst in our history

Speaker: NA
Text: and that our rural people are suffering. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course they suffered. But you did nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: You did not lift one finger-not one-to help

Speaker: NA
Text: those people. They remember it and they will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to remember it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am delighted by the offer of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for MCEwen to circulate my speech in his

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. I would love you to do it. Will you

Speaker: NA
Text: promise me that you will? No. He is shaking

Speaker: NA
Text: his head. It is a typical Labor stunt-make the

Speaker: NA
Text: offer and then get rid of it, like the l-a-w law

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cuts. What ever happened to those tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts? You lied to the Australian people. You

Speaker: NA
Text: said the tax cuts were legislated and that

Speaker: NA
Text: every small business person in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: would get tax cuts. What did you do? As

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as you got back into government, you

Speaker: NA
Text: got rid of them. You did not honour your

Speaker: NA
Text: promise. You lied.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Nehl)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Actually, the chair did not lie. You might

Speaker: NA
Text: address your remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fancy government members having the gall

Speaker: NA
Text: to come into this House with a motion like

Speaker: NA
Text: this. I have indicated to you the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: that had on small business people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: community. They will never forget what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party has done to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most farmers operate as small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people. They are the true small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people. They operate as a partnership or as a

Speaker: NA
Text: family company and try to run their farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are really the people who are suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: under the policies of the Keating government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an absolute disgrace that this member has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought this motion before the House and is

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to palm off the responsibility for this

Speaker: NA
Text: onto the state government in Victoria, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is trying to repair the damage of an incurred

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and liability of $42,000 million, incurred

Speaker: NA
Text: by your Labor mates from Victoria-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cain-Kirner governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the member for Corio not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what happened with the Pyramid Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Society, not understand the debt that was

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred from it and what the government

Speaker: NA
Text: did-selling the State Bank? (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: Dunkley) (1.50

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-In possibly the last speech by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo ( Mr Reid) he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: justifying the standard of the Kennett govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. He has been saying that we made an

Speaker: NA
Text: offer, then we withdrew it, and it was a lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me show you who the liar is: the liar is

Speaker: NA
Text: Jeffrey 'Glib' Kennett from Victoria. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet that he distributed throughout my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and all over Victoria back in 1992

Speaker: NA
Text: before the last election, he stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Coalition New Jobs Initiative will generate

Speaker: NA
Text: between 30,000 and 40,000 new jobs for Victorians

Speaker: NA
Text: by giving employers the incentive to take on new

Speaker: NA
Text: employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Private sector employers-

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly who we are talking about-

Speaker: NA
Text: who take on new employees over and above their

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian workforce numbers as at 30 June 1992

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive a cash payment of up to $2,500 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum for every additional employee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Did we see one dollar? Not a dollar. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct lie by Jeffrey 'Glib' Kennett. He drags

Speaker: NA
Text: us Victorians down all the time he is there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just in last Sunday's Age, this article headed

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Jobs lag in private sector' states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Private enterprise has failed to compensate for

Speaker: NA
Text: massive Public Service job losses in Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: figures released by the Australian Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics last week show.

Speaker: NA
Text: The figures show that almost 68,000 Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service jobs were lost during the first three years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Kennett Government. More than 8,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: those were not absorbed by the private sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett has sacked huge numbers of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has destroyed the state government in our

Speaker: NA
Text: state. What has happened to those people?

Speaker: NA
Text: They have all got their payouts; they have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the debt for Victoria; and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: all out spending it. But in a couple of years

Speaker: NA
Text: time what will happen will be that many of

Speaker: NA
Text: them will be asking for Commonwealth hand-

Speaker: NA
Text: outs. Why? Because of Jeff Kennett's mad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness in trying to cut down state government

Speaker: NA
Text: services. There has hardly been a job created

Speaker: NA
Text: down in Victoria by Jeffrey 'Glib' Kennett.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me give you an example of what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened on the peninsula. The Flinders Shire

Speaker: NA
Text: Council has sacked 180 people and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston council has sacked-as far as I can

Speaker: NA
Text: find out, because they are very secretive-

Speaker: NA
Text: around 50 people. If you add that together,

Speaker: NA
Text: that makes 200-odd people gone on the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies of Jeffrey 'Glib' Kennett. Why?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of some mad rationalism idea that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has got from Nazi Germany or somewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has destroyed jobs in our area.

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order: I think the reference that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member made should be withdrawn. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that is quite inappropriate. I certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: take offence to it.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Nehl)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be obliged if you would withdraw the

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to Nazis.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: I was just reporting

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been said in the Herald-Sun in an

Speaker: NA
Text: article headed 'City churches hit Nazi state'.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have said that. I am quite entitled to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this House.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: The article states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Democracy in Victoria is threatened by the

Speaker: NA
Text: tyrannical forces which shaped Nazi Germany,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to a major discussion paper by some of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne's church leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The churches included the Baptist Church, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wesley Uniting Church, St Francis, St

Speaker: NA
Text: Augustine's and the Salvation Army City

Speaker: NA
Text: Corps. Do you reckon they are all wrong just

Speaker: NA
Text: because I say it? It is not wrong. What Ken-

Speaker: NA
Text: nett has done is try to turn Victoria into Nazi

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany. He has deliberately run down

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy, as the member for Corio ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor) mentioned. Democratic council

Speaker: NA
Text: elections are not held any more. I have three

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party appointed commissioners in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cleeland-Commissars!

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: Commissars, all

Speaker: NA
Text: right. They are not past members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party; they are present members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party. One of them actually chaired a

Speaker: NA
Text: local Liberal election down there. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: they are deciding what is going to happen in

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston. They are sacking people down

Speaker: NA
Text: there; they are cutting services; and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting up service charges all the way around.

Speaker: NA
Text: They give us a measly $2.50 a week and say,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Good on you, Bob, we've cut your rates

Speaker: NA
Text: down 20 per cent.' What they are doing is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I shall be doing all the rest of my

Speaker: NA
Text: time that I am ever in parliament is making

Speaker: NA
Text: certain that I highlight what Kennett is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: to destroy the Victorian economy. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: destroying democracy there and he is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: it by stealth all the time. His mates are looked

Speaker: NA
Text: after. If you have got a job or if you own a

Speaker: NA
Text: casino, no problem; if you run a building

Speaker: NA
Text: contracting firm and you want to get a few

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs off the council, no problem. But if you

Speaker: NA
Text: are a worker for the council looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: parks and gardens, out you go; if you are a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker in the local child-care centre, out you

Speaker: NA
Text: go. They are the sorts of things that are

Speaker: NA
Text: happening down in Victoria. That is what this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion is all about. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ATKINSON
Text: Isaacs) (1.55 p.m.)-This

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a totally political and cynical exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise by the member for MCEwen ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cleeland) and his Labor government mates.

Speaker: NA
Text: They come in here and talk about privat-

Speaker: NA
Text: same isation and the bad things that happen. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: there anyone of those four over there who

Speaker: NA
Text: did not vote for the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: being privatised? Are there any hands coming

Speaker: NA
Text: up over there from those who did not vote for

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank to be privatised?

Speaker: NA
Text: Would you like me to move to the Qantas

Speaker: NA
Text: sale? Would anyone over there like to stand

Speaker: NA
Text: up and say that they did not support the sale

Speaker: NA
Text: of Qantas? Is there anyone over there who

Speaker: NA
Text: will stand up and say that they did not sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port the sell-off of the airports of this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try? Not one of you! You stand up in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House and say that the Kennett economic

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalist government is doing all the wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: things. You stand up and talk but you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think anyone on this side of the House will

Speaker: NA
Text: answer you. I can tell you that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of people on this side who will answer

Speaker: NA
Text: you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Talk about devastation! Talk about fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: increases! What about the fuel taxes that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has increased in this term? What

Speaker: NA
Text: about the increases in sales tax? We had $9.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in sales tax before the last election and

Speaker: NA
Text: now Australians are paying $14 billion. On

Speaker: NA
Text: average it means that a family consisting of

Speaker: NA
Text: a mother, a father and two children are paying

Speaker: NA
Text: $60 a week in sales tax. Those opposite have

Speaker: NA
Text: the gall to stand up in this place and talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the devastation being created by Jeffrey

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett!

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for MCEwen spoke about the

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in numbers in the Public Service in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. If we do not start to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers in the Public Service, and reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to the average Victorian, we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: problems with the taxes that have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: collected. That is the problem facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government in this country. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty returning to a balanced budget

Speaker: NA
Text: because those opposite are not prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the adjustments that are necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: get the results that this country needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: You talk about Victoria. Go back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cain-Kirner era. Who was selling off the

Speaker: NA
Text: trams and trains and leasing them back from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Japanese? It was not Jeffrey Kennett: it

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Cain-Kirner administration. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett came to government with a $42

Speaker: NA
Text: billion debt created by your Labor mates.

Speaker: NA
Text: How would you expect him to resolve the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem other than by inflicting some hard-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship on the people? Do you think the people

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria are not going to remember what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Cain-Kirner administrations did? Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course they are going to remember!

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the process we are going through

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment with employment. You talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the creation of jobs. Your industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: laws have a hell of a lot to answer for. Look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the wrongful dismissal law. Many people

Speaker: NA
Text: are employing workers on overtime because

Speaker: NA
Text: they say, 'I really don't want to put on any-

Speaker: NA
Text: body else because I may have a problem if I

Speaker: NA
Text: need to get rid of them in the future.' This

Speaker: NA
Text: problem has been caused by the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government's wrongful dismissal laws.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today's motion is absolutely hypocritical.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the people of Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that. This country has a foreign debt

Speaker: NA
Text: of $180 billion-plus. When this government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office the foreign debt was $23

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. We saw problems like this in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Cain-Kirner administrations. These

Speaker: NA
Text: things have to be rectified if we are to turn

Speaker: NA
Text: this country around. It is not simply a prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem for state governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have a philosophical belief in the old

Speaker: NA
Text: process of filling up the Public Service and

Speaker: NA
Text: letting a few pay for the system. It eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: gets to the stage where you cannot finance

Speaker: NA
Text: your business and you go out the back door.

Speaker: NA
Text: You find that someone from overseas is

Speaker: NA
Text: selling goods in opposition to you. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy that is destroying this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner the people of this country have the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to vote in a federal election, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner we will be able to get rid of those on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side of this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you think I am angry about this, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, I am. The nerve of these

Speaker: NA
Text: people, coming into this House with a motion

Speaker: NA
Text: criticising a government that is turning around

Speaker: NA
Text: a previously bankrupt state. It is outrageous.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we get to the next election I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia will recognise this and

Speaker: NA
Text: treat these people opposite with the same sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of contempt as I do. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: MCMillan) (2.00

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-We have just heard from two members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the opposition who I think, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: after listening to their speeches today, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be here after the next election. The seat of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo and the seat of Isaacs are two seats

Speaker: NA
Text: that certainly will fall to the Labor Party at

Speaker: NA
Text: the next election. They will fall to the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party not because of privatisation or because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate about corporatisation but be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the policies that the Kennett govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has delivered and what those policies

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing to small business people, employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ees, country towns and the general atmos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phere in Victoria today.

Speaker: NA
Text: My two parliamentary colleagues on the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite side of the chamber-the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo ( Mr Reid) and the member for Isaacs

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Atkinson)-know that. They know they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in trouble because of the Kennett policies,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are probably doing a little behind the

Speaker: NA
Text: scenes to help their causes. I was hoping that

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate today we would hear them

Speaker: NA
Text: stand up for their electorates and defend their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates against some of the policies of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett government, policies which, behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the scenes, they definitely do not agree with.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason they do not agree with these

Speaker: NA
Text: policies is that they are destroying Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kennett government has no social

Speaker: NA
Text: policy at all. It has no heart. It has a rational

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policy and that is as far as it goes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kennett government tells the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria that everything will be fine. Maggie

Speaker: NA
Text: Thatcher was in town a couple of days ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: and she was saying that Thatcherism was

Speaker: NA
Text: alive and well in Victoria. What would

Speaker: NA
Text: Jeffrey say about that? He would say, 'No,

Speaker: NA
Text: don't tag me to Thatcherism; that is not what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are on about' -as if it were not true.

Speaker: NA
Text: Go to any part of rural Victoria and see if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government is not the most city

Speaker: NA
Text: based government that has ever been elected

Speaker: NA
Text: to parliament in Australia. Not one National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party member in this parliament is prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to stand up and defend the Kennett govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. What about the so-called coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Liberal and National parties? The

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party is mute because, firstly, they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not have the numbers-which means they

Speaker: NA
Text: have no power-and, secondly, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely devastated by what the Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing to their constituency

Speaker: NA
Text: right across Victoria. They have put the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioners in there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chynoweth-Commissars.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: The commissars.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kennett government are making deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, but there is no democracy. Straight out,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will cut the rates-with no assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: whether that is necessary--cut the services,

Speaker: NA
Text: sell the park-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cleeland-Cut the jobs.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: They will cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, destroy the total economy in the area,

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in the poker machines and take more

Speaker: NA
Text: money out. The result from all of that is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no money in the community and the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy keeps on going down.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is not a small country town in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria today that is not bleeding. If we had

Speaker: NA
Text: people moving to the bigger cities and the

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger towns in the past, we have a mass

Speaker: NA
Text: exodus right now. People are flooding out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the smaller towns. Their first choice is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps the Sheppartons or the Bendigos, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no solution there.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the money is being spent in the city-

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, money is being spent on the

Speaker: NA
Text: casino. Millions and millions of dollars are

Speaker: NA
Text: being spent in Melbourne. The development

Speaker: NA
Text: of Melbourne is the only thing that the Ken-

Speaker: NA
Text: nett government has in the way of policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we go out to the country regions of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, we find that they are being abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely devastated by this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about the health area? What is hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pening in our public hospitals? Come 5

Speaker: NA
Text: o'clock, the public hospitals close down in

Speaker: NA
Text: Rosebud and the Latrobe Valley and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to have a consortium of private doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors who will agree to come on call, but even

Speaker: NA
Text: they are out on strike. They are refusing to

Speaker: NA
Text: work for this Kennett government because of

Speaker: NA
Text: what Jeff Kennett is actually doing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy area.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about mental health? We have people

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate at the moment who are living

Speaker: NA
Text: in flats and are dependent upon public ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vants coming and assisting them after 5

Speaker: NA
Text: o'clock on a Friday. But the Kennett govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is so ideologically pure when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to overtime and penalty rates that it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: provide enough money to have people assist

Speaker: NA
Text: our mentally disabled people. These mentalIy

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled people have to wait until Monday

Speaker: NA
Text: morning-not because there are no people

Speaker: NA
Text: available to work but because the ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the Kennett government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party is that you cannot pay penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. Their view is, 'We will do a CRA. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will break that union. We wiIl break that

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal so we can get them on to hourly

Speaker: NA
Text: rates.'

Speaker: NA
Text: But who is suffering? The people of Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria are suffering. Families in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: are suffering, because their loved ones have

Speaker: NA
Text: nobody there to look after them. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: some disgusting cases of neglect caused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian government, and that neglect is

Speaker: NA
Text: based upon that government's ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: view and nothing else. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Bruce) (2.05 p.m.)-Any

Speaker: NA
Text: devastation caused to small business and rural

Speaker: NA
Text: communities in Victoria was caused by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cain and Kirner governments and not by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett government, which by any standards

Speaker: NA
Text: has been outstanding, given the shocking

Speaker: NA
Text: mess it inherited. The Kennett-MCNamara-

Speaker: NA
Text: Stockdale government inherited the worst

Speaker: NA
Text: mess in Australia's federal history, worse than

Speaker: NA
Text: the mess left by the discredited Lawrence

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: worse than WA Inc. and worse than the mess

Speaker: NA
Text: left by the discredited Labor government in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shocking mismanagement by Cain and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kirner left Victoria in a black hole and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett government has been fixing the place

Speaker: NA
Text: up. Cain and Kirner were selling off assets,

Speaker: NA
Text: not to reduce debt but to pay recurrent ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penses, selling assets to invest in the most

Speaker: NA
Text: dubious of projects and selling assets to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: their mates in high positions. Cain and Kirner

Speaker: NA
Text: were running around telling Tricontinental

Speaker: NA
Text: and the State Bank to invest in any thing-

Speaker: NA
Text: give the money away, lend to anything and on

Speaker: NA
Text: anything. That is what Cain and Kirner were

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. They were like the Marx brothers on

Speaker: NA
Text: the train, smashing up the carriages and seats

Speaker: NA
Text: and furniture to feed the locomotive of Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria as it sped on to ruin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who was one of the leading faction figures

Speaker: NA
Text: and an adviser to the Cain and Kirner govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments?-none other than the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen ( Mr Cleeland). We now have Jeff

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett cleaning up the mess created by these

Speaker: NA
Text: governments and their adviser Peter Cleeland

Speaker: NA
Text: is smashing up the seats and furniture to feed

Speaker: NA
Text: the boiler. The electors of MCEwen should

Speaker: NA
Text: know about their current member. They

Speaker: NA
Text: should know that he was an adviser to Cain

Speaker: NA
Text: and Kirner and an adviser to the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent of them all-David White. David

Speaker: NA
Text: White is lucky he is not the subject of a royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission. Jeff Kennett and Alan Stockdale

Speaker: NA
Text: have exposed his incompetence. He cost the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian taxpayers $6 billion in his failed

Speaker: NA
Text: deals. The Gas and Fuel Corporation building

Speaker: NA
Text: was a disaster. So was the deal David White

Speaker: NA
Text: did with the State Electricity Commission of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria and so was the deal he did with

Speaker: NA
Text: Alcoa-and all the time advised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCEwen, Peter Cleeland.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a criminal offence for a director of a

Speaker: NA
Text: public company to make false and misleading

Speaker: NA
Text: statements and it is a criminal offence for a

Speaker: NA
Text: director to fail to exercise reasonable skill and

Speaker: NA
Text: care in the exercise of his duties. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: way that David White exercised reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: skill and care in the exercise of his duties. If

Speaker: NA
Text: he had been a director of a public company

Speaker: NA
Text: he would have been charged by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities Commission and he would now be

Speaker: NA
Text: in gaol. He would be in gaol for creating the

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that he left Victoria in. He was advised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the member for MCEwen and it is this

Speaker: NA
Text: mess that the Kennett government is now

Speaker: NA
Text: cleaning up.

Speaker: NA
Text: David White cost the Victorian taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: $6 billion. This motion should not be about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government. It should be about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Cain and Kirner governments. Cain and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kirner and David White cost the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers $40 billion. If White had been a

Speaker: NA
Text: public company director, he would now be in

Speaker: NA
Text: gaol. Let the member for MCEwen note this

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully. The people he advised-Cain,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kirner and David White-cost the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers $40 billion. That is $50,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: every family in his electorate. The voters in

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen need to know that their member and

Speaker: NA
Text: his state factional cronies cost every family in

Speaker: NA
Text: his electorate $50,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Kennett government doing? It

Speaker: NA
Text: is cleaning up the disaster left by the Cain

Speaker: NA
Text: and Kirner governments and by Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: White. These people bear the badge of gross

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetence around their necks like a chain

Speaker: NA
Text: of shame while the Kennett government

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves the thanks of all Victorians for the

Speaker: NA
Text: job it is doing.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Les

Speaker: NA
Text: Scott)-Order! The time for this debate has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired. The debate is adjourned and the

Speaker: NA
Text: resumption of the debate will be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: MCEwen)- Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: I do indeed.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bruce ( Mr Beale) made allegations that I

Speaker: NA
Text: had been employed as an adviser to the

Speaker: NA
Text: former member-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale---I didn't say you were em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed. I said you advised him.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: Or was an adviser. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have never been an adviser and I have never

Speaker: NA
Text: been employed by any state member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian parliament. It is an outrageous

Speaker: NA
Text: allegation which shows how incompetent your

Speaker: NA
Text: speech was.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: Cowper) (2.10 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges the vital role of roads as the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic transport infrastructure of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: national economy;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) realises the need for more road funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth in regional and rural areas;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls for the urgent re-introduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: spots road program; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) endorses the need for special priority funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of my constituents, a man called Kevin

Speaker: NA
Text: Moran, died on Friday, 12 May 1995. Kevin

Speaker: NA
Text: was a good man and a family man. I just

Speaker: NA
Text: want to quote briefly from a letter written by

Speaker: NA
Text: his widow two days later, on 14 May. It

Speaker: NA
Text: reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: After losing one son to this road, we were

Speaker: NA
Text: stunned. Then when Roberts bus was hit by a semi,

Speaker: NA
Text: we were shattered, but honestly ... I don't know

Speaker: NA
Text: what I am now-I can't feel, I can't think, I don't

Speaker: NA
Text: want to live, my family have lost their Dad. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: lost my best friend, my mate of 35 years, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: only person I have ever loved-all because no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: will make a decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have pleaded, I have begged, I have prayed, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have done everything possible to get this road

Speaker: NA
Text: underway ... but it has obviously been to no avail,

Speaker: NA
Text: and now I have to suffer a life of solitude, of

Speaker: NA
Text: grieving, of aching loneliness ... Something has

Speaker: NA
Text: got to be done . . . before someone else is killed-

Speaker: NA
Text: surely two, and almost three, from one family is

Speaker: NA
Text: enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: I grieve for Mrs Moran and her family. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is what we are talking about when we talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Pacific Highway. We are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about death, mayhem, slaughter, grief and an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous cost to the society of Australia; not

Speaker: NA
Text: just in pain and suffering, but in money. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cost-benefit ratio of building a new Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway makes it far cheaper to build a new

Speaker: NA
Text: highway than to pay for the deaths and the

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering. I am reminded that very soon-22

Speaker: NA
Text: December-we have the anniversary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Clybucca bus smash in my electorate where

Speaker: NA
Text: 35 people died. It was Australia's worst

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster. I see the member for Page ( Mr Harry

Speaker: NA
Text: Woods) sitting in the chamber. A couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: months before that smash, in his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: near the little village of Cowper, 20 people

Speaker: NA
Text: died on a bus. In actual fact, the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have died on the Pacific Highway

Speaker: NA
Text: ROADS between 1985 and 1994 is 766. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: 10,000 casualties-10,000 smashed, maimed

Speaker: NA
Text: and battered bodies. It is not good enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we approach Christmas 1995, let's pray

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are no more bus smashes-but,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, there will be deaths. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: interested to see the 60 Minutes segment last

Speaker: NA
Text: night on which Richard Carleton spoke with

Speaker: NA
Text: black Kevin Waller, the former Chief Coroner of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales, who conducted coronial

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries into both bus smashes. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the federal minister for roads,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Transport ( Mr Brereton). He

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, Mr Brereton, I would just ask you to serious-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly get down to work to start planning this dual

Speaker: NA
Text: construction and to give the motorists something

Speaker: NA
Text: that they've deserved, I think, for the past 20 or 25

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another point made in that program was that

Speaker: NA
Text: a painted line is not good enough for separat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing traffic. It is absolutely true. We have to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a four-lane dual carriageway, a divided

Speaker: NA
Text: highway all the way from Hexham to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland border. All the evidence from

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia and from right around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world shows, without any doubt, that once

Speaker: NA
Text: you put in a divided highway the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: accidents diminishes and the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: fatalities goes down by as much as 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. These are not just idle figures. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: the statistics of the RTA and the various other

Speaker: NA
Text: state bodies around Australia and throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the world. Put in a divided highway and cut

Speaker: NA
Text: out the deaths. That is what we have to do on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: The highway serves a population of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 500,000. But that is just the local population.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is that, with a traffic level of

Speaker: NA
Text: 37,000 vehicles a day, an enormous number

Speaker: NA
Text: of people from Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: and Geelong also use the highway. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: making a plea for the local people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: north coast but for all of Australia. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the major traffic arteries of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It connects the two largest cities in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It serves the fastest growing area of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the transportation backbone of the east

Speaker: NA
Text: coast of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is huge potential along the length of

Speaker: NA
Text: that highway for major industries such as

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism. Getting the right road will assist

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody. If these industries are to succeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be economically beneficial for the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of Australia, not just the people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: north coast. We should not forget that the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 Olympics are just around the comer.

Speaker: NA
Text: With people travelling from Sydney to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast, the amount of traffic on the

Speaker: NA
Text: highway will increase dramatically.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the present Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-I am going to be political; I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Page and his colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: will attack me-has abandoned the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. There is no doubt about that. For a

Speaker: NA
Text: while, they did the right thing. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: a very brief history of what has happened

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Pacific Highway and the campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: for a new one. Before I was first elected in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984, I started the campaign for a new Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. People said that I was stupid and an

Speaker: NA
Text: idiot. They said that I would never get a

Speaker: NA
Text: lane highway there and that it was pie in the

Speaker: NA
Text: sky. How wrong they were, because we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to get it. We have had a little. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reality is that we must get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: After those unfortunate bus smashes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia got right behind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway. In 1990, I was able to

Speaker: NA
Text: present something like 50,000 signatures on

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions to this parliament from people right

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia. They said, 'Please give the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway some priority.' I was able to

Speaker: NA
Text: convince first the National Party of the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for priority funding and then our Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: friends. When we went into the 1990 election,

Speaker: NA
Text: we had a firm coalition policy, in conjunction

Speaker: NA
Text: with the then coalition government of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, to provide additional funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: We did, and it did happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had a program that said that the high-

Speaker: NA
Text: way would get an additional $300 million. An

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of $130 million was to come from the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government and $170 million was to

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the state government. Thank

Speaker: NA
Text: goodness the Labor government took up the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge. They matched our offer. The reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that $300 million was spent between 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1993. The few kilometres of divided

Speaker: NA
Text: highway that we now have are a result of that

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $300 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: I praise the member for Charlton ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Brown), who was the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, and a darned good one. He put the

Speaker: NA
Text: money into the Pacific Highway. Unfortunate-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly, he left the ministry, and that was it. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: finished. The black spots program went right

Speaker: NA
Text: out the door. That was the most efficient use

Speaker: NA
Text: of funding that this country has ever seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: People want it back. Labor abolished the

Speaker: NA
Text: black spots program. I am very pleased to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that, while the details of everything have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been announced and will not be until the

Speaker: NA
Text: election, the coalition has promised to reintro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the black spots program. It is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: promise. After 1993, no more funding went

Speaker: NA
Text: give you directly to the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: All sorts of organisations on the north coast

Speaker: NA
Text: have created a task force. There is a meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: of it in the next few weeks. We met in Bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lina about a year ago. We were all very happy

Speaker: NA
Text: and bipartisan, but nothing happened. I say to

Speaker: NA
Text: four- the member for Page-he will have a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: in a minute to refute this-that he says things

Speaker: NA
Text: in the electorate but, when he comes down

Speaker: NA
Text: here, as in the forestry industry debate, he

Speaker: NA
Text: votes on the party line. I challenge the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Page to say that he will pressure his

Speaker: NA
Text: government, going into the next election, to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide priority funding for the Pacific High-

Speaker: NA
Text: way and to reinstate the black spots program.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not want any more deaths. There have

Speaker: NA
Text: been far too many. I for one have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: gutful of people dying on that highway.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Les

Speaker: NA
Text: Scott)-Is the motion seconded?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Vaile-Yes, I second the motion and

Speaker: NA
Text: reserve my right to speak later.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can only be with the member for Cowper

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Nehl) on this subject of the deaths on the

Speaker: NA
Text: roads, particularly those on the Pacific High-

Speaker: NA
Text: way as he mentioned. Back in 1989 and 1990

Speaker: NA
Text: we had some particularly bad bus crashes

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting in the deaths of many people. I too

Speaker: NA
Text: have known people who have been killed on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: My great fear is that, as we approach the

Speaker: NA
Text: year 2000, unless there is some serious and

Speaker: NA
Text: rapid upgrading of that road, along with the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater volumes of traffic on that highway,

Speaker: NA
Text: including more buses particularly in that

Speaker: NA
Text: period before the Olympics, we will see more

Speaker: NA
Text: of those dreadful bus crashes that occurred a

Speaker: NA
Text: few years ago. I think the answer to this

Speaker: NA
Text: problem is that the Pacific Highway does

Speaker: NA
Text: need to become part of the national highway

Speaker: NA
Text: system. It does need additional funding to

Speaker: NA
Text: accelerate the work being done on it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be serious about this, and we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to raise people's hopes falsely. I notice

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph (4) of the motion moved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Cowper says 'endorses the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for special priority funding for the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway'. I support that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will refer to a couple of instances that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred recently in my electorate which have

Speaker: NA
Text: led me to doubt the sincerity of the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter. The shadow minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: transport was in my electorate recently and he

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that the coalition would have a

Speaker: NA
Text: new category of roads called roads of national

Speaker: NA
Text: importance. He said the Summerland Way

Speaker: NA
Text: was one of those roads of national importance

Speaker: NA
Text: and that he would provide, if elected, $38

Speaker: NA
Text: million towards upgrading it.

Speaker: NA
Text: But when questioned by the Lismore Echo

Speaker: NA
Text: he said the funding would be sought on a

Speaker: NA
Text: fifty-fifty basis with the state government to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve the figure of $38 million to be spent

Speaker: NA
Text: over a period of five to six years. The new

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales government has already

Speaker: NA
Text: promised $50 million over that period and

Speaker: NA
Text: this year is spending over $6 million on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Summerland Way, far in excess of what was

Speaker: NA
Text: spent under a coalition government. Even on

Speaker: NA
Text: that basis it is a funny sort of promise, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when you look at some of the policy docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have come into our hands you can

Speaker: NA
Text: understand why.

Speaker: NA
Text: The policy document headed 'Structural

Speaker: NA
Text: reform management group: regional and rural

Speaker: NA
Text: development' has the name Bruce Scott,

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister for regional and rural devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment, at the bottom. When talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure on this policy document he

Speaker: NA
Text: says:

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to set a figure ($1 billion, $3 billion-the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual number is insignificant) as an indication of

Speaker: NA
Text: our commitment to putting roads, dams, port,

Speaker: NA
Text: airports, bridges, whatever, into regional Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should also then allude to some sort of assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment procedure by which regions can directly seek

Speaker: NA
Text: funding ...

Speaker: NA
Text: In a further document, a briefing paper to

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow cabinet, when talking about infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure the shadow minister for regional

Speaker: NA
Text: development and infrastructure stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem with proposals in infrastructure is how

Speaker: NA
Text: to give us the flexibility to campaign properly

Speaker: NA
Text: without being so specific as to lock us into particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar projects which then of necessity must rule out

Speaker: NA
Text: others.

Speaker: NA
Text: He further said:

Speaker: NA
Text: This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: major long term visionary matters but without

Speaker: NA
Text: committing ourselves to actually proceeding with

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the members opposite, when talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Pacific Highway and country roads,

Speaker: NA
Text: not to raise those hopes and tell people we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to do something when we have these

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of documents which are hypocritical in

Speaker: NA
Text: the extreme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Cowper was, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: right in saying that the federal government no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer puts money directly into the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. We had the provincial cities and

Speaker: NA
Text: rural highways program from 1990 to 1993,

Speaker: NA
Text: which put $300 million into the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. That was discontinued as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1991 Premiers Conference, in which it

Speaker: NA
Text: was resolved to more clearly define the roles

Speaker: NA
Text: and responsibilities of each level of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for funding of both maintenance and

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements. That agreement was signed-

Speaker: NA
Text: in other words, agreed to-by the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales government. That government at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time was a coalition government. The agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment reinforced the historical links between

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales government and its

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: The state government agreed, as part of that

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement, to fully fund improvement works

Speaker: NA
Text: for the highway as it had always done. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: five years leading up to this year, the average

Speaker: NA
Text: spent by the state government----:that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government-on the Pacific High-

Speaker: NA
Text: way was $74 million a year. This year, under

Speaker: NA
Text: a New South Wales Labor government, the

Speaker: NA
Text: figure was in excess of $100 million. It is still

Speaker: NA
Text: not enough. Still we need more improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand the quandary of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cowper. In paragraph (4) of the motion he

Speaker: NA
Text: moves that the House 'endorses the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: special priority funding for the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway'. The question is how we get it. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is, by the agreement I have mentioned, a state

Speaker: NA
Text: government responsibility. There is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: about that. The money that the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government was putting in as part of that

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement was paid to the states in an untied

Speaker: NA
Text: way. In excess of $100 million per annum

Speaker: NA
Text: was provided to cover both the black spots

Speaker: NA
Text: program and the provincial cities and rural

Speaker: NA
Text: highways program. As part of that, we took

Speaker: NA
Text: into the national highway system the Newell

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sturt highways.

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of the agreement, the Pacific High-

Speaker: NA
Text: way stays part of the state responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: unlikely, under present circumstances, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government will step in. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: hullabaloo from the opposition about roads of

Speaker: NA
Text: national importance. I do not know if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway will also be made part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: roads of national importance program, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is worth noting-and it shows real hypocri-

Speaker: NA
Text: sy-that, when the member for Hume ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sharp) was asked about where these roads of

Speaker: NA
Text: national importance would be, he said, 'Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, they would focus on marginal elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates.' That is a rather cynical view when you

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about deaths and trauma on roads.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no free rides as far as funding

Speaker: NA
Text: goes. The answer is for negotiations to go on

Speaker: NA
Text: between the New South Wales government,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland government and the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government, with the aim of making the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway part of the national highway

Speaker: NA
Text: system, with a long-term plan-though as

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term as possible-to improve it to a

Speaker: NA
Text: state where it can take the sort of traffic that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is receiving at the moment and will do in

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing loads in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: In essence, I support the motion, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: would ask the member for Cowper and other

Speaker: NA
Text: members, when they are talking about these

Speaker: NA
Text: issues, to try to be factual about them and to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the issues involved. As I say, I can

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the member for Cowper's quan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dary because it is difficult for him to propose

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway as part of the national

Speaker: NA
Text: highway system-though he did in the past-

Speaker: NA
Text: because he recognises that on his side of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament it is more than likely politically

Speaker: NA
Text: unachievable because it would mean the

Speaker: NA
Text: dropping of the New England Highway as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the national highway system. That

Speaker: NA
Text: would be opposed very strongly by his Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party colleagues from over the moun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us try to work towards the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway as part of the national highway

Speaker: NA
Text: system. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (2.30 p.m.)-For

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time since there has been a concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trated state-wide concern with the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway we have two governments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: same political persuasion responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of roads in New South Wales. They

Speaker: NA
Text: It is are the Carr Labor government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: These two governments of the same politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal persuasion have made noises over the year

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what should be the results for the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. First, Mr Carr promised $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year-just a marginal increase on

Speaker: NA
Text: what was already being provided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government. There is no real com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment from the Carr government to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: out a massive task for the Pacific Highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating)

Speaker: NA
Text: say? He says, 'Talk to the states. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: paying for two roads.' But the killing goes

Speaker: NA
Text: on.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are getting some bright ideas about

Speaker: NA
Text: what should happen. The member for Rich-

Speaker: NA
Text: mond ( Mr Newell) says, 'Shove up some

Speaker: NA
Text: more signs on the Burringbar Road.' I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the reports of it here. The members for Page

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Harry Woods) and Paterson ( Mr Home)

Speaker: NA
Text: are not reading their local newspapers. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are accidents occurring, people being killed

Speaker: NA
Text: and your people are saying, 'Put up more

Speaker: NA
Text: signs.' The mayors of that area are calling for

Speaker: NA
Text: major roadworks because they have to live

Speaker: NA
Text: with the accidents that occur in the rain.

Speaker: NA
Text: People are killed there.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a killer road. The area from Hexham

Speaker: NA
Text: right through to the border does need redoing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of coming up with ideas about road

Speaker: NA
Text: signs and instead of making placatory remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about how difficult it is, the ALP should

Speaker: NA
Text: make some decisions. The Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party are in office. They can make decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forget about picking up bits of paper you find

Speaker: NA
Text: floating around and about criticising the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. You guys can actually make

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions. You are in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labor Party are in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. They can spend the taxpayer's money.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can make a decision. Their cabinets are

Speaker: NA
Text: in government with the powers to act. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: no. They prefer to fight this argument on bits

Speaker: NA
Text: of paper they find floating around and by

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, 'The coalition will not do anything.'

Speaker: NA
Text: What a bunch of wimps they are. How un-

Speaker: NA
Text: committed are they to the people and the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of the north coast? You know what that

Speaker: NA
Text: road is like.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been talking about the advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: having both federal and state governments

Speaker: NA
Text: involved. What about the Billinudgel decision

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by Bob Carr to wipe out a section of

Speaker: NA
Text: freeway? He just said, 'I am not going to do

Speaker: NA
Text: it. We are going to have an inquiry or some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing or other. Forget about it.' I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: how much expenditure that decision of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government has postponed. If you make

Speaker: NA
Text: the promises, you have to deliver. You are in

Speaker: NA
Text: government in Canberra; you are in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Macquarie Street. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party ought to do something to fix this

Speaker: NA
Text: road up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are you going to make announcements for

Speaker: NA
Text: the next federal election? If you do, not too

Speaker: NA
Text: many people are going to believe that process

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have seen both Paul Keating and

Speaker: NA
Text: Bob Carr make commitments to the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. One delivered his promise. One has

Speaker: NA
Text: partially delivered. It is not going anywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the way in which you are

Speaker: NA
Text: handling this. One has to say that if you bring

Speaker: NA
Text: the speed limit down to zero on Tintenbar

Speaker: NA
Text: Hill you are going to get zero accidents. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the way it is heading. This is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: result you are achieving as a Labor Party for

Speaker: NA
Text: a major thoroughfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fastest growing area in Australia is up

Speaker: NA
Text: along the north coast of New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are opportunities for you to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: major contribution to national growth. You

Speaker: NA
Text: want to pause and analyse what the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: might have said three, five or two years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: Take some action instead, because this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: killer road.

Speaker: NA
Text: Likeable though the members for Page and

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond may be, they are never going to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve anything on the north coast. Nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to be achieved up there until there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a change of members and a change of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, federally and in the state of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. I appeal to the voters in those areas to

Speaker: NA
Text: take action and make sure these guys are

Speaker: NA
Text: rolled out of their seats so that Liberal or

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party members can be elected and so

Speaker: NA
Text: that there can be a proper program com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced and a real commitment to some

Speaker: NA
Text: action to rectify the problems of the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway.

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Text: Paterson) (2.35 p.m.)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to address this motion today having had a

Speaker: NA
Text: look through the Hansard record, so I know

Speaker: NA
Text: it seems to be somewhat of an annual visit

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable member for Cowper ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Nehl) makes to this issue. I can tell you what

Speaker: NA
Text: will not appear in the Taree Times or the

Speaker: NA
Text: know Coffs Harbour Clarion, and that is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Carr government has increased funding on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway by 36 per cent. That will

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely not appear in any of your papers

Speaker: NA
Text: because you would not dare tell people.

Speaker: NA
Text: You come here and criticise the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government for not funding a state road that

Speaker: NA
Text: was declared in 1974. The agreement between

Speaker: NA
Text: the then Askin government and the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government under Gough Whitlam was that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway would be a state road.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Carr government came in, we

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately saw an increase in funding. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the commitment of the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party to the Pacific Highway. I think you

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen would be wise not to forget it.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you want to talk about facts, maybe you

Speaker: NA
Text: should go back to the fact that grants became

Speaker: NA
Text: untied last year. This is the first time in

Speaker: NA
Text: history that grants have not been tied to a

Speaker: NA
Text: specific purpose. What did we see the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Fahey government do with the first $50

Speaker: NA
Text: million given to that state for road funding?

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw them spend it on City Rail. As much

Speaker: NA
Text: as there is a demand by the people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: north coast for increased funding on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific Highway, the Fahey government took

Speaker: NA
Text: the first $50 million in untied road funding

Speaker: NA
Text: and spent it on City Rail. That is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that your side of politics has to

Speaker: NA
Text: this important highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can tell members that the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
