Text: ment has continued to fund the Pacific High-

Speaker: NA
Text: way. It has made major commitments, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cowper alluded to

Speaker: NA
Text: and acknowledged this. In my own electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: the planning, the acquisition, the roundabouts

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Raymond Terrace bypass and the

Speaker: NA
Text: black spots funding between Raymond Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: race and Nabiac in the electorate of Paterson

Speaker: NA
Text: have been funded by the federal government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite keep talking about policies

Speaker: NA
Text: and about changes that will come in if, by

Speaker: NA
Text: some freak of nature, they happen to be on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House after the next election.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let us just consider what one of your

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders told the annual conference of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Farmers Federation. Every time we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear from that side of the House there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: different policy being put forward, but I will

Speaker: NA
Text: remind members that, at the annual confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of the National Farmers Federation, Tim

Speaker: NA
Text: Fischer said that your side of politics would

Speaker: NA
Text: not increase funding for rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: roads in Australia because they did not want

Speaker: NA
Text: to run the risk of increasing interest rates by

Speaker: NA
Text: competing for capital.

Speaker: NA
Text: What policy will we accept from the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party of Australia? I prefer to take

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the leader when he is addressing an

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation as influential as the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers Federation. But I guess we will not

Speaker: NA
Text: know until an election is called when prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably some more sexy, if I can use that adjec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive, policies come out that might appeal to

Speaker: NA
Text: voters. But I can tell you that those policies

Speaker: NA
Text: will definitely not contain the facts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. They will not reveal the real level of

Speaker: NA
Text: funding by state and federal Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on the Pacific Highway; they will

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to conceal that, because that side of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House knows that it is Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, both state and federal, that have had

Speaker: NA
Text: the commitment all along to funding a road

Speaker: NA
Text: which, federally, we do not have the responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parallel to the Pacific Highway, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: runs our national rail line. We have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: significant funding there by the federal Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We have seen an attempt to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport industry to use rail rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: road, to get the heavy transport off the road-

Speaker: NA
Text: way. I am sure that those members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the major problem on this road is

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by the fact that so many transporters

Speaker: NA
Text: use it. It seems logical with the streamlining,

Speaker: NA
Text: the upgrading, of rail infrastructure that that

Speaker: NA
Text: should happen. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Text: Lyne) (2.40 p.m.)-It was

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to listen to the member for Pater-

Speaker: NA
Text: son ( Mr Home) participate in this debate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was pleased to see him do so, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at what he had to say the last time we

Speaker: NA
Text: visited this issue back in 1993. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: What the honourable member for Cowper ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Nehl) attempted to do with the private member's

Speaker: NA
Text: motion this morning was to move the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for that road from the coalition government of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales to the federal government.

Speaker: NA
Text: So he is saying it is a state government

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. And he has just been talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the increase the Carr government has

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated to the spending OIl the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. He might tell the House why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Carr government has completely canned the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition of the Bulahdelah Mountain

Speaker: NA
Text: bypass, which was locked in place under the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous coalition government. The acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were done and the design was done, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the the Carr government is not going to do it-

Speaker: NA
Text: $120 million worth. It is the most important

Speaker: NA
Text: black spot on the Pacific Highway today.

Speaker: NA
Text: It always intrigues me when we get into

Speaker: NA
Text: debates like this that we get back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: semantics of what you can and cannot do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bureaucracy in Australia is running

Speaker: NA
Text: rampant. In my years in public life in local

Speaker: NA
Text: government and in this place, I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely appalled at the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucracy being focused on finding reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: why we cannot do something.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem at hand is that we have a 700-

Speaker: NA
Text: odd kilometre road that in the last 10 years

Speaker: NA
Text: has not seen 600 people killed, as Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Carleton reported on 60 Minutes last night; it

Speaker: NA
Text: has seen 766 people killed and 10,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: injured. It is an absolute disgrace. Yet we

Speaker: NA
Text: keep on saying, 'It's a state responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: not our responsibility. They took it on in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1974, let the states fix it.'

Speaker: NA
Text: What happened to the national perspective?

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a road of national economic import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance running between Sydney and Brisbane.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regardless of what you say, the region is

Speaker: NA
Text: growing at an enormous rate. Over 500,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people live in the region. It is a road of major

Speaker: NA
Text: economic importance as a transport link,

Speaker: NA
Text: notwithstanding the rail between Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane. We have to find a way of doing

Speaker: NA
Text: something about it and not just saying, 'It's

Speaker: NA
Text: their responsibility. We haven't got the

Speaker: NA
Text: money.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal government collects $10 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: from road users in Australia-$10 billion! In

Speaker: NA
Text: this year's budget they have spent $850

Speaker: NA
Text: million. So over the life of the Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Australia we have seen those two

Speaker: NA
Text: figures part-the amount collected heading up

Speaker: NA
Text: on an increasing tangent and the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: being spent going down. So just remember

Speaker: NA
Text: those figures, Mr Speaker: $10 billion col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lected and $850 million spent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fuel tax revenue has increased from around

Speaker: NA
Text: 8c a litre in 1983 to 33c a litre today. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not seeing it spent back on the roads. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are not even seeing a reasonable percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: of it being spent back on the roads.

Speaker: NA
Text: The motion moved by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper ( Mr Nehl) today has a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: parts. The speakers today, coming from the

Speaker: NA
Text: areas they represent, are putting the most

Speaker: NA
Text: importance on the Pacific Highway because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is one of the most important pieces of

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure in Australia that has been totally

Speaker: NA
Text: neglected. We have not seen the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway, the Hume Highway or the highways

Speaker: NA
Text: down in this end of the country referred to.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you come south of Sydney, you are on

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent roads all the way to the country's

Speaker: NA
Text: capital and all points south. When you go

Speaker: NA
Text: north it is a different story.

Speaker: NA
Text: The motion is about getting a realistic

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of revenue collected by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth allocated by whatever means. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: not matter how it goes-whether it is back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the states as untied grants or SPPs going

Speaker: NA
Text: straight to local government. We just want to

Speaker: NA
Text: It's see a reasonable amount of the money that is

Speaker: NA
Text: collected by the Commonwealth aimed back

Speaker: NA
Text: at where it should be going-into road infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure whether it be on highways, country

Speaker: NA
Text: roads, country bridges or bridges in the city.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see plenty of money spent around the

Speaker: NA
Text: city, but the point is that it is not being

Speaker: NA
Text: redirected. I would like to know where a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of that $10 billion is going-and so too

Speaker: NA
Text: would a lot of the people that pay petrol tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is important that we focus on that

Speaker: NA
Text: issue because of the size of Australia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: tyranny of distance. We are a very unique

Speaker: NA
Text: country: an enormous country with a small

Speaker: NA
Text: population. As I said, we are paying $10

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in fuel taxes. The government has

Speaker: NA
Text: spent $850 million back on the roads. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: not seeing enough money being spent. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have to find a way instead of coming in here

Speaker: NA
Text: and saying, 'We can't do it because of this

Speaker: NA
Text: and this or because of some 1974 agreement.'

Speaker: NA
Text: It is 20 years later!

Speaker: NA
Text: What if we stuck to the values and the

Speaker: NA
Text: traditions that were in place in 1974 on all the

Speaker: NA
Text: social issues in this country. There would be

Speaker: NA
Text: some bleeding going on from over there! The

Speaker: NA
Text: thing is we have to get up into 1995. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have 1995 vehicles running on these roads. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the last IO years, 766 people have been killed.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 2.45 p.m.,

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate is interrupted in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the resumption of the debate will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: an order of the day for the next sitting Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: day. The member will have leave to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking for about one second when the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is resumed.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Election Campaign

Speaker: Ms WORTH
Text: Adelaide)-Last week, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Trades and Labour Council document

Speaker: NA
Text: titled 1996 Federal election planning was

Speaker: NA
Text: leaked. Amongst the seven pages of detail,

Speaker: NA
Text: the unions set out their plans to distort and

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupt the next federal election. The strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: spelt out was to develop a 'third' party cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign of 'fear and loathing' in the run-up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the next federal election. Decent men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women should be horrified by this, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that individual unionists are outraged

Speaker: NA
Text: that their organisation should act in this

Speaker: NA
Text: The document says nothing about truly

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before entering parliament, I worked con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structively with an industrial officer at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nurses Federation to ensure that jobs were not

Speaker: NA
Text: lost and that suitably trained staff would be

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in a particular area. As a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliament, I have worked with unionists

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that their safety concerns would be

Speaker: NA
Text: heard by Australian national management

Speaker: NA
Text: This is how it should be, but now a document

Speaker: NA
Text: is published which spells out details of how

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals will be used by union leaders as

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial fodder, including being used in

Speaker: NA
Text: 'demonstrations and rallies'. My union leader

Speaker: NA
Text: opponent in Adelaide has already embarked

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the 'fear and loathing' campaign, using

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses in industrial action for her own politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal purposes instead of encouraging them to

Speaker: NA
Text: have real influence in public policy, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken seriously and so constructively effect

Speaker: NA
Text: change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Greece: Pension Arrangements

Speaker: Mrs EASSON
Text: Lowe)--In early November

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, representatives from the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Social Security met informally in Stras-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourg with representatives from the Greek

Speaker: NA
Text: government to discuss an agreement between

Speaker: NA
Text: our two countries concerning pension arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Baldwin) and the department are doing a

Speaker: NA
Text: good job in this difficult field but, standing

Speaker: NA
Text: back from the details, I can see that no

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement can actually be reached in the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner that Australia would like.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have over a century of very accurate

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic records, but Greece has

Speaker: NA
Text: not. Many of the Greek migrants came to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia from rural and island communities

Speaker: NA
Text: where bureaucracy was minimal, if existent at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. Australia should realise

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum accuracy and perfection in a future

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is not feasible. The matter will

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be settled at a political level.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are dealing with a generation of Greeks

Speaker: NA
Text: who stood by our men and women in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: war and during the last catastrophic Greek

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign, and I speak often of this matter in

Speaker: NA
Text: way. this House. We must as a nation be loyal to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who at that time were loyal to us. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: are not, we will not have much loyalty shown

Speaker: NA
Text: to us in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: My suggestion is that a broad political

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement, a generous settlement, be made.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are rich and prosperous, thanks largely to

Speaker: NA
Text: postwar migration, and we can afford to be

Speaker: NA
Text: generous and appreciative. This matter is not

Speaker: NA
Text: one of bureaucracy but is a matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the unbroken bounds between Greece

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia. Let us show our qualities by

Speaker: NA
Text: not haggling, and let us show our thanks to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who did the hard postwar work in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Australia has a great future. Let us

Speaker: NA
Text: add loyalty and generosity to our list of

Speaker: NA
Text: national characteristics and resolve the Greek

Speaker: NA
Text: pension issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party Policies

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Text: Curtin)-In the run-up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the election, and this probably being the last

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting of this parliament, I want to go over

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the policy issues which seem to be

Speaker: NA
Text: so important to those opposite. Let me remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the House about policy undertakings given by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government before the 1993 election.

Speaker: NA
Text: People will remember the one about how it

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to give us a government that we

Speaker: NA
Text: can trust. Trust does not figure among the

Speaker: NA
Text: attributes of this government, from any

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about big reductions in hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting lists? They continue to grow and

Speaker: NA
Text: grow. What about the building of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Museum of Australia? Not a sod has been

Speaker: NA
Text: turned. What about the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: single air market between Australia and New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand? Some New Zealanders even believed

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. What about increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign aid? That is made up of an increased

Speaker: NA
Text: number of trips by the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), and that is it.

Speaker: NA
Text: that a pursuit of It has come down.

Speaker: NA
Text: What about the creation of the emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: dental fund for low income earners? That is

Speaker: NA
Text: another one they could not bite on. What

Speaker: NA
Text: about the use of super for home buyers?

Speaker: NA
Text: Another super deception. Then we had real

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations reform, which proved

Speaker: NA
Text: again that reform is the most misused word in

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's lexicon. They said, 'No taxes for age

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners,' but the age pensioners of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country are still waiting.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know about the I-a-w law tax cuts. But

Speaker: NA
Text: I-a-w spells 'lie' in Labor's language. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know about the promise that there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: no new taxes, but that was blatantly broken.

Speaker: NA
Text: You could have fooled me. They promised no

Speaker: NA
Text: more budget deficits. No more than one a

Speaker: NA
Text: year, they meant. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett Government

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Text: Corio)-When Jeff

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett came to power in Victoria, he gave

Speaker: NA
Text: this undertaking to Victorian and Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: workers that none of them would be worse off

Speaker: NA
Text: under a Kennett Liberal state government. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: on coming to power, the workers of that state

Speaker: NA
Text: faced an awful betrayal in that their wages

Speaker: NA
Text: and conditions were attacked via the 'take the

Speaker: NA
Text: contract or take the sack' policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know in this House that Jeff Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: has one big supporter, and that is John How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard. He supports the policies of the Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: government and of the Court government in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia. We know recently that Jeff

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett has indicated to both the Geelong and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian work force that, with the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of a Howard government, workers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria will have nowhere else to go. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know what that means.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was only one government that

Speaker: NA
Text: stepped into the ring to protect the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: work force from the industrial excesses

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett government, and that was Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating and a Labor government. It was Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating and a Labor government that stood

Speaker: NA
Text: over Jeff Kennett, put him back in his place

Speaker: NA
Text: and said, 'We will offer workers in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of Victoria the sanctity and protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: federal industrial award system.' In my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, a librarian had her wages cut by

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 under the policies of the Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal government. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Testing

Speaker: Mr COBB
Text: Parkes)-I wish to register a

Speaker: NA
Text: protest against the continuing testing of

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear weapons by China. Much has been

Speaker: NA
Text: said, and rightly so, against the French nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear testing in the Pacific. But most mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers, especially government members, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been largely mute on communist China.

Speaker: NA
Text: Testing there is done at Lop Nor in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Xinjiang province, which contains 14Yz

Speaker: NA
Text: million people in the Chinese occupied East

Speaker: NA
Text: Turkestan region. It is the largest nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: testing site in the world. Forty-three tests have

Speaker: NA
Text: been conducted there since 1964, with 23 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the atmosphere up until 1980. Until August

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, four had been conducted in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 months. They have reputedly three to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: The site is a similar distance from or even

Speaker: NA
Text: closer to Australia than the site at Mururoa

Speaker: NA
Text: Atoll. It is very near Mongolia, Tibet, India,

Speaker: NA
Text: Pakistan and other countries. Testing there

Speaker: NA
Text: will only stir up Pakistan and North Korea to

Speaker: NA
Text: step up their weapons testing programs. China

Speaker: NA
Text: has dragged its feet on being a good world

Speaker: NA
Text: citizen. It was the last of the nuclear capable

Speaker: NA
Text: nations to sign the nuclear non-proliferation

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty of 1970, which it signed only in 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: The world should put pressure on China to

Speaker: NA
Text: cease its present testing program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fuel Prices

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: MCEwen)-The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lyne ( Mr Vaile) just made a speech about

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel excises but he forgot to tell the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that all fuel excise is spent on hospitals and

Speaker: NA
Text: education, among a host of other things. So

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not forgotten; it is spent. The other thing

Speaker: NA
Text: the member forgot is that this parliament, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth, has no constitutional power

Speaker: NA
Text: over prices. That was defeated in a referen-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the dum way back in 1974.

Speaker: NA
Text: The states, however, do have power over

Speaker: NA
Text: prices. The Victorian government has power

Speaker: NA
Text: over prices. His colleagues in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party run around Victoria nonstop complain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about fuel prices. They seem to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the forgotten that they have the constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: power in state government to control those

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel prices. They ran around before the last

Speaker: NA
Text: election saying they would introduce new

Speaker: NA
Text: terminal systems into rural Victoria to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: price. They won government but somehow

Speaker: NA
Text: they have forgotten that they now have the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to change the pricing structure of fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural Victoria. So when I hear the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party members complain about fuel prices, I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to them, 'Go and talk to your state col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues in Victoria who are in government

Speaker: NA
Text: and tell them that they can do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about it.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Landcare and Environment Action Plan

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: Wannon)-I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: tell you just how miserable the current

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating government really is. Not only is it

Speaker: NA
Text: artificially trying to suppress the true state of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment but also those people on

Speaker: NA
Text: government benefits are now finding that their

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits are being reduced when they are put

Speaker: NA
Text: through this process. I draw your attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: a case in my electorate where someone has

Speaker: NA
Text: been put on a landcare and environment

Speaker: NA
Text: action program or LEAP. This constituent has

Speaker: NA
Text: just turned 18 and was assigned to a 20-week

Speaker: NA
Text: training course. Prior to being assigned to

Speaker: NA
Text: LEAP, this constituent received $318 each

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight from Social Security, which included

Speaker: NA
Text: rent assistance. But as a LEAP participant he

Speaker: NA
Text: receives only $300 a fortnight. Also, this

Speaker: NA
Text: payment is taxable, and he no longer gets rent

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is getting approximately $270 after tax

Speaker: NA
Text: from which he has to pay $170 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: in rent. In other words, he is nearly $60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight worse off. I think this shows just

Speaker: NA
Text: how miserable the Keating government is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only is the government trying to doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployment figures by thinking up

Speaker: NA
Text: some schemes-some of which may have

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits in their own right; nevertheless the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary objective is to reduce the figures on

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployment list-but in so doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is reducing the benefits to these

Speaker: NA
Text: people at a time-(Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Services

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Text: Macarthur)-I listened

Speaker: NA
Text: with interest to the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin ( Mr Rocher). For an Independent

Speaker: NA
Text: member of this House he was surprisingly

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-government. He attacked the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policies. He did not sound like an

Speaker: NA
Text: Independent at all. Indeed, he was scraping

Speaker: NA
Text: the bottom of the barrel to try to remember

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the policies that he was criticising.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the matters mentioned by the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member was hospital waiting lists. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was surprised to hear that because hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting lists are one of these convenient

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that state governments and the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House use to bash the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment around the head. Hospital waiting lists

Speaker: NA
Text: might be a problem in Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Court government, but we see

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging signs in New South Wales that

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of hospital waiting lists has been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought under control by the new Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the Minister for Health,

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrew Refshauge. This matter was made an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue at the last state election by the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only has this matter been brought under

Speaker: NA
Text: control by the Labor government, but there

Speaker: NA
Text: are encouraging signs in New South Wales-

Speaker: NA
Text: unlike other states-where a lot more money

Speaker: NA
Text: is being spent and a lot more commitment has

Speaker: NA
Text: been given to mental health. Let us not have

Speaker: NA
Text: this nonsense about health. If there is one

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that the opposition in this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: should keep quiet about-apart from indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial relations-it is health policy. As those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite know, Medicare is a very popular

Speaker: NA
Text: health system and it wiII become even better

Speaker: NA
Text: the longer this government stays in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition does not have a policy on

Speaker: NA
Text: health; the AMA has not written it yet. The

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition is totally lacking when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: policies on health and industrial relations.

Speaker: NA
Text: City Link Project

Speaker: Mr CLEARY
Text: Wills)-I cannot let the

Speaker: NA
Text: response by the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating)

Speaker: NA
Text: to my question on the City Link project go

Speaker: NA
Text: without a response. It is remarkable that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister can talk about Jeff Kennett-

Speaker: NA
Text: not remarkable, because everything he says

Speaker: NA
Text: about Jeff Kennett is basically right-but he

Speaker: NA
Text: does not want to rectify any of the problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Corio ( Mr O'Connor) is

Speaker: NA
Text: correct on the issue of state awards, but when

Speaker: NA
Text: it comes to the question of tax concessions to

Speaker: NA
Text: the City Link project the Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely nothing to say. He has accused Jeff

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett of just about everything bar being an

Speaker: NA
Text: axe murderer, but he is not going to take

Speaker: NA
Text: those tax concessions from him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to know whether our architectural

Speaker: NA
Text: aficionado, the Prime Minister, is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: bail us out in Vicloria and refuse to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government tax concessions. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: also like to know whether the shadow Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Costello )-who is present-might

Speaker: NA
Text: make a statement suggesting that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: refuse to give the state government tax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions for a project which is quite clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-competition and which would break all

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tertiary Education

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley)-Last week in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate the Liberal and National parties

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked off 4,200 additional tertiary educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion places for young Queenslanders. Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land was given its fair share of tertiary places

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Liberal and National parties in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate knocked them back. Those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate responsible for that should hang their

Speaker: NA
Text: heads in shame. I refer to Senator Ian Mac-

Speaker: NA
Text: donald, Senator MACGibbon, Senator Parer,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator O'Chee, Senator Herron and Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Boswell. Every Liberal Party and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party member in this House and in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: should hang their heads in shame.

Speaker: NA
Text: Queenslanders should ring and fax members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Liberal and National parties and tell

Speaker: NA
Text: them to reverse their stand. Liberal and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party members should stand up for

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland; not come into this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and destroy the educational future of young

Speaker: NA
Text: Queenslanders. It is an act of shame. Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: and National Party members should be asham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed of what they have done to the job pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects and career prospects of young Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: landers. Those opposite should change their

Speaker: NA
Text: stance and vote for Queensland in the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTU Representation

Speaker: Mr FILING
Text: Moore)-One of the things

Speaker: NA
Text: that upset me when the former Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's services were used by the ACTU

Speaker: NA
Text: in the CRA case was the way in which people

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed that the ski lIs of retired people are

Speaker: NA
Text: of no further use to the community. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, the ACTU was perfectly entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: recaIl the former Prime Minister to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: it in the case. Many retired people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community have skiIls which are perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: usable. These people are extremely useful to

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. The way in which the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister was criticised by the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) was absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: scandalous.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 3 p.m., in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with standing order 106A, the

Speaker: NA
Text: time for members' statements has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Blaxland-Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister)-I inform the House that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: absent from question time this week as he is

Speaker: NA
Text: ill. The Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr,

Speaker: NA
Text: will answer questions on his behalf.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, do you

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with the statement by the Treasurer this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning that it would be foolish to rule out

Speaker: NA
Text: new taxes if Labor is re-elected at the next

Speaker: NA
Text: election?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I noticed the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: slippin' and slidin' all over the TV screens all

Speaker: NA
Text: weekend, teIling anyone what they wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: believe on fiscal policy. So they are being

Speaker: NA
Text: asked. The Leader of the Opposition said no.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their commitment is that they won't be

Speaker: NA
Text: putting tax rates up or changing tax and they

Speaker: NA
Text: won't be cutting spending. He was asked

Speaker: NA
Text: persistently on Meet the Press whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be cutting spending or making program

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts. He said, 'No, it's just duplication and

Speaker: NA
Text: overlap that I'd be into.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Does he think he is talking to complete

Speaker: NA
Text: fools? There are people on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House who have been through 20 budget

Speaker: NA
Text: reviews. If you want to make major changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australian fiscal policy on the outlay side,

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to cut into programs. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: it means. So he said they are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: touch programs and they are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: touch taxation. They will just tippy toe into

Speaker: NA
Text: office. They won't do anything to anybody.

Speaker: NA
Text: They won't touch revenue. They won't touch

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays. They won't touch Medicare. They

Speaker: NA
Text: won't touch the Industrial Relations Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion; no, they won't stab it. They won't do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything. 'If they will just trust us to get into

Speaker: NA
Text: office'-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello- Mr Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Don't you like the an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-No, you haven't started the

Speaker: NA
Text: answer yet; that is your trouble. Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: the question was whether the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed with the Treasurer's statement that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be foolish to rule out new taxes if

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is re-elected at the next election. The

Speaker: NA
Text: question goes to the Prime Minister's secret

Speaker: NA
Text: tax agenda. He has not addressed this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: slightest. I ask you to direct him to be rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant to that question.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Prime Minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked a question about fiscal policy. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: responding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello- Mr Speaker, on a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order: he was not asked a general question

Speaker: NA
Text: about coalition intentions or fiscal policy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked a question about his tax agenda.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! There is no point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. Resume your seat. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The general line is: 'You

Speaker: NA
Text: know our policies and you know the team.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott- Mr Speaker, further to the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order raised by the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, could I refer you to a ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: by Speaker Cope-

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Oh, by all means; by all

Speaker: NA
Text: means!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott-talking about ministers who

Speaker: NA
Text: persisted in spreading misinformation about

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition. On 2 August 1974 Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: Cope said that the minister was 'not entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk about the remarks of the right honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman that has nothing to do with his

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio'. He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is not responsible for what other

Speaker: NA
Text: people say. He is responsible for giving infonnation

Speaker: NA
Text: conceming his own department. He is not respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for what anybody in another Party says.

Speaker: NA
Text: And he ruled the minister out of order. I put

Speaker: NA
Text: it to you, Mr Speaker, that standing order 142

Speaker: NA
Text: and standing order 145 mean that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and other ministers are simply not

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to blackguard the opposition in the

Speaker: NA
Text: guise of answering questions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. I urge you to uphold the ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: of Speaker Cope.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. I invite the honourable member to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a look at a statement which I made in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place which amplified previous rulings of

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers in respect of the matters he has

Speaker: NA
Text: raised.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The general opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: position on fiscal policy and all these policies

Speaker: NA
Text: is: 'You know the team and you know what

Speaker: NA
Text: our views are.' In other words, 'We won't go

Speaker: NA
Text: saying expressly what we'll do; you know

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophically where we are coming from.'

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what he thinks will constitute a

Speaker: NA
Text: mandate were he to win an election. In

Speaker: NA
Text: America, in a quite old-fashioned way Newt

Speaker: NA
Text: Gingrich, Senator Dole and others actually put

Speaker: NA
Text: a program to the people of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which a very large Republican majority

Speaker: NA
Text: in both houses of the Congress was won.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition is saying: 'I

Speaker: NA
Text: will not put revenue up. I won't cut spending.

Speaker: NA
Text: I won't do anything to offend anybody.' Then

Speaker: NA
Text: he will want to claim he has a mandate. On

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House we have made the point

Speaker: NA
Text: over and over that this is the second lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed country in the Western world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer said today that we would broadly

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the present level of tax. The present

Speaker: NA
Text: level of tax is forecast at 23 per cent of GDP,

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1994-95. In 1983-84, when the government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office-in a recession, when tax

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue had been badly hit-it was 23.1 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of GDP. So it was 23.1 per cent of GDP

Speaker: NA
Text: when the government came to office and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 per cent now, after the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in office in that period.

Speaker: NA
Text: So when the Treasurer says that we would

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly maintain the present level of tax-it

Speaker: NA
Text: varies according to the economic cycle-in

Speaker: NA
Text: essence he is referring to no more than those

Speaker: NA
Text: very pertinent statistics and giving me the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to remind the House that Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia is the second lowest taxed country among

Speaker: NA
Text: Western developed countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Contrast that record with the cheap commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of the opposition. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is determined not to actually put

Speaker: NA
Text: a firm statement down on anything. He

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that he will not lift taxation or

Speaker: NA
Text: ual taxes and he will not cut spending.

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, he will give up all of the instruaverage

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on fiscal policy and wish to be bea

Speaker: NA
Text: lieved on it, and then when he gets asked

Speaker: NA
Text: persistently about any other matters-Medicent

Speaker: NA
Text: care, wages, the Industrial Relations Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion-no, he will not touch anything. 'If you

Speaker: NA
Text: will just let us tippy toe into office we

Speaker: NA
Text: then set up shop and our mandate will be:

Speaker: NA
Text: "You know what we have always had in per

Speaker: NA
Text: mind"-not our written word, not our stated

Speaker: NA
Text: word.' That is not a mandate. The Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will then say: 'People know

Speaker: NA
Text: where we are coming from. They know what

Speaker: NA
Text: our views are.' Yes, we know what their

Speaker: NA
Text: views are-$10 billion of cuts in government

Speaker: NA
Text: spending; that is what you are on the record

Speaker: NA
Text: as supporting-and introducing a state income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax and state consumption taxes. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: things that you are really on about.

Speaker: NA
Text: The deputy over here in some interview lows:

Speaker: NA
Text: with someone from the BRW, sitting down as

Speaker: NA
Text: if they had given him some sort of truth drug,

Speaker: NA
Text: and out it all popped: 'Yes, we are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: hop into the vertical fiscal imbalance, which

Speaker: NA
Text: means we are going to give taxing powers to

Speaker: NA
Text: the states.' One thing is for certain: when

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard says he won't lift tax and he

Speaker: NA
Text: won't cut government spending, don't believe

Speaker: NA
Text: him. Because what he will do

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. The government's position is this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here are the numbers: tax revenue to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1983-84, 23.1 per cent compared to 23 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent for this year. I will leave our case on that

Speaker: NA
Text: point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensioners

Speaker: Mr GRIFFIN
Text: Has the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: seen reports today concerning the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners in Australia? What is the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's response to those reports? Is it the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the government to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that Australian pensioners get a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: deal from the government?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Before the government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office pensions were not indexed,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly not twice yearly as they are now,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they were not adjusted in a discretionary

Speaker: NA
Text: way by further commitments by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment off the budget to the pension system and

Speaker: NA
Text: is to pensioners. As a result, pensions were

Speaker: NA
Text: individaround 22-odd per cent of average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: In earnings. They are now at 25.7 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly earnings. The government had

Speaker: NA
Text: target of getting pensions to 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: average weekly earnings. They are at 25.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: of average weekly earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the opposition leader was last in

Speaker: NA
Text: office, the real value of pensions fell by two

Speaker: NA
Text: will per cent. In fact, when the Whitlam govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment came to office, pensions were below 20

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of average weekly earnings. It was a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment of the Whitlam government to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring them to 25 per cent, which brought into

Speaker: NA
Text: the public domain that commitment by Labor.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it proves one point: when Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: governments are elected, age pensions go up;

Speaker: NA
Text: when coalition governments are elected, age

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions go down. That has been the accu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate, historical fact. Yesterday, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the the Opposition during an interview was asked

Speaker: NA
Text: about pensions. The interview went as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard: Pensions?

Speaker: NA
Text: Michelle Grattan: Yes, would you retain them?

Speaker: NA
Text: Compere: Age pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard: Absolute iron clad retention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Michelle Grattan: Twenty-five per cent of aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age weekly earnings?

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard: Well, well, we are going to retain

Speaker: NA
Text: is just the the present system.

Speaker: NA
Text: He prides himself on being tricky with words.

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP, The compere comes back and says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The present system is 25 per cent of average

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly earnings. It is not simply adjusting them to

Speaker: NA
Text: CPI. That is the commitment?

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard: Well we retain the adjustment to

Speaker: NA
Text: cpr and-

Speaker: NA
Text: Michelle Grattan: And the 25 per cent?

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard: Well the 25 per cent is a goal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is, not any government he might lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: our government. In other words, he has slid

Speaker: NA
Text: by without making the commitment. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, you might recall that the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition recently made a speech to

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS where he made it clear again that the

Speaker: NA
Text: only commitment would be the adjustment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension to the CPI-and nothing more.

Speaker: NA
Text: What needs to be understood is that if we

Speaker: NA
Text: assume that average weekly earnings increase,

Speaker: NA
Text: say, by around one per cent a year-and

Speaker: NA
Text: recently they have been going up by more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 1Y2 per cent a year-over 10 years the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension would be 10 per cent higher in real

Speaker: NA
Text: terms than if you just maintained its real

Speaker: NA
Text: value.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the commitment to giving

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension a relationship to average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings means not just an adjustment in real

Speaker: NA
Text: terms to maintain it, but to let it grow along

Speaker: NA
Text: with the rest of the work force so its relative

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasing power is improved. So if you have

Speaker: NA
Text: real increases in wages, meaning above the

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation rate, you get real increases in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. That is what he will not commit to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then with the high cynicism he learned from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Carrick and others, he stuck a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the afternoon-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: It is John Carrick now?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: He taught you most of

Speaker: NA
Text: your dirty tricks. Mr Howard said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear and absolute Coalition policy-

Speaker: NA
Text: that was after I put out a statement-

Speaker: NA
Text: both to index pensions on a twice-yearly basis ...

Speaker: NA
Text: and as well maintain their value at 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: average weekly earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the interview, when pressed, he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, well, we are going to retain the present

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: When asked whether that was not simply

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted in the CPI he repeated:

Speaker: NA
Text: we retain the adjustment to CPI-

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, he got a third go. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Well the 25 per cent is a goal of the government's.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, at midday it is not on, but at 5 o'clock it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a policy of the opposition. You must think

Speaker: NA
Text: the gallery are the greatest bunch of dodos

Speaker: NA
Text: and fools, the greatest bunch of naive clots,

Speaker: NA
Text: that have ever graced the portals of this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament-to believe this sort of rubbish

Speaker: NA
Text: that you would push out at 5 o'clock in the

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon when you have had a chance to go

Speaker: NA
Text: with a considered statement to ACOSS, where

Speaker: NA
Text: you gave notice for weeks that you were

Speaker: NA
Text: going to make the big wasteland speech at

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS. Then, when you got to ACOSS,

Speaker: NA
Text: what did you say about pensions? You said

Speaker: NA
Text: you would only maintain them with the CPI.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was no mention of average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: In your declaratory main statement to the

Speaker: NA
Text: peak welfare body, was there any mention of

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent of average weekly earnings? No

Speaker: NA
Text: way. Was there any mention of it yesterday?

Speaker: NA
Text: No way. When pressed three times, did you

Speaker: NA
Text: commit yourself to it? No way. But when you

Speaker: NA
Text: felt the heat of understanding what the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's commitment was, you put out

Speaker: NA
Text: this press statement saying that you will

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain it. If anyone believes that, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in fairies at the bottom of the garden.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make this point again to all those pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, particularly those in the demographic

Speaker: NA
Text: group who have a tendency to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition: John Howard will cut the real value

Speaker: NA
Text: of your pension. John Howard will cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: relative purchasing power of your pension. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has proven it. If he gets into office, he will

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'You know the team. You know where

Speaker: NA
Text: we have come from. Look at my speech to

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS.' Was there any mention of 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of average weekly earnings? Someone

Speaker: NA
Text: will say, ' Mr Howard, you put out a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: on 26 November 1995 that said it.' He will

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'Look at our main speech to ACOSS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the things that I have said on the

Speaker: NA
Text: record.' That is the game that the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is playing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that every pensioner organisation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia knows that, as a consequence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's policy, if this government had

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted pensions by the consumer price

Speaker: NA
Text: index, single pensioners would be $20 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: worse and couples would be $34 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: worse off. So I ask pensioners to consider

Speaker: NA
Text: whether, were Mr Howard to be Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, they could stand the loss of $20 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: as a single pensioner or $34 a week as a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner couple. They are the sorts of poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies that he presided over when Treasurer and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are the policies that he is still committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister that before the last election he

Speaker: NA
Text: legislated income tax cuts. After the election,

Speaker: NA
Text: he increased wholesale sales tax on all items

Speaker: NA
Text: by two per cent, increased wine tax, increased

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol tax by 5c and 7c per litre, increased

Speaker: NA
Text: company tax by three per cent and abolished

Speaker: NA
Text: the l-a-w tax cuts which would otherwise be

Speaker: NA
Text: payable in five weeks on 1 January 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since it is clear that you now have in mind

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing new taxes if re-elected, what new

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes do you have in mind?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: What I made very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: in the run-up to the 1993 election-you might

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that we discussed this issue on Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Brien's Lateline program-was that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government would be keeping revenue to

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP at about the levels which then obtained.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been through that issue in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: on a number of occasions. Let me give you

Speaker: NA
Text: the numbers again. Revenue to GDP is at 23

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. It is exactly where it was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: recession year of 1983-84. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: over the period of the government's life, we

Speaker: NA
Text: still have around 23 per cent of revenue to

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP. That is the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government did not make commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: of the kind which those opposite are now

Speaker: NA
Text: making and foolishly believe that people will

Speaker: NA
Text: accept; that is, that they will not increase tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rates or change the tax system in any way. Do

Speaker: NA
Text: you think people are complete mugs when

Speaker: NA
Text: you tell them that sort of stuff? That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: you think.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the commitments which the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is now to legislate, in respect of having

Speaker: NA
Text: paid the first round of the tax cuts and the

Speaker: NA
Text: second round of their superannuation ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: counts, the totality is greater than the quantum

Speaker: NA
Text: of the One Nation tax cuts announced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: One Nation statement in 1992. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are paying taxpayers back more than what

Speaker: NA
Text: we said we would in the One Nation state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of 1992. That is the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: record. The fact that we remain the second

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest taxed country in the OECD makes it

Speaker: NA
Text: very clear that we in Australia are running a

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively small public sector very efficiently.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have outlays to GDP in trend terms at

Speaker: NA
Text: around 25 per cent of GDP and revenue at

Speaker: NA
Text: around 23 per cent of GDP.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the sorts of figures which, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated to the House some time ago, are up

Speaker: NA
Text: in lights as the sorts of numbers which are

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as part of the convergence criteria

Speaker: NA
Text: for the European monetary system. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: most of the countries you would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify us with would not qualify but Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia would, and that is because of this sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of outcome. When the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion goes around saying he will not cut

Speaker: NA
Text: government spending and he will not change

Speaker: NA
Text: or increase tax rates, do not believe him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensioners

Speaker: Ms DEAHM
Text: My question is addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's commitment to maintaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension at 25 per cent of average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings. What effect does such a commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment have on pensioners?

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Text: I can inform the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has retained its commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to keeping the pension at or above 25

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of average weekly earnings. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of a number of key social benchmarks

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has adopted over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years. In fact, we have had that as an objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive for some considerable time. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to achieve that benchmark since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990 and to equal or exceed it ever since.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is very significant. By contrast, during

Speaker: NA
Text: the period of the coalition government the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension was allowed to drift down to 22.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of average weekly earnings and there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a two per cent real reduction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very important to bear in mind the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of a commitment of that sort and set it

Speaker: NA
Text: against the sorts of statements that emanate

Speaker: NA
Text: from the opposition about what it claims it

Speaker: NA
Text: can do on the fiscal policy front. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite have made statements implying that

Speaker: NA
Text: they can take around $10 billion off outlays.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition gave a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in his address to ACOSS and said that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would not take $10 billion off the social

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net. There is no ambiguity about the

Speaker: NA
Text: implication of the opposition's policy. It says

Speaker: NA
Text: it would get the budget into surplus without

Speaker: NA
Text: asset sales. On the adjusted ABS definition,

Speaker: NA
Text: that implies a $10 billion cut in outlays.

Speaker: NA
Text: To give some idea of what maintaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of commitment that the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: on pensions implies in terms of outlays, on 22

Speaker: NA
Text: September this year the government increased

Speaker: NA
Text: the base pension for single people by $9.80

Speaker: NA
Text: a fortnight and for each member of a married

Speaker: NA
Text: couple by $8.20 a fortnight. That adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: to the pension was made on 22 September

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. The budgetary cost of that, when

Speaker: NA
Text: you take into account flow-oTIS to other

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, was around $800 million in a full

Speaker: NA
Text: year. That is the sort of commitment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outlay side that is required in order to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain that sort of commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: After a stumblebum performance by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition on Sunday, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation where he had given no commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: on that 25 per cent issue, he issued a press

Speaker: NA
Text: lease at 5 o'clock yesterday saying that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would. How on earth are the opposition going

Speaker: NA
Text: to reconcile the achievement of that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: social policy objective with the sorts of state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments they have made on fiscal policy? This

Speaker: NA
Text: is something that arises time and again and

Speaker: NA
Text: which they refuse to address in any coherent

Speaker: NA
Text: or sensible way. If you look at the perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of this government compared with that

Speaker: NA
Text: of the coalition in terms of the social safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net, you see that the record under us has been

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent real improvements whereas the

Speaker: NA
Text: record under the coalition has been consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: real declines. If we had done no more than

Speaker: NA
Text: index the pension since we came into office,

Speaker: NA
Text: a single pensioner would be getting from $20

Speaker: NA
Text: per week less and a married couple would be

Speaker: NA
Text: getting from $34 per week less. The reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is no coherency or sense in the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition's statements in these areas. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no reason that the pensioners of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: could have to believe any commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from the coalition. Their record is the

Speaker: NA
Text: diametrical opposite of maintenance and

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement of that safety net. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct and very clear contrast with the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensioners

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. In 1989 the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government first promised, and renewed at

Speaker: NA
Text: Bankstown before the 1993 election, to

Speaker: NA
Text: completely remove all age pensioners from

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax system by 1995. Less than a week

Speaker: NA
Text: after the 1993 election that promise was with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn by your then Treasurer Mr Dawkins

Speaker: NA
Text: who said he did not feel bound by it. Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: age pensioners still paying tax? Secondly, I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer the Prime Minister to his government's

Speaker: NA
Text: lowering of the eligibility threshold for family

Speaker: NA
Text: payments since the last federal election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Considering that the change led to some

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated $118,000 families losing their basic

Speaker: NA
Text: family payment, why were they not told of

Speaker: NA
Text: the change as part of Labor's policy prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1993 election? Why should anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: believe a word the Prime Minister is saying

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning social policy, given his complete

Speaker: NA
Text: deception of pensioners and families?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I suppose if you have

Speaker: NA
Text: rebeen here for 20 years in opposition you have

Speaker: NA
Text: got to get your kicks somehow. Is the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber really seriously trying to suggest-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Answer the question.

Speaker: NA
Text: MrKEATING-We have heard from the

Speaker: NA
Text: real genius on the comer over there, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. He interjected. Does the questioner

Speaker: NA
Text: really contend, in the implication of his

Speaker: NA
Text: question, that there have not been huge

Speaker: NA
Text: increases-massive increases-to low income

Speaker: NA
Text: families since the government has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: office?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Come on! Give us the an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: There have been massive

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in rent assistance, additional family

Speaker: NA
Text: payment and the family allowance supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Many times in the House both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Security and I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: through the numbers about the huge increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in allowances under this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Gallus-What about your promise,

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hindmarsh!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The last one I gave was

Speaker: NA
Text: a few minutes ago about the basic rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. The basic rate of pension came from

Speaker: NA
Text: 22-odd per cent of average weekly earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-You said 'all pensioners'.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: It is worth to a pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: $20 a week-$34 a week to a pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: couple-or weren't you listening? On this

Speaker: NA
Text: question about the tax system, as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's policies, two-thirds of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners-all those on the full rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension-have been freed of tax liability

Speaker: NA
Text: completely since July 1990. Not only did the

Speaker: NA
Text: government increase the threshold-the free

Speaker: NA
Text: area-within which pensioners can earn but

Speaker: NA
Text: we have removed it completely from the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: system. At the time when Mr Howard was

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, under the coalition government, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only was there a miserable free area-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Gallus-You are stumbling a lot,

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: where some additional

Speaker: NA
Text: income could be earned without someone

Speaker: NA
Text: losing any pension, but when pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: earned additional income they were taxed on

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Now they are not taxed on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Gallus-And they are still paying tax.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I warn the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hindmarsh!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: You can still have a full

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, with a generous increase in the free

Speaker: NA
Text: area, and not pay one dollar in tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-That wasn't the promise.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: When Mr Howard was

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer full pensioners were taxed fully on

Speaker: NA
Text: the income above the threshold. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: two things about that. Because you had such

Speaker: NA
Text: a miserable free area, not only would they

Speaker: NA
Text: lose part of their full pension by any modest

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in earnings-say from superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: or from deposits they had in a bank-but, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as that, you would actually tax the

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings in the free area. People opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: have the hide to ask me that question. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: their record. They must have a sort of front

Speaker: NA
Text: school in the Liberal Party to learn how you

Speaker: NA
Text: can say the most embarrassing things and not

Speaker: NA
Text: be embarrassed. They must run through a

Speaker: NA
Text: course or something. You would have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: psychologically prepared for this sort of thing

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to ask that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: body who is a full pensioner now has a

Speaker: NA
Text: generous free area and not one dollar of it is

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Text: My question is to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, and it concerns Medicare. Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: government remain committed to Medicare,

Speaker: NA
Text: and what steps is the government taking to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that our health system meets the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of all Australians?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The Labor Party have

Speaker: NA
Text: long believed-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter will wait for a minute. I again today

Speaker: NA
Text: remind people of standing order 55: ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: are entitled to be heard-and they will be.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The Labor Party have

Speaker: NA
Text: always believed that part of the social fabric

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia should be the right to universality

Speaker: NA
Text: in health protection. But we do not regard it

Speaker: NA
Text: as something that the market might give you.

Speaker: NA
Text: We regard it as a social right. If you get sick,

Speaker: NA
Text: you are entitled to be looked after. It is not,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'If you get sick and you have got money you

Speaker: NA
Text: are entitled to be looked after,' but, 'If you

Speaker: NA
Text: get sick you are entitled to be looked after.'

Speaker: NA
Text: This, of course, the coalition have never be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieved. They believe you are only entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: health protection if you can pay for it. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is their basic position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I again go back to the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's Meet the Press interview yester-

Speaker: NA
Text: day. He had a right little blow-out on Meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the Press yesterday. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I don't accept for a moment that we went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: last election as Paul Keating alleges promising to

Speaker: NA
Text: abolish Medicare; that is wrong, we didn't.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said that with intonation and meaning. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Fightback changes included Medicare for

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and card holders only and bulk-

Speaker: NA
Text: billing abolished for Medicare except for

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare recipients. If that is not the destruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Medicare, what is? If that is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of the universality of the system,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is? That was only three years ago. That

Speaker: NA
Text: has followed the general views he has put

Speaker: NA
Text: over the period. When he was leader he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Medicare system is a total disaster. We will be

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing changes to Medicare that amount to its

Speaker: NA
Text: question. Everyde facto dismantling.

Speaker: NA
Text: The questioner said:

Speaker: NA
Text: You will pull it right apart?

Speaker: NA
Text: And he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, we will pull it right apart.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have thought that was plain enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is his view. It has always been his view.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there was more of it. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The second thing we will do is we will get rid of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bulk-billing system, it is an absolute rart.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have thought that, if you are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: pull it apart and dismantle it and get rid of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bulk-billing system because it is a rort,

Speaker: NA
Text: what you really mean to do is hop into

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare. So the questioner-it was actually

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Laws-says to him:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... so really what you are saying is what you

Speaker: NA
Text: do is take us back to how things were pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare?

Speaker: NA
Text: The reply was:

Speaker: NA
Text: As best we can, yes, recognising that in a society

Speaker: NA
Text: you never go completely back, but I would love to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back.

Speaker: NA
Text: What he would like to do is really go back.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know where back means. It is about 1953,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the dreamtime of his political life. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is: basically what he means is, 'Medicare is

Speaker: NA
Text: a total disaster. We will propose changes that

Speaker: NA
Text: amount to its de facto dismantling. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: pull it right apart. We will get rid of bulk-billbottom

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It is a rort. And we will go back to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare.' That is his position. It is all out

Speaker: NA
Text: there in his health policy. In 1987 he says he

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow opting out of the Medicare arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, abolish bulk-billing and says that

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare is a failure. What he says on Meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the Press is not what he says when asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: But, Mr Howard, you have not put ail your policies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the marketplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: People know where we stand. They know who the

Speaker: NA
Text: team will be.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words-wink, wink-'We'll be there,

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have always been, for our old,

Speaker: NA
Text: long-run position to policies.' The long-run

Speaker: NA
Text: position to policies is to smash Medicare.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has always been his position. Then he

Speaker: NA
Text: was contesting yesterday that the Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: government did not abolish Medicare. In fact

Speaker: NA
Text: what Mr Fraser said is, 'We are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the Medibank scheme. The scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue as it was introduced.' That is

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty much almost word for word. Mr How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard said:

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of people will say that the changes Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: made did not amount to dismantling Medicare ...

Speaker: NA
Text: He thinks he is good with the words. He

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks the media and the public will not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand what he is in fact saying. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: only one party that will keep universality of

Speaker: NA
Text: health protection in Australia, and that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. That is the only party that will

Speaker: NA
Text: keep health protection as a common right, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a public right in this country. What would

Speaker: NA
Text: happen under a Howard government is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they would go back to a two-tiered medical

Speaker: NA
Text: will system: the well-heeled system for the weal-

Speaker: NA
Text: thy and basically public squalor for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: might somehow pay to keep a toehold in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the whole question of universality would

Speaker: NA
Text: go.

Speaker: NA
Text: I told the House not long ago about what

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of funds are involved in a rebate system

Speaker: NA
Text: for private health insurance of the kind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition espouses. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the sort of money that would hit the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. But of course he will not touch tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and he will not touch outlays, so I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know what he is going to do to the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: line other than poke a hole in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, with private health fund reserves

Speaker: NA
Text: over $1.6 billion now, why would the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition decide to give another

Speaker: NA
Text: billion dollars to the private health system?

Speaker: NA
Text: But that is what he wants to do. He is not

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the public health system; he is

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the private health system. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in basically the gold-plated private

Speaker: NA
Text: system for the people he thinks he represents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he is interested in public squalor for the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, the public of Australia should

Speaker: NA
Text: rest assured on these things: when John

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard says he will maintain Medicare, don't

Speaker: NA
Text: believe him. The only party that will maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare and keep it growing is of course the

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Human Services and Health

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I direct a question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister about believability. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: cabinet was deciding whether or not to use

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' money in an attempt to stop the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth about the Minister for Human Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Health emerging, did you disclose to the

Speaker: NA
Text: cabinet the inside information you had on the

Speaker: NA
Text: case from Labor leader, Jim MCGinty, or did

Speaker: NA
Text: you cover it up? And is it a fact that the real

Speaker: NA
Text: reason you tried to stop the royal commission

Speaker: NA
Text: going ahead-in other words, the real reason

Speaker: NA
Text: you tried to cover up the truth-was that you

Speaker: NA
Text: knew beforehand that Carmen Lawrence was

Speaker: NA
Text: lying?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Is that in order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker?

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
