Text: Leader of the Opposition. All these cuts are

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting in bed closures, increased waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: lists, loss of services, loss of hundreds of jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and industrial disputes-including the doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria. That is your commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare on the opposition benches. Until

Speaker: NA
Text: you repudiate it, that is what Australians will

Speaker: NA
Text: see as Liberal governments in action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Human Services and Health

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: My question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of his own pledge on 19 December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 when he rolled his former boss and

Speaker: NA
Text: current ACTU advocate, Bob Hawke, that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would: one, deal honestly deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: people; two, tell them the truth; and, three,

Speaker: NA
Text: resist the temptation to gild the lily. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the Prime Minister that, in response to

Speaker: NA
Text: a question in this House on 28 August, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said: 'I insist that in the performance of their

Speaker: NA
Text: public duties, in their dealings with the public

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the parliament ministers tell the truth

Speaker: NA
Text: and behave honestly at all times.' In view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that a royal commission has now

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly found that the Minister for Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Health not only gilded the lily

Speaker: NA
Text: but clearly lied and, in doing so, clearly failed

Speaker: NA
Text: the ministerial test you so passionately in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted upon in August, why do you not now

Speaker: NA
Text: insist that she step down as a minister in your

Speaker: NA
Text: government?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Yeah, the way Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Nixon did with Asia Dairy; the way when all

Speaker: NA
Text: those sorts of characters were around? I mean,

Speaker: NA
Text: you need a memory to be around here, you

Speaker: NA
Text: know. What about the meat substitution

Speaker: NA
Text: racket?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I can only again quote no less

Speaker: NA
Text: a source than Sir Garfield Barwick. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it remarkable that the public accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct of royal commissions as a means of

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining evidence, bearing in mind that our

Speaker: NA
Text: forebears revolted against the Star Chamber, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was a standing royal commission of its day. Press

Speaker: NA
Text: and politicians alike seem quite anxious to call

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commissions in all manner of activities, not

Speaker: NA
Text: pausing to consider that the powers of a royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission are easily abused. Indeed, the public

Speaker: NA
Text: spectacle of witnesses squirming under questioning

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Commissioner or by his Assisting Counsel

Speaker: NA
Text: provides dramatic copy for the daily press to the

Speaker: NA
Text: delectation of many of its readers.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is in his text, A radical tory, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: published this year. How apt those comments

Speaker: NA
Text: about a royal commission. I also made clear

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House the other day the points made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Lawrence Street. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... a royal commission has no connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: court as such. It has nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: istration of justice. A royal commission or a

Speaker: NA
Text: commission of inquiry is an instrument of the

Speaker: NA
Text: executive government and they are appointed in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to carry out a task that is put upon them by

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, not only are those observations

Speaker: NA
Text: completely correct, but as well as that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have the spectacle of Mr Marks himself

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that his professional training is such

Speaker: NA
Text: that he operates on all the facts. Let me quote

Speaker: NA
Text: him:

Speaker: NA
Text: The terms of reference have turned out of course

Speaker: NA
Text: to be fairly restrictive and stirred up a hornets nest.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is part of my training not to make assumptions

Speaker: NA
Text: on half the evidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: That did not stop him taking further views.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello--So he went on to hear all of

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: He did not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-He did.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Deputy Lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: er of the Opposition will not interject!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The terms of reference

Speaker: NA
Text: would not let him hear it all. He went on:

Speaker: NA
Text: The sooner this commission comes to an end the

Speaker: NA
Text: better. I think the experience here has demonstrated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the usefulness of royal commissions is fast

Speaker: NA
Text: receding. One thing one day and another the next

Speaker: NA
Text: has made virtually the result of this commission

Speaker: NA
Text: probably open to some doubt.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is entirely open to doubt. It is for that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that it deserves to be treated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: utter contempt it deserves--contempt for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government which corruptly arranged for its

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting and its terms of reference; for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and the former

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy leader, the member for Chisholm, who

Speaker: NA
Text: for connived in the terms of reference; for Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Richard Court who could not remember

Speaker: speaking to Mr HOWARD
Text: he would not say he

Speaker: NA
Text: did not speak to him but he could not remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber; and for the manner in which the people

Speaker: NA
Text: were called.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of first calling the petitioner, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Easton, or the person who wrote the petition,

Speaker: NA
Text: the clerk, or the person who presented the

Speaker: NA
Text: petition, Mr Halden, who was the first wit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness? A former press secretary to the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costello-Yes, a staffer-a press

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with the admin- secretary.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I am not going to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to advise the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to remain silent.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: As I indicated to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House the other day, we find that Mr Richard

Speaker: NA
Text: Court's private staff had given briefings to the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission before it actually undertook its

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings. In other words, the process was

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely corrupted. As I said at the beginning

Speaker: NA
Text: of all this, no Queen's Counsel, no barrister,

Speaker: NA
Text: and no former judge should trust their reputa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions with a reference like this. But Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Marks, in my view naively and foolishly, did

Speaker: NA
Text: and he has worn the admonition and the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences as a result.

Speaker: NA
Text: From our point of view on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House we regard the whole process as dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: reputable. The minister's standing in public

Speaker: NA
Text: life has been obvious for all to see. She quite

Speaker: NA
Text: courageously set up an open royal commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion on proper terms of reference into what

Speaker: NA
Text: was called WA Inc. That action left her with

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a few enemies in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: some of whom had a chance to catch up with

Speaker: NA
Text: her during these grubby proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Uniform Credit Code

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Consumer Affairs. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: the status of action to implement a uniform

Speaker: NA
Text: credit code? Has the Tasmanian parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified that code? If not, why not?

Speaker: Ms MCHUGH
Text: The question that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member asked actually exposes a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgraceful and scandalous state of affairs, in

Speaker: NA
Text: that a few members of the upper house in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania are holding hostage every consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia who is waiting for the benefits of

Speaker: NA
Text: the uniform credit legislation. We have been

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for this uniform legislation for years,

Speaker: NA
Text: although all states and territories agreed to it

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly two years ago. Consumers are waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: for it because of the very considerable ben-

Speaker: NA
Text: efits that they will get, particularly in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the disclosure of detailed information. The

Speaker: NA
Text: banks are waiting for it, because the banking

Speaker: NA
Text: code of practice cannot come into operation

Speaker: NA
Text: until a uniform credit code is in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland was the first state to pass the

Speaker: NA
Text: template legislation, and all states have now

Speaker: NA
Text: passed it except for Western Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. I am informed that it will pass

Speaker: NA
Text: through the lower house of the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian parliament in the next couple

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks, but it is a very different story in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: What has happened in Tasmania is this.

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to enact uniform credit legislation was

Speaker: NA
Text: sent back to the lower house from the upper

Speaker: NA
Text: house with an amendment to exempt three

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian based finance companies from

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions. These companies are reported to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the Hobart based Personal Finance Co., the

Speaker: NA
Text: Launceston based Lendco Pty Ltd and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Smithton based Braddon Investment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance Pty Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been reported to my office that the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies have concerns with the code's

Speaker: NA
Text: rules concerning the precontractual disclosure

Speaker: NA
Text: of establishment fees. You have to ask why

Speaker: NA
Text: they would have problems with that. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: also been reported to my office that these

Speaker: NA
Text: three finance companies have very close links

Speaker: NA
Text: with members of the Tasmanian upper house.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the Deputy Leader for the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the upper house, Tony Fletcher, has

Speaker: NA
Text: declared that he is a shareholder in one of

Speaker: NA
Text: these companies, and other members also

Speaker: NA
Text: reportedly have connections. That is what has

Speaker: NA
Text: been reported to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tasmanian government refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept the amendment to exempt these com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies, so the bill has lapsed. That means

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as a result of what appears to be some

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty personal interests-some declared,

Speaker: NA
Text: some not--of a few members of the Tasman-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian upper house, all consumers in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will not have the benefit of this uniform credit

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Lyons asked what can be

Speaker: NA
Text: done about this. The fact is that this is state

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory legislation-it is not Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth legislation. But I can inform members

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth is represented on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Consumer Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: which met last Friday. That committee will

Speaker: NA
Text: propose that state and territory consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs ministers agree to an implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: date of 1 August 1996 for the code and that

Speaker: NA
Text: they proceed without Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: The upshot therefore is that, if the states

Speaker: NA
Text: and territories do not agree to that recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation, the implementation of a uniform credit

Speaker: NA
Text: code is under serious threat. It also means

Speaker: NA
Text: of that, if they do agree, Tasmanian consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: will miss out on the benefits that every other

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian consumer will enjoy under the

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation-all because three small, local

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian finance companies, which obvious-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly have very good connections in the Legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive Council, want to escape providing their

Speaker: NA
Text: its customers with the protection which this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation ensures and which every consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia is waiting for.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRIME MINISTER

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion of Censure

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong)-I seek leave

Speaker: NA
Text: to move a motion of censure against the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Keating).

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Mr Speaker, I gave this offer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Leader of the Opposition last Thursday.

Speaker: NA
Text: He then moved a suspension of standing

Speaker: NA
Text: orders refusing the offer. If you refuse the

Speaker: NA
Text: offer there is no point in coming back now.

Speaker: NA
Text: So stick it on Thursday, mate. I am not done

Speaker: NA
Text: with you yet.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The offer has been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fused.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (4.05 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing and sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House

Speaker: NA
Text: censures the Prime Minister for his paralysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership and:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) his failure to sack-

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I move that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition be no longer heard.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have to wait until the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition has put the motion

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Prime Minister moves that. Put the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: I wouldn't run for Speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: er, if I were you. You are a coward. I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing and sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House

Speaker: NA
Text: censures the Prime Minister for his paralysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership and:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) his failure to sack a minister who has been

Speaker: NA
Text: exposed as having lied;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) his failure to disclose that he had been told by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian Labor leader that his

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's claims were wrong;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) his use of taxpayers' money in an attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover up the truth;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) his industrial relations incompetence which

Speaker: NA
Text: enabled a disastrous strike to go ahead;

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) his inability to insist on truth from those around Simmons, D. W.

Speaker: NA
Text: him; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) his preoccupation with power plays involving

Speaker: NA
Text: himself, Mr Hawke and Mr Kelty rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: focusing on the needs of bauling Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, despite the cowardice-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the honourable member be not further

Speaker: NA
Text: heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: A division being called and the bells being

Speaker: NA
Text: rung-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I remind members

Speaker: NA
Text: that with division bells there are certain

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided. [4.12 p.m.]

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions on Notice

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: As the last time I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: you to write a letter to a minister pursuant to

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 150 produced a very quick

Speaker: NA
Text: response, Mr Speaker, I was wondering

Speaker: NA
Text: whether you would write three letters to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer with respect to questions 2553,

Speaker: NA
Text: 2554 and 2555, which first appeared on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice Paper on 22 August this year.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will endeavour to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the same quick response.

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions on Notice

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Text: Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: similarly rise to draw your attention to an

Speaker: NA
Text: unanswered question, No. 2552. That question

Speaker: NA
Text: has been on the Notice Paper longer than 90

Speaker: NA
Text: days and I ask that under standing order 150

Speaker: NA
Text: you write to the Minister for Housing and

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Development asking him to give an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate response.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I shall.

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions on Notice

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: My request also relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 150. I ask that you write to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and request that

Speaker: NA
Text: he answer my question 2429 of 19 June.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I shall.

Text: Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-

Text: agreed to:

Text: That so much of the standing and sessional

Text: the day No.1, government business (Grievance

Text: debate) when called on, continuing until 5.30 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: lodged for presentation as follows and copies

Speaker: NA
Text: will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that the traditional Christian view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the family unit excludes anything other than a male

Speaker: NA
Text: and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship,

Speaker: NA
Text: along with their children, and that it is necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: for this to be restated by our political leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian

Speaker: NA
Text: view of marriage as God's holy institution in which

Speaker: NA
Text: male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24;

Speaker: NA
Text: Matthew 19.5,6)

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and

Speaker: NA
Text: has restricted it to the union of male with female

Speaker: NA
Text: and that such marriage between male and female

Speaker: NA
Text: is commended in Scripture as honourable among

Speaker: NA
Text: all. (Ephesians 5.15-23)

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm that such marriage between male and

Speaker: NA
Text: female is ordained for life-long companionship,

Speaker: NA
Text: help and comfort which husband and wife ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord

Speaker: NA
Text: and should be nurtured in a godly home, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: human society can be strong and happy only where

Speaker: NA
Text: the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be

Speaker: NA
Text: made lawful by the law of any man or government,

Speaker: NA
Text: or the consent of parties, so as to allow those

Speaker: NA
Text: people to live together as married couples. (Mark

Speaker: NA
Text: 6.18; Leviticus 18.6-28)

Speaker: NA
Text: We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse

Speaker: NA
Text: with another male, or for a female with a female,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that since this is an abomination before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord, such as a prohibited relationship for marriage.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe the entire stability and well being of

Speaker: NA
Text: our society depends on maintaining this traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: Christian view of marriage and family (Leviticus

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives should call on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: BUSINESS

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness

Speaker: NA
Text: of marriage as being one male and one female.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) That the definition of a prohibited relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be

Speaker: NA
Text: amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so

Speaker: NA
Text: that it reads as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship are marriages-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) between a person and an ancestor or descend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant of the person; or

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole blood or the half blood); or

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage (c) between a male and a male or between a

Speaker: NA
Text: female and a female.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Abbott (from 31 citizens),

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson (from six citizens) and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snow (from 23 citizens).

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecom Mobile Net

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of certain residents of the Electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Higgins draw to the attention of the House our

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that local planning authorities are not able

Speaker: NA
Text: to fully represent the wishes of local residents

Speaker: NA
Text: under the present Telecommunications National

Speaker: NA
Text: Code.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore request that the House take the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary steps to resolve the above issue and that

Speaker: NA
Text: a new Telecommunications National Code be

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced with more power for local councils so

Speaker: NA
Text: that the concerns of the community are taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: account and residents are fully informed of planned

Speaker: NA
Text: installations of mobile telephone towers and cabling

Speaker: NA
Text: for pay television.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Costello (from nine citizens) and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Georgiou (from 25 citizens).

Speaker: NA
Text: Newsagents

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Right Honourable The Speaker and Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the House of Representatives in Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully shows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Authorised news agents are one of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining bastions of family owned and operated

Speaker: NA
Text: business and provide an efficient, low-cost and

Speaker: NA
Text: convenient service;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The present system of newspaper distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantees that every Victorian, no matter where

Speaker: NA
Text: they live, has access to home delivery of daily

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Owners of news agencies have purchased their

Speaker: NA
Text: business and invested in new technology on the

Speaker: NA
Text: security of a defined distribution territory for

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery and supply to sub-agents;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The Trade Practices Commission's plans to

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulate newspaper distribution will spell the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of universal home delivery, increase costs to

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers and force many news agents out of busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of Australia will:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) express its support for the present system of

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper distribution in Victoria and the commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial survival of family owned and operated news-

Speaker: NA
Text: agents; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) urge the Federal Government to direct the

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Practices Commission to ensure that its

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberations do not disadvantage newsagents who

Speaker: NA
Text: have invested time and money into building

Speaker: NA
Text: reputable businesses based on commercial arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which the Commission proposes to abolish.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Atkinson (from 26,772 citizens).

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Law Act

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: draws to the attention of the House the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Child Support Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact

Speaker: NA
Text: the following changes:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped

Speaker: NA
Text: and replaced by a more simplified version together

Speaker: NA
Text: with the minimum of rules and regulations neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. That The Family Court be replaced by a

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce

Speaker: NA
Text: and family breakdown be heard before, and deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined by a panel, the panel to be made up of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons qualified in matters arising from family

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. That legal professionals be barred from

Speaker: NA
Text: appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast

Speaker: NA
Text: savings to the disputing parties.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. That a modified fault clause be re-introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: to Family Law primarily designed to discourage

Speaker: NA
Text: adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of deserted and innocent parties.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. That the Child Support Agency be scrapped

Speaker: NA
Text: and replaced by an appropriate administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure within the Tribunal.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. That apart from cases of exceptional circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances parental-child access become the inalienable

Speaker: NA
Text: right of all parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. That alternative counselling, (Government

Speaker: NA
Text: funded) be made available through the churches

Speaker: NA
Text: home and that much more emphasis be placed on medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation in resolving disputes prior to the commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of legal proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Beale (from 80 citizens).

Speaker: NA
Text: Landmines

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of certain residents of the State of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria draws to the attention of the House the

Speaker: NA
Text: devastating effects of landmines, which maim and

Speaker: NA
Text: kill often decades after hostilities have ceased.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Through bilateral and multilateral relations

Speaker: NA

Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia draws to the attention of the House that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: steps be taken to stop it immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forest Protection

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully points out that: There is an urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: demand from the majority of Australians for

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate federal government intervention to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the remaining high conservation value

Speaker: NA
Text: forests and other areas which support flora and

Speaker: NA
Text: fauna habitats unique to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore request that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives calion the Federal Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the United Nations Biodiversity

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention, to which Australia is a signatory,

Speaker: NA
Text: and immediately implement the moratorium

Speaker: NA
Text: clause in the national forest policy statement;

Speaker: NA
Text: reap only what is sown and utilise readily

Speaker: NA
Text: available plantation timbers for industry needs;

Speaker: NA
Text: permanently protect all old growth forests,

Speaker: NA
Text: wilderness, and other high conservation value

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, under the guardianship of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous peoples, in co-operation with the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, conservation and scientific organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions;

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly implement timber industry transition

Speaker: NA
Text: from native forests to plantations, with provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for retraining, redeployment, and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment for affected workers and contractors;

Speaker: NA
Text: create employment incentives to collect seeds,

Speaker: NA
Text: propagate, establish and manage sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: permaculture-style mixed species timber planta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, on existing cleared and degraded lands;

Speaker: NA
Text: convert paper and fibre board manufacture to

Speaker: NA
Text: use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp and

Speaker: NA
Text: cane;

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage investment in the growing and

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing of indigenous, plantation based tree

Speaker: NA
Text: products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries,

Speaker: NA
Text: seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal

Speaker: NA
Text: resources;

Speaker: NA
Text: develop educational environmental tourism as

Speaker: NA
Text: a sensitively managed industry in appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural heritage and sacred sites; and

Speaker: NA
Text: further support the above initiatives by the

Speaker: NA
Text: progressive utilisation of defence personnel,

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and funding, to assist rural communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to implement sustainable plantation forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: practices.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Mack (from 221 citizens).

Text: Earth Repair Charter

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of concerned Australian citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully points out that:

Speaker: NA
Text: World-wide, people are concerned that important

Speaker: NA
Text: natural resources, such as trees, soil, pure

Speaker: NA
Text: water and our Earth's protective ozone layer-all

Speaker: NA
Text: essential for sustaining life-have been dangerously

Speaker: NA
Text: depleted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore urge that the Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian Parliament will:

Speaker: NA
Text: Let Australia lead the way and legislate to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement the Earth Repair Charter-a practical

Speaker: NA
Text: action plan-to help rectify humanity's environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental, social and economic imbalances, towards

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving, just, sustainable and cooperative local

Speaker: NA
Text: and global communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Earth Repair Charter's summarised objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives-

Speaker: NA
Text: Cooperate in peace for the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: Preserve our remaining natural heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: Declare an earth repair action decade

Speaker: NA
Text: Support the world's indigenous people

Speaker: NA
Text: Recognise interconnectedness of all life

Speaker: NA
Text: Use sustainable methods to end poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: Compost consciousness to improve soils

Speaker: NA
Text: Acquire immunity efficiency and vitality

Speaker: NA
Text: Educate for and practise healthy living

Speaker: NA
Text: Unite humanity in a common purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition is to show that-

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully claim

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia must preserve and uphold its present

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag which has proudly represented this

Speaker: NA
Text: country ever since the federation of its sovereign

Speaker: NA
Text: States in 1901, and then being confirmed under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Flags Act (1953). We do so because....

Speaker: NA
Text: It truly reflects our history and heritage, our

Speaker: NA
Text: culture, law and language;

Speaker: NA
Text: It embodies our common law rights and liberties,

Speaker: NA
Text: our very birthright;

Speaker: NA
Text: It signifies the Christian ethic, friendliness,

Speaker: NA
Text: international goodwill;

Speaker: NA
Text: It enshrines in memory the wartime sacrifices of

Speaker: NA
Text: our gallant servicemen and servicewomen;

Speaker: NA
Text: It symbolises our past achievements and inspires

Speaker: NA
Text: future loyal efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: So therefore do we petition that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Our present Australian National Flag be not

Speaker: NA
Text: changed, replaced or diminished in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever without such a proposal being first

Speaker: NA
Text: voted upon and approved by a majority of Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: Triple J ian citizens in a national referendum.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Text: by Mr Moore (from 20 citizens).
