Speaker: NA
Text: GRIEVANCE DEBATE

Speaker: NA
Text: Question proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That grievances be noted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service: Staff Cuts

Speaker: Mr SMYTH
Text: Canberra) (4.30 p.m.)-It is

Speaker: NA
Text: about time this government came clean on

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is up to with Public Service staffing

Speaker: NA
Text: Austudy numbers. You may recall that in May, before

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget, the Canberra Times ran a line that

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 4,000 public servants in this town may

Speaker: NA
Text: lose their jobs. Being the member for Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra, it is important to me and to all my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents because so much of the business

Speaker: NA
Text: that is conducted here in Canberra depends on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service. The Minister Assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for Public Service Matters ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Johns) did not know and could not say how

Speaker: NA
Text: many jobs would go. The minister could not

Speaker: NA
Text: say what the implications were in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: for Public Service numbers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wrote the minister a letter and in that

Speaker: NA
Text: letter I referred to recent media reports in

Speaker: NA
Text: which it was claimed that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: intends to make large cuts to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service as a result of the 1995 budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wrote to him on behalf of all Canberrans,

Speaker: NA
Text: expecting a reasonable answer. You will be

Speaker: NA
Text: amazed, I am sure, when you find out that in

Speaker: NA
Text: the letter I got back from the Minister Assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Prime Minister for Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Matters he claimed that he did not know how

Speaker: NA
Text: many jobs would be going. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: As the implementation of the Government's Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions is the responsibility of individual

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers and their Departments, I am unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide you with the precise figures on the possible

Speaker: NA
Text: staffing impact of the Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is fair enough, I guess. It means that,

Speaker: NA
Text: like so much of the Public Service, the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility has been devolved to the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental level and they spend their money as

Speaker: NA
Text: they see appropriate. That was okay.

Speaker: NA
Text: I then put a question on notice to each of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ministers asking, given that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Assisting the Prime Minister for Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Matters had said they would know,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they would please tell me what the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications of this year's budget were on

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service numbers. I did that on 30 June.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure you will be surprised to find out

Speaker: NA
Text: that, so far, I have not had a single response.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I have actually had is nothing. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: just a waste of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was forced to ask the Speaker on 17 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 24 October if he would write to the ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: and get them to respond to me. The Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: kindly did so. I am getting back answers that

Speaker: NA
Text: are a bit of a form letter. They state:

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you for your letter of 17 October 1995 in

Speaker: NA
Text: which you pointed out that a Question on Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: ... placed by Mr BM Smyth, Member for Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra ... had not been answered within the 90 day

Speaker: NA
Text: answering period. You would be aware this same

Speaker: NA
Text: question was also posed to 20 other Ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequent to this question I have been advised by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Finance will respond on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: all Ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is very curious because the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the Public Service could not

Speaker: NA
Text: answer that question himself, but it would

Speaker: NA
Text: now appear that the Minister for Finance ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley) is well able to do that. It is curious

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Department of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and Cabinet has been coordinating this re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse through the Minister for Finance since

Speaker: NA
Text: about mid-July. Even if you allow them 90

Speaker: NA
Text: days from mid-July, that would give a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse date of mid-October. Here we are

Speaker: NA
Text: almost in December and we still do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: what the implications of this year's budget are

Speaker: NA
Text: on Public Service numbers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is extraordinary. Not only is it extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary because it is a total disregard for the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary and democratic processes, but

Speaker: NA
Text: P0l1folio obviously the government holds all public

Speaker: NA
Text: servants in contempt. ObvIously, the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not know what they are doing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service. I think this is part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: malaise that found voice so clearly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra by-election when so many Canberr-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans felt they had been treated with arrogance

Speaker: NA
Text: and contempt by this government-given that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service is the main industry of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT, that the government does not know

Speaker: NA
Text: what they are doing with public servants and

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service numbers inside the ACT show

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government has not learnt from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra by-election.

Speaker: NA
Text: This also raises the question of whether or

Speaker: NA
Text: not the minister is competent to continue in

Speaker: NA
Text: his portfolio. If the Minister for Finance can

Speaker: NA
Text: come up with these answers, or is indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: charged with coming up with these answers,

Speaker: NA
Text: how is it that the Minister Assisting the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Public Service Matters cannot?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is curious that the minister assisting said

Speaker: NA
Text: that only the departments could answer

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the devolved responsibilities. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may well have been easy for him to have

Speaker: NA
Text: asked all the other ministers to give him the

Speaker: NA
Text: answers and to put an answer to my question

Speaker: NA
Text: together, but obviously he was not up to it

Speaker: NA
Text: because PM&C has decided that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Finance should do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that PM&C is actually coordinating

Speaker: NA
Text: this and that the Minister for Finance will do

Speaker: NA
Text: it, the question is raised: when will this

Speaker: NA
Text: happen and how long will it take? We are

Speaker: NA
Text: almost five months into the new budget cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: and this government still does not know what

Speaker: NA
Text: it is doing with the Public Service, and it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not know what it is doing with Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is evident in a couple of other areas as

Speaker: NA
Text: weB when you take into account things like

Speaker: NA
Text: the MPRA review of the Australian War

Speaker: NA
Text: Memorial, which went so badly for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, and indeed when you take into

Speaker: NA
Text: account that new Public Service legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was supposed to be before this House before

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the year. I had a meeting with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Commissioner the other day

Speaker: NA
Text: and he kindly told me that it would appear

Speaker: NA
Text: that the new Public Service legislation will be

Speaker: NA
Text: presented in this House at the earliest in

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly March next year. In fact, the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Commissioner and some of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: departments are getting ready to present new

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in July next year. It makes you

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder who is in charge of Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: activities inside this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it goes on. In the last 12 months we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen the number of public servants axed

Speaker: NA
Text: under this government double. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is quite capable of producing the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for the number of public servants it has axed,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it does not know how many it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: get rid of. It can do it for last year, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot do it for this year. Does that mean we

Speaker: NA
Text: now have to wait until next year to find out

Speaker: NA
Text: what was done in this year? If you have any

Speaker: NA
Text: management experience, you would know that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is not a very competent or a very oblig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing way to run a business.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Minister for Finance is now working

Speaker: NA
Text: on the answer, and he is-one of the letters

Speaker: NA
Text: I got back stated that he is 'currently seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: more information'-where will this answer

Speaker: NA
Text: come from and how is it that the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting could not do this? It seems curious

Speaker: NA
Text: that one of the most senior ministers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has been tasked with the fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: simple task of asking 21 departments how

Speaker: NA
Text: many public servants they are going to axe

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, if they are going to axe any, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister assisting could not do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does his inability to answer these

Speaker: NA
Text: questions say about his entire management of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service and, indeed, about the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Act? I think it is up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister to answer what he really does as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Matters and whether he is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing anything at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, in this country we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the great problem of youth unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last few years, APS employment of

Speaker: NA
Text: young people under the age of 25 has

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped by 60 per cent. Again, that input of

Speaker: NA
Text: new individuals into the Public Service itself

Speaker: NA
Text: is not happening. Young people in the ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: are being denied an opportunity to get into

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a minister who does not know

Speaker: NA
Text: how many people he is in control of. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a minister that allows things like the

Speaker: NA
Text: MPRA review of the War Memorial to go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead without any apology when it is found

Speaker: NA
Text: to be faulty. And now we have a minister

Speaker: NA
Text: overseeing a Public Service that is denying

Speaker: NA
Text: positions to young people in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: and, indeed, all electorates around Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing that makes me worried

Speaker: NA
Text: about the administration of the Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: and the things that are going on now is the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of departments that have been trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred out of Canberra and, in general, the

Speaker: NA
Text: decline in the numbers in the Public Service.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we look at the actual figures the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers contain, we see that the drop was

Speaker: NA
Text: about 1,700. I fully expected to get that back

Speaker: NA
Text: as an answer, but obviously that is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: right answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this now does is throw into doubt the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole validity of the budget papers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: budget papers and the ASL are how the

Speaker: NA
Text: government works out its expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: public servants. Given that there is one figure

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget papers that the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously not willing to back up, what are the

Speaker: NA
Text: true figures and what are the implications for

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service expenditure?

Speaker: NA
Text: The government have placed a lot of credi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility on the question of this year's budget but

Speaker: NA
Text: if they cannot answer how many public

Speaker: NA
Text: servants they expect to employ this year, then

Speaker: NA
Text: any figures that they have put forward in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to expenditure on wages must also be

Speaker: NA
Text: very rubbery. I put it to you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that this throws this year's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: into further doubt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra is the national capital and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: right that there are Public Service functions

Speaker: NA
Text: here. Given that about 48 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in this city is provided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service, these are important questions

Speaker: NA
Text: to all Canberrans. Indeed, the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, how the government administers this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and how the government spends

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' money are important questions to

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians. If the government are appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priating money and putting money towards

Speaker: NA
Text: public servants that they do not even know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they have, then you have to call into

Speaker: NA
Text: question the administration of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service by this government; you have

Speaker: NA
Text: to call into question the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Public Service by the current

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and you have to call into question

Speaker: NA
Text: how accurate the budget figures are in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to public servants and Public Service expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Aircraft Noise

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Text: Macarthur) (4.40 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: My grievance today is about a subject that is

Speaker: NA
Text: debated quite a lot in this place: aircraft noise

Speaker: NA
Text: around airports. Earlier today I presented a

Speaker: NA
Text: petition to the Bills and Papers Office obtain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing 1,221 signatures. The petition reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: "The humble petition of certain citizens of Australof

Speaker: NA
Text: ia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we oppose the construction of Sydney West

Speaker: NA
Text: Airport at Badgerys Creek by the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, without a new and comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) being

Speaker: NA
Text: completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous EIS was done over ten years ago, and

Speaker: NA
Text: did not take account of the rapid growth in our area

Speaker: NA
Text: or the inadequacy of aircraft noise prediction

Speaker: NA
Text: techniques. The noise problems experienced at

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford Smith Airport will be worse in our area

Speaker: NA
Text: as Sydney West will operate twenty four hours a

Speaker: NA
Text: day over now quiet semi-rural and residential areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you

Speaker: NA
Text: will not allow construction of Sydney West Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: at Badgerys Creek until a new and comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) has been

Speaker: NA
Text: completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray."

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, the petition has 1,221 signatures,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I understand there are many more on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way. The petition reflects the deep concern

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst residents in my electorate and neigh-

Speaker: NA
Text: bouring electorates about the likely effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction and operation of Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: West airport. This concern has obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: increased dramatically since the opening of

Speaker: NA
Text: the third runway at Sydney airport in Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber last year and the resulting noise problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in the inner city.

Speaker: NA
Text: The publicity surrounding the chaos caused

Speaker: NA
Text: by the new runway at Mascot could not have

Speaker: NA
Text: been missed by residents in my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly as it has become fashionable for

Speaker: NA
Text: inner city politicians to say that the answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the noise problems in Sydney is to fast-track

Speaker: NA
Text: Badgerys Creek airport. There is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that Sydney badly needs a second interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional airport and has done for many years.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is not good enough for inner city

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians, would-be politicians and single

Speaker: NA
Text: issue parties to simply presume that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: fix their noise problem by moving the noise

Speaker: NA
Text: out west.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has become quite clear from this petition

Speaker: NA
Text: and from the hundreds of letters and phone

Speaker: NA
Text: calls I have received in my electorate office

Speaker: NA
Text: that residents in my electorate will not cop

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft noise being transferred out there and

Speaker: NA
Text: will certainly not cop anything like the level

Speaker: NA
Text: noise now being experienced in places like

Speaker: NA
Text: Marrickville and Sydenham. Indeed, I regular-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly receive phone calls and letters from all

Speaker: NA
Text: over my electorate from places like Theresa

Speaker: NA
Text: Park, Thirlmere, Tahmoor, Bradbury, Narel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lan, Camden and Warragamba. These people

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want this airport because in many

Speaker: NA
Text: cases they moved away from inner Sydney to

Speaker: NA
Text: get away from aircraft noise and pollution.

Speaker: NA
Text: I even get many calls from people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirlmere area complaining about current

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft noise associated with the changed

Speaker: NA
Text: flight paths to Mascot airport. At first I found

Speaker: NA
Text: this unbelievable, but I have noticed when

Speaker: NA
Text: flying from Canberra to Sydney that the

Speaker: NA
Text: planes are flying a different route than they

Speaker: NA
Text: used to-we know that-and in many cases

Speaker: NA
Text: are flying much lower than previously. So

Speaker: NA
Text: you can understand the concerns people have

Speaker: NA
Text: about the likely noise impact of Badgerys

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Transport ( Mr Brereton)

Speaker: NA
Text: has said many times that in the construction

Speaker: NA
Text: of Sydney West airport we do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat the mistakes of Kingsford Smith

Speaker: NA
Text: airport. One of the first mistakes which

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be repeated is to proceed with

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of the airport at Badgerys Creek

Speaker: NA
Text: without a comprehensive, up-to-date EIS,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly examining the questions of noise,

Speaker: NA
Text: air and water pollution. The government has

Speaker: NA
Text: already announced a study to update some as-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects of the previous EIS, which was done in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985. Whether this will satisfy the concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: of residents remains to be seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: While it can be argued that you don't need

Speaker: NA
Text: to completely repeat the 1985 study, which

Speaker: NA
Text: included geological and other details which

Speaker: NA
Text: would not require updating, the request

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the petition for a new and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehensive EIS is nevertheless valid. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: petition points out, the 1985 EIS did not take

Speaker: NA
Text: account of the rapid housing development and

Speaker: NA
Text: population growth in the surrounding areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Due to the policies of the previous Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: state government, there has been considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: urban expansion in the surrounding areas

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1988. These include housing estates at

Speaker: NA
Text: Cecil Park and Silverdale in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous state government had also

Speaker: NA
Text: planned a huge housing development at South

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek, but this has not proceeded. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: also been rapid growth around Narellan,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Annan, Currans Hill and to the south

Speaker: NA
Text: of Campbelltown.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Macarthur region is the fastest growing

Speaker: NA
Text: area in New South Wales. People throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of Macarthur, as well as those

Speaker: NA
Text: in the adjoining electorates of Werriwa and

Speaker: NA
Text: Prospect, are expressing concern about where

Speaker: NA
Text: the flight paths from Badgerys Creek might

Speaker: NA
Text: go. It is not a simple matter of transferring

Speaker: NA
Text: the aircraft noise out west to overcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in the inner city. One of the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: for Macarthur, which includes rural and semi-

Speaker: NA
Text: rural areas, is that there is much less back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground noise than there is in the inner sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: urbs of Sydney, so the impact of any aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: noise will be much greater on residents in

Speaker: NA
Text: these areas than otherwise would be the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: All governments make mistakes and if

Speaker: NA
Text: governments remain in office for a long

Speaker: NA
Text: period they are bound to make mistakes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe one of the greatest mistakes made by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government was in 1989 when it decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to build the third runway at Mascot rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than getting on with building a second airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having nominated Badgerys Creek as the site

Speaker: NA
Text: for the second airport in 1985, and having

Speaker: NA
Text: completed an EIS at that time, the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should have got on with the job of

Speaker: NA
Text: building the airport then.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like most Labor politicians at federal,

Speaker: NA
Text: and local government level in Sydney, I

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed the third runway at Mascot. Interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly, the coalition supported it. As we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen in this House in recent weeks, we now

Speaker: NA
Text: have the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard) and the former Premier, now Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: candidate for Macarthur, John Fahey, playing

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunist politics with the issue of airports

Speaker: NA
Text: and aircraft noise, despite their well-recorded

Speaker: NA
Text: previous positions on this issue. Clearly, one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the problems with the third runway and the

Speaker: NA
Text: resultant noise chaos is that the EIS process

Speaker: NA
Text: was less than satisfactory. Let us ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: this mistake is not repeated at Sydney West

Speaker: NA
Text: airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortly, the draft flight paths for Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: West will become known. This will hopefully

Speaker: NA
Text: clarify the situation for many residents who

Speaker: NA
Text: will find that they may not be affected at all

Speaker: NA
Text: by aircraft noise from the new airport. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: also reduce the scope for scaremongering by

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition over aircraft noise. Neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less, I urge the government to at the very

Speaker: NA
Text: least conduct a comprehensive review of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985 EIS in all relevant aspects, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft" noise, noise pollution, air pollution

Speaker: NA
Text: and water pollution, and to do that before

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of the airport commences.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent times a bill to privatise airports

Speaker: NA
Text: has been blocked in the Senate and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to hold up the construction of Badgerys

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek airport. This is unfortunate. It had been

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's plan, supported I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: by all sides of the House, to build the airport

Speaker: NA
Text: by the year 2000. Hopefully, that will still be

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, but it should not go ahead without

Speaker: NA
Text: an updated environmental impact statement

Speaker: NA
Text: which will look at various aspects such as

Speaker: NA
Text: noise. Otherwise the people of south-west

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney and people in my electorate will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be satisfied that they should have to put up

Speaker: NA
Text: with a new airport, especially given the

Speaker: NA
Text: horrendous outcome of the third runway and

Speaker: NA
Text: the noise that people are copping in Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: As bad as that is, it is not satisfactory to

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer the noise to the western suburbs-any

Speaker: NA
Text: more than it is satisfactory to do what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition suggested: that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: share the noise around.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very important issue which must

Speaker: NA
Text: state be clarified and determined as quickly as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. This is an area where a lot of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people buy their first home. They move there

Speaker: NA
Text: to get away from Sydney-to get away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the city life, aircraft noise and other things. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very important that the matter is clarified

Speaker: NA
Text: very soon. I look forward to seeing the draft

Speaker: NA
Text: flight paths at the earliest opportunity.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: Dawson) (4.50

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I bring to the attention of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: what a member referred to the 'ugly

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian' last Wednesday. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Deakin ( Mr Aldred), from a separate and

Speaker: NA
Text: independent source, came to the same conclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion as I did-that Westpac is abusing its

Speaker: NA
Text: banking licence and the legal system to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent its becoming accountable for all its

Speaker: NA
Text: deficiencies revealed in what is known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Westpac or French letters. My concern goes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the inquiry by the then House of Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives finance and public administration

Speaker: NA
Text: committee into banking and deregulation. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: first report A pocketful of change was tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House of Representatives in November

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 and its follow-up Checking the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: in October 1992. The member for Fairfax ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Somlyay) and I are the only remaining mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of that original committee still on the

Speaker: NA
Text: current banking, finance and public adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: The crux of the first report that I can recall

Speaker: NA
Text: is that some of the major banks, under their

Speaker: NA
Text: deregulated role, went deeply into foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: currency loans on behalf of clients and never

Speaker: NA
Text: had the experience or the staff to properly

Speaker: NA
Text: market and service the product. Westpac's

Speaker: NA
Text: whole litany of inexperience and then deceit

Speaker: NA
Text: was offered up by the bank's Mr Stuart

Speaker: NA
Text: Fowler in a series of letters between the bank

Speaker: NA
Text: and its lawyers, Allen Allen and Hemsley. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is on the public record that on 7 March 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: these letters were tabled at the inquiry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee indicated that it would thoroughly

Speaker: NA
Text: examine the issues raised in the letters as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as the more general matter of foreign currency

Speaker: NA
Text: loans. In fact, this became a prominent part of

Speaker: NA
Text: that inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The then Senator MCLean provided a mass

Speaker: NA
Text: of evidence to the committee in connection

Speaker: NA
Text: with not only these but also many other

Speaker: NA
Text: matters with other banks where he maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: the banks were abusing their banking licences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The then Senator MCLean called on the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee to recommend a royal commission

Speaker: NA
Text: into these abuses by the banks. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I now view subsequent and current tactics,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially by Westpac, we made the wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: decision in not insisting on a judicial inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: or a royal commission at that time. Our only

Speaker: NA
Text: Banking recommendation on the Westpac letters was

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation 61:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Attorney-General refer the so called Westpac

Speaker: NA
Text: Letters to the National Crime Authority for investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation as to whether any criminal wrong doings

Speaker: NA
Text: arise from the management of foreign exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts by Partnership Pacific Limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I understand that the letters were

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the National Crime Authority, no

Speaker: NA
Text: action was taken. These papers were not

Speaker: NA
Text: tested. The most self-incriminatory piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence given to the inquiry was not investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gated and the only reason I have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the NCA had insufficient resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. No wonder so many people hurt, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only by Westpac but also by other banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost faith in our parliamentary system,

Speaker: NA
Text: our committees and this report. I believe and

Speaker: NA
Text: now recommend that the government should

Speaker: NA
Text: set up a royal commission or a judicial in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry to inquire into the Westpac letters and

Speaker: NA
Text: other related matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now tum to a related matter which re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired litigation by former clients of the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. The committee heard evidence about

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of the settlement of cases and dispute

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution. It was obvious from evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: banks could force former clients to insolvency

Speaker: NA
Text: in legal and court costs before the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: could be properly judged by a court. This

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus of funds by the banks to engage top

Speaker: NA
Text: lawyers and expend large amounts-all tax

Speaker: NA
Text: deductible-was in contrast to the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: resources to respond with adequate funds, not

Speaker: NA
Text: tax deductible, for legal expenses by the

Speaker: NA
Text: client. This led to recommendation 60:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... that an independent mediator (or mediators),

Speaker: NA
Text: funded by the banks, but acceptable to both banks

Speaker: NA
Text: and foreign currency borrowers be appointed to

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate in foreign currency loans cases that remain

Speaker: NA
Text: in dispute. Mediation is not compulsory, banks will

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for their own mediators or for a general

Speaker: NA
Text: mediator based on usage. The detenninations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mediator will not be binding on either party. Banks

Speaker: NA
Text: should endeavour, to the extent possible, to advise

Speaker: NA
Text: all foreign currency loan borrowers of the media-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory mechanism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some banks have engaged in meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute resolution. Westpac has not. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Deakin gave a detailed summary

Speaker: NA
Text: of one such case. I have evidence of another.

Speaker: NA
Text: This case ended in Westpac bankrupting

Speaker: NA
Text: Heather and John Donkin after unsuccessfully

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavouring to have that done by the Tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation Office on its behalf and then having to

Speaker: NA
Text: do it itself to ensure that a bankrupt could not

Speaker: NA
Text: continue a case against it. In fact, the solicithe

Speaker: NA
Text: tors for AGC Advances Ltd-Messrs Clayton

Speaker: NA
Text: Utz-followed this decision up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: official receiver in Brisbane requesting the

Speaker: NA
Text: trustee to elect whether or not he wished to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue with court action and, further, to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake not to assign interest to Mr Donkin

Speaker: NA
Text: or any other person in that case. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: typical of the intimidatory actions that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bank is capable of producing. The effect on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Donkins of this and the letters in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Drambo, or Porters, case was to dissuade

Speaker: NA
Text: some of those who were representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Donkins to cease their services under the

Speaker: NA
Text: threat that costs in the eventual pursuance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the case would be sought against the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives in the event the bank won the court

Speaker: NA
Text: action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other matters, post the banking inquiry, not

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned or investigated to any extent are

Speaker: NA
Text: now coming to light in other court cases and

Speaker: NA
Text: those settled on the court steps, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Stringer v. ANZ in South Australia. These

Speaker: NA
Text: additional points include: the extent of point

Speaker: NA
Text: taking by the banks at the expense of the

Speaker: NA
Text: client-in Drambo's case, I understand this

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the claim is for $3 million or $4

Speaker: NA
Text: million; whether in fact the client actually

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowed foreign currency or whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank did itself and, upon bringing the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeds onshore, then lent to the client but

Speaker: NA
Text: charged the client for the exchange losses and

Speaker: NA
Text: took the profit of point making for itself; and

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that withholding tax should have

Speaker: NA
Text: never been deducted from clients' funds, as

Speaker: NA
Text: found in subsequent cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thankfully, I can report that AGC Advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ces intentions have apparently been thwarted

Speaker: NA
Text: by a letter I received from the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Justice ( Mr Kerr), which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to your letter of 9 October 1995 to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General in which you made representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions on behalf of your constituents, Mr CJ and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs HK Donkin, both of whom are bankrupt, in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to their proposed High Court action against

Speaker: NA
Text: AGC Advances Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: As you know, on the bankruptcy of Mr Donkin, his

Speaker: NA
Text: right to conduct the action vested in the trustee of

Speaker: NA
Text: his estate (the Official Trustee). I note that, under

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection 60(2) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Official Receiver ... has elected not to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: the action.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I understand that, so as not to frustrate

Speaker: NA
Text: Donkins' action, the Official Receiver proposes

Speaker: NA
Text: assigning the rights in it to Mr Donkin. The

Speaker: NA
Text: assignment would allow Mr Donkin to continue the

Speaker: NA
Text: action, notwithstanding that he is bankrupt.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem still remains for the Donkins,

Speaker: NA
Text: having already expended thousands of dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: in legal representation, now being bankrupted

Speaker: NA
Text: and now in view of the more recent Westpac

Speaker: NA
Text: letters threats of Feez Ruthoning: where do

Speaker: NA
Text: they go? Particularly when negligence has

Speaker: NA
Text: been found against AGC Advances in the

Speaker: NA
Text: court decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the interests of justice, legal aid should

Speaker: NA
Text: be given to provide competent representation

Speaker: NA
Text: to Donkins, Potts, Porters and others. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a need for the Treasurer ( Mr Willis) to

Speaker: NA
Text: follow through on a notice of motion that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have initiated for debate in this House, which

Speaker: NA
Text: stands on today's Notice Paper at No. 11,

Speaker: NA
Text: where I am suggesting that legal expenses be

Speaker: NA
Text: non-tax deductible to banks, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: these cases, so there can be some equality and

Speaker: NA
Text: justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have followed the case of the Donkins

Speaker: NA
Text: since it came to my notice after the inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have corresponded with the law section of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank to argue the case and have received

Speaker: NA
Text: no satisfaction whatsoever. What can you

Speaker: NA
Text: argue against a bank's representative who

Speaker: NA
Text: says, 'We have spent over $1 million on the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular Donkins' case and don't intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: lose it now,' even to the point of prosecution

Speaker: NA
Text: into bankruptcy, which was their answer?

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no doubt that the law section of

Speaker: NA
Text: Westpac act in isolation from the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank whose only instruction is, apparently, to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Westpac letters are put to rest

Speaker: NA
Text: permanently and to ensure the statute of

Speaker: NA
Text: limitations works in the bank's favour, which

Speaker: NA
Text: it currently is doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: My final observation on this whole matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is that neither the government nor the Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank is prepared to uphold its own legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: and regulations. In the Banking Act 1959

Speaker: NA
Text: under 'Interpretation', 'prudential matters', in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the bank, means, amongst other

Speaker: NA
Text: things:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) to keep itself in a sound financial position;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) not to cause or promote instability in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian financial system; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) with integrity, prudence and professional skill;

Speaker: NA
Text: The Westpac letters are evidence, as is an

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of the cases of Donkins and

Speaker: NA
Text: Potts. The recent letters of Feez Ruthoning

Speaker: NA
Text: prove that banks have no integrity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard, no prudence, and had no professional

Speaker: NA
Text: skill when foreign currency loans were first

Speaker: NA
Text: marketed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have placed questions on notice to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank to determine whether such

Speaker: NA
Text: Westpac practices should mean a review of

Speaker: NA
Text: the licence under which that bank operates

Speaker: NA
Text: with impunity from the law. In a recent letter

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer for intervention in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Donkins' case, I received an answer from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistant Treasurer ( Mr Gear) who said that

Speaker: NA
Text: he had no right of intervention because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: separation of powers. I believe the Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer is wrong. It is a matter for him, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and the Reserve Bank to conduct a

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough examination of the bank's conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: that should affect the conduct of its licence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that there should be a royal com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission or a judicial inquiry into the Westpac

Speaker: NA
Text: letters; legal aid should be made available to

Speaker: NA
Text: litigants in the cases I have mentioned;

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration should be given to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank's litigation expenses are not tax

Speaker: NA
Text: deductible; and a review should be undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: of all banking licences on the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prudential requirements of the act. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition Policies

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter Electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr FITZGmBON (Hunter) (5.00 p.m.)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: has been an interesting few days. The ACCI

Speaker: NA
Text: chief, Ian Spicer, is to quit. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, the member for Bennelong ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard), has repudiated deeply-held beliefs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Joh Bjelke-Petersen Jr has won National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-selection for the federal election. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bennelong renounced beliefs that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been close to his heart all his life. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Irish legalised divorce. And the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition discarded his beliefs and emerged

Speaker: NA
Text: a new man deeply in love with pensioners,

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and other welfare recipients.

Speaker: NA
Text: To add to the interests of the week, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals have gone into the trucking business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Liberal's trucking tours let people know

Speaker: NA
Text: that things may not be all that good now-but

Speaker: NA
Text: things are a lot better than they were when

Speaker: NA
Text: the now Leader of the Opposition was in

Speaker: NA
Text: office and unemployment, interest rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation were rampant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald was a

Speaker: NA
Text: scream. On page 40, the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition says that a coalition-in the unlikely

Speaker: NA
Text: event of them gaining government-would

Speaker: NA
Text: require Telstra to speed up its national up-

Speaker: NA
Text: grade of telephone exchanges over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: few years. However, on the previous page, his

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy lists 13 points in the coalition's eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic policy. Point number 10 says, 'Sell off

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Maybe the Deputy Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Costello), a proud protege of John Stone,

Speaker: NA
Text: should have closer dialogue with his boss.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition makes

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of admissions in the Sydney Morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Herald. He says he believes that modesty

Speaker: NA
Text: is a virtue, and confesses that he is not a big

Speaker: NA
Text: spender.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet the opposition is going around talking

Speaker: NA
Text: to interest groups, or should I say self-interest

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, and is giving a wink and a nod to

Speaker: NA
Text: every group to whom they speak, but will not

Speaker: NA
Text: spell out where the money is coming from to

Speaker: NA
Text: fund the sweeteners that they are offering. No

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder the top end of town is pleased and no

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder the pensioners and welfare recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: are terrified. Look out Medicare-smash!

Speaker: NA
Text: Look out child care-smash! Look out age

Speaker: NA
Text: care-smash! Look out equity and fairness.

Speaker: NA
Text: And look out workers. It is no wonder that

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is surging back in the opinion polls.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, enough of political debate. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: nearing Christmas, a time of peace and

Speaker: NA
Text: goodwill and I am sure people would not

Speaker: NA
Text: mind a change of pace. I know all members

Speaker: NA
Text: are most anxious to hear of the good things

Speaker: NA
Text: that are happening in the electorate of Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: where the very best wines are produced,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the people are the friendliest and where

Speaker: NA
Text: caring people cooperate to help their area

Speaker: NA
Text: prosper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Besides mines, wines and people, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter has dairy and beef cattle, wool, grains

Speaker: NA
Text: and horses. Let me teIl you a story about

Speaker: NA
Text: horses. There are many splendid thoroughbred

Speaker: NA
Text: horse studs in Scone and throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: remainder of the vaIley and these studs and

Speaker: NA
Text: horse racing are integral features of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter VaIley tourism industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The good people of Scone regard their

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful town as the horse capital of Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia, but others would have disputed their right

Speaker: NA
Text: to that title until this year. That title will

Speaker: NA
Text: be disputed after recent funding grants. Earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: this year the federal government granted $5

Speaker: NA
Text: million for a new T AFE college at Scone

Speaker: NA
Text: which will have subjects oriented to the horse

Speaker: NA
Text: breeding industry. Then the state government

Speaker: NA
Text: came along and funded $6 million for a

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful new racecourse in Scone. Then, last

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday, Minister Howe made a grant of

Speaker: NA
Text: $3.185 million for an equine research centre,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that was all federally funded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members will understand that this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: development of regional, state, national and

Speaker: NA
Text: even international significance. The state

Speaker: NA
Text: government has also provided money for the

Speaker: NA
Text: building of 400 horse stables. The courses

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be put on the curriculum at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Scone TAFE will draw students from through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out Asia and throughout the world. This will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a massive boost for the whole Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: Valley, and Australia will benefit greatly as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last Friday evening I went to a celebration

Speaker: NA
Text: dinner for the Johns brothers-Matthew and

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrew. The Johns brothers come from

Speaker: NA
Text: Cessnock, the town in which I live. Cessnock

Speaker: NA
Text: has produced three rugby league internation-

Speaker: NA
Text: als: Frank Stanmore, Dave Parkinson and Don

Speaker: NA
Text: Schofield. Because my wife, Anne, had taught

Speaker: NA
Text: both Matthew and Andrew in kindergarten,

Speaker: NA
Text: she gave a great speech and told what they

Speaker: NA
Text: were like as young lads. But she made a

Speaker: NA
Text: dreadful mistake. With about 350 people

Speaker: NA
Text: there, she admitted, she confessed, she stated

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly, that she hated rugby league. She

Speaker: NA
Text: forgot to explain it was because she had to

Speaker: NA
Text: wash my dirty washing when I played and she

Speaker: NA
Text: had to wash the dirty garments when her two

Speaker: NA
Text: sons, Mark and Joel, played. But it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: great night.

Speaker: NA
Text: While on the topic of sport, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention Kurri Kurri, which is only a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of kilometres down the road from my place.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year, in the very strong Newcastle rugby

Speaker: NA
Text: league competition, Kurri won its third

Speaker: NA
Text: straight first grade premiership-three first

Speaker: NA
Text: grade premierships, year after year. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent team and a magnificent achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for a relatively small town such as Kurri

Speaker: NA
Text: Kurri. Not surprisingly, Kurri has produced

Speaker: NA
Text: more rugby league internationals than any

Speaker: NA
Text: not other town in Australia-I think the number

Speaker: NA
Text: is 10 or II-and, rightly, those people are so

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud of their rugby league prowess.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not only excel in rugby league in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter. Steve Merrick, from the Singleton

Speaker: NA
Text: Rugby Club, represented Australia in this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's Bledisloe Cup. Singleton was premier

Speaker: NA
Text: in the very strong Newcastle competition. It

Speaker: NA
Text: won the premiership this year for the second

Speaker: NA
Text: year in a row. This year's win was more

Speaker: NA
Text: scintillating than last year's because Singleton

Speaker: NA
Text: went through the competition undefeated. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year the small town of Weston won the first,

Speaker: NA
Text: reserve and under-21 years premierships in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern New South Wales state soccer

Speaker: NA
Text: competition. Weston is the first ever club to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve this feat. These are just a few of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting achievements within my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further up the valley in small towns like

Speaker: NA
Text: Quirindi, Willow Tree, Murrurundi, Muswell-

Speaker: NA
Text: brook, Merriwa, Denman and Sandy Hollow

Speaker: NA
Text: the young people are right into their sport.

Speaker: NA
Text: What better way in which to engage them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves than to engage in sports of all kinds.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every sport imaginable is played in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter. Every week I enjoy picking up the

Speaker: NA
Text: paper and reading of some outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement by some youngster in primary

Speaker: NA
Text: school or secondary school, or by some other

Speaker: NA
Text: young person who is excelling. Last Saturday,

Speaker: NA
Text: I officially opened the swimming season at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kurri Kurri swimming pool.

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: A very important sport, too.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: It is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: sport. I must congratulate Kurri for its won-

Speaker: NA
Text: derful efforts over the years in training and

Speaker: NA
Text: presenting so many champions. In netbaIl,

Speaker: NA
Text: cricket and tennis, the Hunter is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: nursery for sporting stars.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned Singleton a while ago. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Singleton council, in cooperation with com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity groups, with all the fervour imagi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nable is pursuing funds so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a 50-metre pool-not a 25-metre

Speaker: NA
Text: heated pool, which we are fortunate enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to have here in Parliament House. If you are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to become a champion in swimming,

Speaker: NA
Text: you must have the opportunity to train in a

Speaker: NA
Text: 50-metre pool. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Bendigo) (5.10 p.m.)-I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: grieve for the more than 860,000 small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses in Australia, particularly those in

Speaker: NA
Text: the rural and regional areas, for the treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: they have received at the hands of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating federal government. A recent Yellow

Speaker: NA
Text: Pages small business survey reveals that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating federal government's policies are

Speaker: NA
Text: working against their best interests. The Small

Speaker: NA
Text: business index is the largest economic survey

Speaker: NA
Text: of small business in Australia and focuses

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically on businesses employing 19

Speaker: NA
Text: people or fewer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interviewing for this survey was conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: over the period from 24 October to 7 Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 1995, so it is current. The index used a

Speaker: NA
Text: panel of at least 1,200 randomly-selected

Speaker: NA
Text: small business proprietors, who were inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed by telephone every three months. The

Speaker: NA
Text: panel, drawn from all metropolitan and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan regions of Australia, tapped into

Speaker: NA
Text: non-metropolitan regions of Australia, which

Speaker: NA
Text: makes this quite unique.

Speaker: NA
Text: The areas of activity tapped into cover

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing; building and construction;

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale/retail; transport, storage; finance,

Speaker: NA
Text: property and business services; and recreation,

Speaker: NA
Text: personal and other services. One omission

Speaker: NA
Text: from that would be the farming sector. Small

Speaker: NA
Text: business and farmers go hand in hand. They

Speaker: NA
Text: operate as small business people. This survey

Speaker: NA
Text: involved 1,200 people in total. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan area, 910 people were surveyed;

Speaker: NA
Text: in the non-metropolitan areas, 290 people

Speaker: NA
Text: were surveyed. That gives an indication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: breadth of this survey and its findings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The attitudes in this survey to federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government policy are what makes this quite

Speaker: NA
Text: a remarkable and very active document.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reasons why proprietors of these businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: view the federal government as un supportive

Speaker: NA
Text: were also canvassed in the November 1995

Speaker: NA
Text: survey. According to the survey:

Speaker: NA
Text: Lack of incentive is the number one concem-

Speaker: NA
Text: voiced by 24% of those who find Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policies to be working against small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation issues are also high on the agenda, with

Speaker: NA
Text: many complaining about too many taxes, too high

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes or specific taxes such as sales tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know how the Keating government has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased wholesale sales tax since it came

Speaker: NA
Text: back into government in 1993. The survey

Speaker: NA
Text: continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureaucracy and a limited understanding of small

Speaker: NA
Text: business needs also figure prominently, as does

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about IR policies or unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. Grouping similar responses, reveals the

Speaker: NA
Text: following hierarchy of concerns:

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxes (33%)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureaucracy/red tape/paperwork (26%)

Speaker: NA
Text: Lack of incentives (24%)

Speaker: NA
Text: Lack of understanding/only concerned with big

Speaker: NA
Text: business (20%)

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial relations policies (18 %)

Speaker: NA
Text: · Government charges (15%)

Speaker: NA
Text: · Superannuation (13%).

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it any wonder that that attitude comes

Speaker: NA
Text: through from small business throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia? The member for Pearce ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Moylan), in debate on a matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: · . . the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) in all his

Speaker: NA
Text: arrogance-at the height of arrogance--decIared to

Speaker: NA
Text: small business, 'This is as good as it gets. What are

Speaker: NA
Text: you complaining about? If you cannot make it in

Speaker: NA
Text: this climate, go out and get yourselves a PA YE

Speaker: NA
Text: job.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it any wonder that the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: is held in very scant regard by small business

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia? It becomes even worse when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Government in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Gareth Evans), during the early part

Speaker: NA
Text: of November, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The best possible thing this government could do

Speaker: NA
Text: for small business is to create an economic environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in which small business can flourish-

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not disagree with that-

Speaker: NA
Text: a climate of sustained growth. which we are

Speaker: NA
Text: managing to do with 30f a per cent growth this

Speaker: NA
Text: year; a low inflation environment; an interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: environment that is extremely modest by any

Speaker: NA
Text: previous comparison . . . and activity because

Speaker: NA
Text: business is profitable at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: How far out of touch can Senator Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans be? He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... business is profitable at the moment-

Speaker: NA
Text: You have only to look at the Yellow Pages

Speaker: NA
Text: index and survey of 1,200 businesses through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out Australia to know that that is not correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Evans goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Business confidence is high at the moment and

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer confidence is high.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you talk to small business people, you will

Speaker: NA
Text: find that nothing could be further from the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth. Obviously, the people from Yellow

Speaker: NA
Text: Pages have been talking to small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people and have found that quite the reverse

Speaker: NA
Text: is the situation: small business people have

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely no confidence in what the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is doing. In the survey, small business

Speaker: NA
Text: people were asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Thinking about the current Federal Government-

Speaker: NA
Text: do you believe that their current economic and

Speaker: NA
Text: other policies are supportive of small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: work against small business or have no real impact

Speaker: NA
Text: either way?

Speaker: NA
Text: The overwhelming response was that the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies of the federal government worked

Speaker: NA
Text: against small business. Lack of incentives,

Speaker: NA
Text: high taxes, bureaucracy, lack of understand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, industrial relations policy, government

Speaker: NA
Text: charges and superannuation are just some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues that were mentioned, and men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned very strongly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to page 13 of the Yellow Pages

Speaker: NA
Text: index, where the following question was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: What do you think is the number one national issue

Speaker: NA
Text: that the (Federal) elected government should

Speaker: NA
Text: address?

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment rates as the highest, with 28

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Small business people recognise-as

Speaker: NA
Text: do I-that they are one of the greatest cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ators of employment opportunities. They said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the greatest concern for the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government or any future federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: would be to get on top of unemployment. On

Speaker: NA
Text: page 7 of today' s Financial Review-Monday

Speaker: NA
Text: 27 November 1995-the Australian Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commerce and Industry said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Business perceives the economy as more brittle

Speaker: NA
Text: than a year ago, with profitability slowing, accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the latest survey of its members by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: But members of the Victorian Employers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber of Commerce and Industry provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: more positive outlook in their survey. also released

Speaker: NA
Text: at the weekend.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even more businesses-45 per cent-xpect the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian economy to experience similarly im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved growth during the next 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trends in employment growth have also im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved. according to the VECCI members, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: overall recent adverse job trends in Australia that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been more marked in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Due to the strong coalition government in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria, things in that state are improving.

Speaker: NA
Text: But business in the rest of Australia perceive

Speaker: NA
Text: that the economy is more brittle than a year

Speaker: NA
Text: ago and that profitability is slowing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a travesty that the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: has created this situation for small business in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It has certainly let small business

Speaker: NA
Text: down. When help was needed during the

Speaker: NA
Text: really tough period when interest rates were

Speaker: NA
Text: escalating, the Labor government failed small

Speaker: NA
Text: business. It failed the community. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: borne out by the massive swing away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Keating government by the small business

Speaker: NA
Text: sector in Australia, which recognised that

Speaker: NA
Text: when it was in trouble no help was forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from the federal government. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher Education

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Text: Oxley) (5.20 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: This afternoon I would like to take the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to speak a little bit about higher educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion places, particularly in Queensland. Hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing lived in Queensland all of my life, I know

Speaker: NA
Text: what it was like growing up in rather tough

Speaker: NA
Text: times under a National Party government--or

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party government as they used to call

Speaker: NA
Text: it in Queensland in those days-where your

Speaker: NA
Text: chance of going on to tertiary education was

Speaker: NA
Text: almost nil. As a reasonably small boy, only

Speaker: NA
Text: two people that I can remember actually had

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to go on to university educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from the struggling backgrounds that we

Speaker: NA
Text: were raised in.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no wonder that I myself and a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: people of my generation have had going on

Speaker: NA
Text: to tertiary education as one of the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives for our children. I think we can be

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud of the efforts of this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: government, and certainly it goes back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitlam government as well. In my own

Speaker: NA
Text: family, I have seen my own sons take the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity and the advantage of that to study

Speaker: NA
Text: and to work hard to achieve things. But it has

Speaker: NA
Text: all been done through the assistance of a very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no wonder that a lot of people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland electorate over the weekend

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke to me about their concerns over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate's rejection of certain aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's budget that relate to additional

Speaker: NA
Text: university places for Queensland. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget came down in May this year, I sent

Speaker: NA
Text: out a newsletter to my electorate. I will just

Speaker: NA
Text: read some of the relevant points that I made

Speaker: NA
Text: in that newsletter. This is what I said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate on this occasion:

Speaker: NA
Text: The 1995-96 Commonwealth Budget has provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed added impetus to the push for a University

Speaker: NA
Text: Campus in Ipswich by providing $2 million in 1997

Speaker: NA
Text: to help with the cost of setting up the campus of

Speaker: NA
Text: the University of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Budget proved to be very generous

Speaker: NA
Text: to Queensland in terms of education. Of an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,850 additional higher education places nationwide

Speaker: NA
Text: being funded out of the Budget, 4,200 will go to

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. This is in addition to the 500 extra

Speaker: NA
Text: places set aside by the Government in last year's

Speaker: NA
Text: planning for the three year period of funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: After many years of lobbying by the Queensland-

Speaker: NA
Text: based Federal Parliamentarians and the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, a long-standing imbalance against

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland in the area of higher education has

Speaker: NA
Text: been addressed in this Budget, which recognises the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for increased opportunities for young people

Speaker: NA
Text: in rapidly growing areas like Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: 425 extra places will be provided for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of Queensland, with the majority of these

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be set aside for the Ipswich campus.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to focus on the Ipswich campus issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich is one of the largest provincial cities

Speaker: NA
Text: in Queensland. It is probably the only provin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial city without a university campus, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is a disgrace. It is a disgrace that previous

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments have not had the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to establish a campus in a city the size

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ipswich. I know that my predecessor

Speaker: NA
Text: worked very hard for the campus as well but

Speaker: NA
Text: could not convince the then state government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately, I have had the opportunity of

Speaker: NA
Text: being a member under a Labor state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which has worked very hard for this. I

Speaker: NA
Text: compliment the Minister for Education in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, David Hamill, for his assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: in this as well. He, I and many others have

Speaker: NA
Text: worked extremely hard to get the acknowledg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a campus to go into Ipswich. Sadly,

Speaker: NA
Text: I find out that the Senate rejecting the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: bills last week puts at risk this very aspect. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a major concern to my local community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Crawford-Shame!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LES SCOTTI notice that the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary secretary at the table, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Forde, Mary Crawford, also acknowledges

Speaker: NA
Text: that by her interjection of 'Shame!' It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: shame on the National-Liberal party opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. They should be in opposition, and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure they will be after the next election. From

Speaker: NA
Text: the way they are carrying on here, you can

Speaker: NA
Text: see that they have no commitment to Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land whatsoever. For many years the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party government in Queensland was prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to go along that same way.

Speaker: NA
Text: I compliment the Commonwealth Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment, Education and Training ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Crean), who was prepared to acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for more funding and places in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. I mentioned before, in that article that

Speaker: NA
Text: I put out after the budget, the $2 million that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been provided. However, since then

Speaker: NA
Text: another $6.5 million has been allocated for

Speaker: NA
Text: that campus in Ipswich, which shows strong

Speaker: NA
Text: support by the government and its commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the establishment of that campus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week, as soon as I heard about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate's rejection of the higher education bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: I put out a statement calling on the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: Univerland National and Liberal Party senators to

Speaker: NA
Text: cross the floor on this issue, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to if they have any commitment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Queensland whatever. I think we can

Speaker: NA
Text: prove that they have already shown that they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not have any commitment to Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the coalition members in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: should also come over and vote with us when

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation comes back for debate later in

Speaker: NA
Text: the week. I will certainly hop up and speak in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of it. It will affect not only the young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in my electorate but the young people

Speaker: NA
Text: right throughout Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: All those young people out there today-I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope they are listening to this debate this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon-who are finishing year 12 this

Speaker: NA
Text: year have a lot of concern about this, because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is going to put at risk those places in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. I can assure them, and I will take

Speaker: NA
Text: the risk of speaking on behalf of all my Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues, that we are very concerned for

Speaker: NA
Text: their welfare and are working strongly to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about the matter. Just today, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have joined forces and put out a joint press

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. I congratulate my Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues from Queensland who were pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to put their names to this joint news

Speaker: NA
Text: release, supporting the government in its push

Speaker: NA
Text: for more places in Queensland. That media

Speaker: NA
Text: release headed 'Coalition must reverse block

Speaker: NA
Text: of new uni places' states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland's Labor Senators and Members have

Speaker: NA
Text: demanded that the Federal Coalition reverse its

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to block funding for the State's 4,200

Speaker: NA
Text: university places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor MPs have warned they will hound

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition MPs and candidates all the way to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ballot box and make sure every Queensland voter

Speaker: NA
Text: knows it was the Liberal and National parties that

Speaker: NA
Text: may have stopped Queensland from getting its fair

Speaker: NA
Text: share of university places.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am certainly joining forces with my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues in pushing that line. I am a bit sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: prised that the Liberal and National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: members in my own electorate have not come

Speaker: NA
Text: out and shown their true colours on this. Or

Speaker: NA
Text: are their true colours hidden, like the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition's policies are? Quite clearly, the city

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ipswich needs a university campus. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we are all fighting for. I

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge all those Liberal and National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: members-if there are any left around Ips-

Speaker: NA
Text: wich-to come out and show their true

Speaker: NA
Text: colours on this. If they have any decency

Speaker: NA
Text: about them at all, they should take on their

Speaker: NA
Text: own party on this issue. In this press state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, we have gone on to say that we have:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... urged all school-Ieavers, parents and teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: to phone-reverse charges-Liberal and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Senators and Members today demanding they

Speaker: NA
Text: pass the Government's legislation which funds the

Speaker: NA
Text: additional places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Labor Government will reintroduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the funding Bills into the Senate later this week to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide Queensland with the first round of 1750

Speaker: NA
Text: new university places for next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Coalition blocks the funding again Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land may miss out on some of the places.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the one issue where there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: complete bi-partisan support. Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: young Queenslanders are the beneficiaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the future of our nation, they are the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of our state, and they deserve better

Speaker: NA
Text: support. It continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: Students who have put in years of hard work and

Speaker: NA
Text: study and are now awaiting their offers from

Speaker: NA
Text: universities are entitled to be outraged at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition's cheap political stunts.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is all it is. I would urge them all to call

Speaker: NA
Text: any Liberal senators and members they may

Speaker: NA
Text: know around the place. If they want to know

Speaker: NA
Text: who they are, they can certainly let my office

Speaker: NA
Text: know. I am sure that, if they let any other

Speaker: NA
Text: government members' offices know, my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues will also push very strongly to

Speaker: NA
Text: new assist in highlighting just how hopeless these

Speaker: NA
Text: people are in the coalition, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: blocking this funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call on the Australian Democrats and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Greens to also have a bit of concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, particularly when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that that funding legislation is passed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Senate. If the Liberals and Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: are not prepared to come around to it, I

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly hope that the Democrats and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Greens will. That will ensure that the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion passes the Senate next time around.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very crucial issue for the state of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland; it is a very crucial issue for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future education of our children. While I

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that I speak about it from a very selfish

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view looking at the education of my

Speaker: NA
Text: own children, I think that I reflect average

Speaker: NA
Text: Queenslanders in a lot of ways through the

Speaker: NA
Text: backgrounds that we have, particularly those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have children of tertiary age. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will support very strongly the push that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are making. I thank the House for the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to raise this issue today. I call on

Speaker: NA
Text: all Queenslanders to remind anyone in the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition that they should back away from this

Speaker: NA
Text: and support new university places for Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Rocher)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! It being 5.30 p.m., in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the resolution agreed to earlier, the debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: interrupted, and I put the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That grievances be noted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Text: fixed Tuesday, 28 November 1995, at 1 p.m.,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the time for the next meeting of the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, unless an alternative day or hour

Speaker: NA
Text: is fixed.

Text: progress towards democracy in Myanmar-

Text: debate;

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one further matter that a member

Speaker: NA
Text: raised with me about a foreign affairs com-

Text: mittee report. Tomorrow we may propose that

Text: member and my colleague in the opposition.

Text: Senate's amendments-

Speaker: NA

Text: section 37AA insert the following section:

Speaker: NA
Text: Employee contributions to be excluded

Speaker: NA
Text: " '37 AAA. For the purposes of this Division

Text: any reference to expenses or expenditure in

Text: relation to meal entertainment or meal enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainment benefits excludes any contribution

Text: from an employee or an associate of an em-

Text: the employer.".

Text: No.4 - Schedule 2, pages 11 to 18, omit the

Text: Schedule.

Text: item, substitute the following item:

Speaker: NA
Text: "I. Paragraph 39A(a):

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Securities Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: Perth)-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I take this opportunity to briefly

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the House about the progress of the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining current reference of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Corporations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities-the role of Australian investors in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's capital markets. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: had initially intended to report on this refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence during the current year. A substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the inquiry, however, relates to corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate governance matters, both generally and

Speaker: NA
Text: as corporate governance relates to institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: investors. Given recent events in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a number of important corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance matters still evolving. As a result,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee has resolved not to report this

Speaker: NA
Text: year but to refer committee materials relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the reference, including background materi-

Speaker: NA
Text: al, written submissions and evidence to the

Speaker: NA
Text: joint committee established in the next parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
