Text: I also take the opportunity to advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that the committee recently resolved

Speaker: NA
Text: that the issue of corporate codes of conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: by Australian corporations operating in

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas countries, such as Papua New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea, is of sufficient importance for the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee secretariat to now commence

Speaker: NA
Text: background research. Background research

Speaker: NA
Text: will include: how Australian corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: operating overseas treat their employees in

Speaker: NA
Text: those countries; whether Australian corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions operating overseas adhere satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: to internationally accepted standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace safety and health; what practices

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian corporations adopt for the protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the environment and human rights;

Speaker: NA
Text: how Australian corporations and industry

Speaker: NA
Text: groups are approaching the developing need

Speaker: NA
Text: for codes; and the development of codes in

Speaker: NA
Text: other jurisdictions. The committee expects

Speaker: NA
Text: that the results of the research currently under

Speaker: NA
Text: way will assist the joint committee established

Speaker: NA
Text: in the next parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity to thank the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Joint Committee on Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: and Securities and the committee secretariat

Speaker: NA
Text: for the work done this year in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing five reports for presentation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England)-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-The opposition concurs in the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations of the Chairman of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Corporations and Securities,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Perth ( Mr Stephen

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith), on both issues. The first issue con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns the proposed inquiry into institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: investors. It would seem that, given the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances surrounding developments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Coles Myer company and also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: general field of developments in superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the subject does require careful and

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate consideration. The obvious challen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ges in proceeding into this issue make it

Speaker: NA
Text: inappropriate that the inquiry is pursued at

Speaker: NA
Text: this time. All members of the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it appropriate, therefore, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: hearings into the institutional investors should

Speaker: NA
Text: be deferred. We would ask the incoming

Speaker: NA
Text: government to make a similar reference to the

Speaker: NA
Text: successor of this committee in the next parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the matter of the behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: of corporations in surrounding countries, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a belief that it is appropriate-not just in

Speaker: NA
Text: the field of industrial laws but in corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance generally-that there are matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that need to be addressed. They are issues

Speaker: NA
Text: which enable the committee secretariat to

Speaker: NA
Text: collate information which can then be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered and, if necessary, reported on again-

Speaker: NA
Text: probably in the next parliament. For that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason the members of the coalition support

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement made by the chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. We believe that both issues allow

Speaker: NA
Text: some proper and considered investigations in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 34th parliament rather than in this parliaNew

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I therefore support the statement made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honourable member for Perth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Native Title and the Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander Land Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr QUICK
Text: Franklin)-On behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Committee on Native Title and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund I present the third report of the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee entitled Committee exchange with New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand-August 1995.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr QUICK
Text: by leave-I appreciate this

Speaker: NA
Text: brief opportunity to speak on the report. Four

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the parliamentary Joint Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander Land Fund visited New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand in August this year at the invitation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Speaker of the New Zealand House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives and as part of the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange program between our two countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: As 1995 is the Maori language year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, the Hon. Peter Tapsell, indicated that

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous land rights would be an appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate topic for an exchange by our committee

Speaker: NA
Text: when we visited New Zealand. The commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee's report is a great little report on the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's deliberations and its fact-finding

Speaker: NA
Text: tour of the North Island of New Zealand, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is well worth reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee members spent a very busy

Speaker: NA
Text: 3Y2 days in the North Island almost totally

Speaker: NA
Text: immersed in all aspects of Maori culture. The

Speaker: NA
Text: visit provided us with an unprecedented

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to meet everybody involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: Maori affairs-be they responsible govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ministers, parliamentary backbenchers,

Speaker: NA
Text: local Maori women in health centres, opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors of Maori FM radio stations, the Maori

Speaker: NA
Text: Queen, young Maori activists or teachers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Maori immersion schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only were we rapidly brought up to

Speaker: NA
Text: speed with the historical background of Maori

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs but we were soon involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: current and ongoing machinations revolving

Speaker: NA
Text: around Maori land claims resulting from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand government's $1 billion fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: envelope offer-an offer that was made in an

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to settle the whole issue of Maori

Speaker: NA
Text: land claims once and for all.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were fortunate to spend the early part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the trip in the lands of the Waikato-Tainui

Speaker: NA
Text: tribe, who were finalising the details of a

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement with the government. The redress

Speaker: NA
Text: value of the settlement to the Tainui people

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the value of $NZ170 million, with in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of 29,000 acres of settlement land and

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional 8,000-odd acres of improved

Speaker: NA
Text: land being transferred together with some

Speaker: NA
Text: $NZ60 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well as seeing the practical side to the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole issue of land rights, we were fortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: to be taken through the gamut of New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land native title. The Treaty of Waitangi, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Maori Land Court, the Waitangi Tribunal, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Office of Treaty Settlements, the Maori

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisheries Act, the Maori Language Act and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Maori Affairs Committee were all ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained to us in great detail as we were taken

Speaker: NA
Text: theoretically and practically through the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of land tenure in New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: since white settlement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Comparisons between what was happening

Speaker: NA
Text: in our two countries were constantly made as

Speaker: NA
Text: we sought to elicit answers from each other

Speaker: NA
Text: in the expectation that we could all benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: from each other's experiences on this native

Speaker: NA
Text: title issue. These discussions proved to be

Speaker: NA
Text: very beneficial not only to our committee

Speaker: NA
Text: members but to the people we met and had

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with in New Zealand.

Speaker: NA
Text: To those people in New Zealand and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who are interested in the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of native title, this slim but very valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able report makes very interesting reading-as

Speaker: NA
Text: I stated at the outset-as it details a very

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive outline of what is happening

Speaker: NA
Text: with native title in New Zealand. Finally, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to express my thanks to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee members who accompanied me to New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand--especially Senator Chris Evans, the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair of the committee-and to the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: secretariat, especially Peter Grundy, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance they provided to members and

Speaker: NA
Text: senators during the trip and later for compil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this wonderful report. I thank the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIA TION BILL (No.3) 1995-96

Speaker: NA
Text: Cognate bills:

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIA TION BILL (No.4) 1995-96

Speaker: NA
Text: APPROPRIA TION (PARLIAMENTARY

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1995-96

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 22 November, on

Speaker: NA
Text: motion by Ms Crawford:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Text: Corio) (5.44 p.m.)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: gives me great pleasure to rise in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and speak on the debate of these appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation bills. The function of government is to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise revenue and appropriate it to competing

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. That is what the process of politics

Speaker: NA
Text: is all about. Lobby groups, individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses come to Canberra to lobby mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers and the government for those particular

Speaker: NA
Text: allocations. All of those people make particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar claims on the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra is indeed the clearing house for

Speaker: NA
Text: those various demands and pressures within

Speaker: NA
Text: the political process. Recently we had a good

Speaker: NA
Text: example of this, with a delegation from

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong visiting Canberra to lobby on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the city and region of Geelong, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: represent in this parliament. That Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation consisted of Councillor Gerry

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith, the Mayor of the city of Geelong, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of the Trades Hall Council, John

Speaker: NA
Text: Kranz, and Cathy Roth, the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong Chamber of Commerce, representing

Speaker: NA
Text: employers. They were accompanied by two

Speaker: NA
Text: officials, Michael Malouf and Neil Savery.

Speaker: NA
Text: The delegation was very well received by

Speaker: NA
Text: senior ministers. I use this opportunity on

Speaker: NA
Text: floor of the House to thank those ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: their generosity in consenting to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation. The delegation was put together

Speaker: NA
Text: in a difficult period. We have recently come

Speaker: NA
Text: through some serious floods in Geelong. The

Speaker: NA
Text: officers were working around the clock

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with matters relating to the floods and

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing the documentation for the delega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's visit, which had been arranged some

Speaker: NA
Text: time ahead of the floods. It was a magnificent

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. I pay tribute to the staff: Michael

Speaker: NA
Text: Malouf, the CEO of the city of greater Gee-

Speaker: NA
Text: long, Neville MCPherson, Neil Savery and

Speaker: NA
Text: Richard Walker and all those other people

Speaker: NA
Text: who contributed to the fine documentation

Speaker: NA
Text: that the city was able to present to senior

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers. The community owes them a debt

Speaker: NA
Text: of gratitude. I have had one minister request

Speaker: NA
Text: five copies of the presentation that we made

Speaker: NA
Text: to ministers. He wants to take it back to his

Speaker: NA
Text: own electorate and show his municipalities.

Speaker: NA
Text: That documentation was professionally done

Speaker: NA
Text: and the information was professionally pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented to ministers by the delegation.

Speaker: NA
Text: An important feature of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: recent budgetary reallocations has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of the Building Better Cities program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently the government allocated some $247

Speaker: NA
Text: million over a six-year period to this program,

Speaker: NA
Text: $36 million for strategic studies and $200

Speaker: NA
Text: miIIion to capital grants. Those capital grants

Speaker: NA
Text: can be made to fund infrastructure investment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the form of economic gateways or to

Speaker: NA
Text: finance urban growth centres and redevelop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in areas of high urban growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The program has been particularly benefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial to Geelong. As members would know, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Building Better Cities program is organised

Speaker: NA
Text: along area strategy lines. Geelong is situated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the south-west corridor of Victoria for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of the Building Better Cities pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram. The aims of the strategy in that corridor

Speaker: NA
Text: are to support the growth of areas around

Speaker: NA
Text: Werribee in that corridor and to revitalise the

Speaker: NA
Text: central area of Geelong and its foreshore.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been some major achievements of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Building Better Cities strategy in the

Speaker: NA
Text: south-west corridor. The completion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Food and Research Institute in

Speaker: NA
Text: Werribee and the completion of physical

Speaker: NA
Text: the infrastructure works around the institute and

Speaker: NA
Text: for the technology precinct have been important

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements. We have seen also the upgrad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of the Melbourne-Werribee-Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: railway line and the completion of the Nor-

Speaker: NA
Text: lane Estate urban redevelopment in Geelong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two projects that are under way and near-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing completion are the Deakin wool stores

Speaker: NA
Text: refurbishment and the transport interchange

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Geelong foreshore. It is these two

Speaker: NA
Text: projects to which I would like to make specif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic reference here because they tie in very

Speaker: NA
Text: neatly with the strategy of the Building Better

Speaker: NA
Text: Cities program to act as catalytic develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for further investment and develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in particular areas. As far as this area

Speaker: NA
Text: of Geeiong is concerned, for many years the

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshore development along and around

Speaker: NA
Text: Corio Bay has been almost non-existent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government, in concert with the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous Cain and Kirner governments, was

Speaker: NA
Text: determined that this area could be the focus

Speaker: NA
Text: for a growth strategy and a catalytic develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the Geelong foreshore area. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed done that. The Deakin wool stores and

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport interchange areas have been the

Speaker: NA
Text: catalyst for further study and development of

Speaker: NA
Text: that foreshore area. The current state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Victoria has allocated some $20

Speaker: NA
Text: million to foreshore development and the

Speaker: NA
Text: private developments in the area are anticipat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed over a number of years to be in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million. It all started from the Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Better Cities program funded by a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government and two strategically placed

Speaker: NA
Text: developments on the Geelong foreshore.

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits of these projects have been

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial in Geelong. We have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of employment in the building

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Local firms have been involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction of these projects. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened these enterprises in an economic

Speaker: NA
Text: sense and given them some expertise in

Speaker: NA
Text: handling larger projects. Furthermore, Gee-

Speaker: NA
Text: long suppliers have benefited greatly from the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchases of local contractors who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the project. The overall benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: the Geelong community has been the regen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration of this area of the foreshore.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings me to a rather sad element of

Speaker: NA
Text: this development, and that is the criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been levelled at it in the Better

Speaker: NA
Text: Cities program by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Corangamite ( Mr MCArthur). He has attempt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed in press releases to the Geelong Advertiser

Speaker: NA
Text: and other media outlets to denigrate this

Speaker: NA
Text: program. He recently claimed in a press

Speaker: NA
Text: release that the Auditor-General ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate the Building Better Cities program

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis that the funding went to Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates. In the Geelong region it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a little tough for me to locate the Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: transport interchange over the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Barwon River in his electorate or to

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer the Deakin wool stores building over

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side of the Barwon River so we

Speaker: NA
Text: could even up the score as far as the Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Better Cities program and the funding in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular electorates were concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Building Better Cities program has

Speaker: NA
Text: been of great benefit to the workers of Gee-

Speaker: NA
Text: long and to the Geelong economy. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointed by the criticisms of the program

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been levelled by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corangamite. He needs to take

Speaker: NA
Text: himself down to those building sites and talk

Speaker: NA
Text: to the building workers whose families have

Speaker: NA
Text: benefited from the employment that the

Speaker: NA
Text: breadwinner has had on those sites and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Geelong about the great benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that have flowed from this catalytic develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the foreshore. In excess of $250

Speaker: NA
Text: million, if we can get the foreshore projects

Speaker: NA
Text: up and running, will have flowed from a

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic Commonwealth investment in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of the Geelong delegation to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I referred who were recently here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra and who lobbied the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for several projects for funding under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Building Better Cities mark 2 program,

Speaker: NA
Text: several projects have been tabled with the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. I hope that ministers give them

Speaker: NA
Text: serious consideration. We have tabled projects

Speaker: NA
Text: for funding: a geographical information

Speaker: NA
Text: system, the refurbishment of the Eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: Gardens, the Boulevard restoration project,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Whittington link project and the Corio

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay foreshore management project. All those

Speaker: NA
Text: are worth while and can stand on their own

Speaker: NA
Text: two feet as far as evaluation is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: under the programs that are already in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The base studies have already been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are not projects for funding that the

Speaker: NA
Text: city of greater Geelong or the community has

Speaker: NA
Text: dreamed up. They are concrete and real, based

Speaker: NA
Text: on some excellent studies that have been done

Speaker: NA
Text: on this area in Geelong.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wholeheartedly support the Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Better Cities 2 program and the funding that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made available for economic gate-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways and the refurbishment and regeneration

Speaker: NA
Text: of urban areas in major cities. It is a program

Speaker: NA
Text: that has delivered real and lasting benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities. It has acted as a stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: for a far greater amount of public and private

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure investment in particular areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been a strong generator of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: and a program of great community benefit. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the program to the House.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Text: Dawson) (5.55

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise on these appropriation bills to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover a few matters. As I do so, I am aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the fact that these are probably the last

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriation bills I will be speaking on. Back

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1976 I made my maiden speech when I

Speaker: NA
Text: seconded the address-in-reply on the appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation bills. I commented then on the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary behaviour in the House in 1975

Speaker: NA
Text: during the events leading up to 11 November

Speaker: NA
Text: and said that the Australian people were

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely sick and tired of the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which their elected representatives confronted

Speaker: NA
Text: issues and did not really apply themselves to

Speaker: NA
Text: the governing of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can only say that my 20 years in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament have been singularly ineffective as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as modifying that behaviour is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I go back to that time and look at the respect

Speaker: NA
Text: in which parliamentarians were then held.

Speaker: NA
Text: People recognised that the office of a politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cian had something special about it. They

Speaker: NA
Text: believed politicians. Promises were made, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they were kept.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, in 1995, what has been lost is not

Speaker: NA
Text: only that respect but also the truth. I often

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the notice of motion that the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Parkes ( Mr Cobb) put forward about

Speaker: NA
Text: truth in political advertising comes to the real

Speaker: NA
Text: nub of the difference between then and now.

Speaker: NA
Text: In spite of a whole raft of legislation that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have enacted to make elections fairer and

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians more accountable, it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to put forward that notice of mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The remarkable thing is that nothing has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done as a result of it. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a lesser standard for a politician in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to truth in marketing a product than

Speaker: NA
Text: there is for companies and enterprises outside.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a travesty of justice that has culminated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the most recent suggestion by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Human Services and Health (Dr Law-

Speaker: NA
Text: rence) that all politicians lie, so why is she

Speaker: NA
Text: being attacked just because she has been

Speaker: NA
Text: found out? Her defence in connection with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian case is a reflection on

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole lot of us and really pulls every

Speaker: NA
Text: politician in this country down to her level.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great pity that this is so 20 years

Speaker: NA
Text: down the track, even though we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom of information being used so the

Speaker: NA
Text: public and the media can see what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing and why we are being paid. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: a register of interests, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives. We have had new

Speaker: NA
Text: electoral acts that are meant to free up the

Speaker: NA
Text: system. We also have more exposure to the

Speaker: NA
Text: media so that politicians' private lives are part

Speaker: NA
Text: and parcel of the daily fight in this place. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not saying that their private lives should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be exposed, but I am saying that one

Speaker: NA
Text: person being exposed on one item makes the

Speaker: NA
Text: weight of public opinion collapse on all

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a politician representing an area of some

Speaker: NA
Text: 60,000 square kilometres, I think that one

Speaker: NA
Text: vote, one value deprives a voter, a constituent,

Speaker: NA
Text: in country and huge electorates such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie, Grey, Dawson or Kennedy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Politicians are not the ones being denied

Speaker: NA
Text: because their time and services are available

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent they can give them in 24 hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: But constituents well out of the mainstream,

Speaker: NA
Text: not in a major community or town, have to

Speaker: NA
Text: use a telephone to communicate. That means

Speaker: NA
Text: time and cost, as does sending a letter, which

Speaker: NA
Text: also means delays. They have to wait until

Speaker: NA
Text: they can come face to face with their politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cian or they have to travel to communicate

Speaker: NA
Text: with a Commonwealth department centred in

Speaker: NA
Text: Townsville, Brisbane or Sydney. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: open access to constituents who live in those

Speaker: NA
Text: areas but outback people are denied justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: One vote, one value is a false philosophy.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not matter how much is given to

Speaker: NA
Text: members by way of additional resources, they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot cope as well as those in the cities. In

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison with my 60,000 square kilo-

Speaker: NA
Text: metres, an electorate in Brisbane or Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: could be as small as 100a distance you could

Speaker: NA
Text: spit across and one you would never be out

Speaker: NA
Text: of over 12 months while representing people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been singularly unsuccessful in

Speaker: NA
Text: having parliamentary behaviour improved in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House. In fact, we are going into an era

Speaker: NA
Text: where people do not trust their politicians;

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not expect them to tell the truth; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result, there is a huge disenchantment out

Speaker: NA
Text: there such that only a compulsory vote at an

Speaker: NA
Text: election can bring them to the barriers to cast

Speaker: NA
Text: a vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will also talk about the taxation act. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: practising accountant at the time I came to

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, I was devastated to realise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax act was contained in two volumes and was

Speaker: NA
Text: quite thick. I believe that you need simplicity

Speaker: NA
Text: in taxation if you are going to expect the

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents, the taxpayers, to pay their fair

Speaker: NA
Text: amount. We have seen in this House that at

Speaker: NA
Text: the last budget that tax act grew to four or

Speaker: NA
Text: five times the size it had been. It is no clear-

Speaker: NA
Text: er; it is quite complex and it defies the efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: of a general practitioner in tax law to define

Speaker: NA
Text: every aspect of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has failed to recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not matter how simple a law might be

Speaker: NA
Text: if it is made to appear complex. I will just

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about the fringe benefits tax act. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: copied New Zealand in this respect. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is one-third the size of ours. The

Speaker: NA
Text: simple reason is that the fringe benefits tax

Speaker: NA
Text: that applies in Australia is not exactly a fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits tax; it is being used to tax other

Speaker: NA
Text: items along the way, at the businessman's

Speaker: NA
Text: expense.

Speaker: NA
Text: I often wonder how business people operate

Speaker: NA
Text: today, with a supposed knowledge of not only

Speaker: NA
Text: tax law but all the other complications and

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations imposed by state, local and federal

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. How can they find their way in

Speaker: NA
Text: this mire? My heart really goes out to those

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are trying to make a living. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are not succeeding in doing so because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: complexity of the tax act and all the other

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations we find in front of us. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: interested to read in the letters to the editor

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian this morning that, when every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body is talking about equal pay for equal

Speaker: NA
Text: work, a small business person who starts at

Speaker: NA
Text: fi ve in the morning and ends at 11 at night

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to know when they are going to be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair amount for equal work, as applies with

Speaker: NA
Text: the unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The myth about Weipa is that the argument

Speaker: NA
Text: is not about equal pay for equal work be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause, as I understand it, those people on

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts are multiskilled-they work in

Speaker: NA
Text: various jobs-and they work extra time. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: reward is the bonus arrangements they have

Speaker: NA
Text: made. As I understand it, people on the award

Speaker: NA
Text: do not work the same hours or under the

Speaker: NA
Text: same conditions. There is a need to free up

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the tax aci but also the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations system.

Speaker: NA
Text: One final comment in connection with

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation is that I do have a notice of motion,

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 11, on the Notice Paper at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very important. It refers to tax deducti-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of legal expenses. I have found a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem within my constituency and within

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian public as a whole that banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: large insurance institutions and insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: companies, knowing that they can get tax

Speaker: NA
Text: deductibility for their litigation expenses, use

Speaker: NA
Text: that advantage mercilessly on a litigant who

Speaker: NA
Text: has not the same fund of money and who

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot claim expenses as a tax deduction. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a result, there is an unequal battle in the

Speaker: NA
Text: courts. You can almost buy your form of

Speaker: NA
Text: justice by the amount of tax deductibility you

Speaker: NA
Text: can derive from it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe there should be a correction in

Speaker: NA
Text: those cases where there is an abuse of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system and where ordinary taxpayers are

Speaker: NA
Text: paying for the privilege of large financial

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions being able to blast taxpayers out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the courts, sometimes driving them into

Speaker: NA
Text: bankruptcy. I believe something should be

Speaker: NA
Text: done about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another interest of mine affects every

Speaker: NA
Text: representative in this parliament at some time

Speaker: NA
Text: or another during a year. Every so often, a

Speaker: NA
Text: major contractor will go broke and, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time, leave a raft of subcontractors,

Speaker: NA
Text: builders suppliers and employers of workers

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to collect on that debt. It has no

Speaker: NA
Text: in preference under the Bankruptcy Act. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: it gets worse than that. If a subcontractor or

Speaker: NA
Text: material supplier for a major contractor gets

Speaker: NA
Text: a payment within six months of the bankrupt-

Speaker: NA
Text: cy, they are forced to class that as a preferred

Speaker: NA
Text: payment and pay it back.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last 12 months, this has happened in

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackay on two occasions. One was an entire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly private arrangement, where the subcontrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors missed out. A comparison of the employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment record of small business and big busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness shows that the fallout is tremendous as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as unemployment is concerned. It brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to my mind once again the problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: exist. If the building industry drops dramati-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally after a period of prosperity or a boom,

Speaker: NA
Text: within two or three months you can expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: see a whole category of bankruptcies and

Speaker: NA
Text: liquidations where only the local people

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the other example is more important.

Speaker: NA
Text: A person was contracting for Q-Build, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is a state department. The client was a state

Speaker: NA
Text: department with money in hand. Obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: they did not have protection and they did not

Speaker: NA
Text: care to exercise it. When they paid the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tractor, the subbies should also have been

Speaker: NA
Text: paid. As a result, once the contract was

Speaker: NA
Text: finished, the contractor had liabilities of

Speaker: NA
Text: $327,000, for which he had assets of about

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000. As a result, all those subcontractors

Speaker: NA
Text: and suppliers of material and services also

Speaker: NA
Text: had to go to the wall. Despite this happening

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, I remember three years ago writing

Speaker: NA
Text: to the same minister in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: same department asking what protections he

Speaker: NA
Text: had put in place. He gave me a whole raft of

Speaker: NA
Text: assurances, but nothing came of it to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that it is still happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: The good news in this regard is that this

Speaker: NA
Text: year the Joint Committee on Public Works

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook to have every contract involving

Speaker: NA
Text: any Commonwealth department as a client

Speaker: NA
Text: state that subcontractors be paid a progress

Speaker: NA
Text: payment and that, unless there is evidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: that effect, no payment be made to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tractor. I am happy to say that I was given an

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance that that happens not only with

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts of $6 million or more that the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Works Committee examines but also

Speaker: NA
Text: with every other contract that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth enters into. If that is the record, pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments may be slow. If payments are made,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is great. But that has not been happening

Speaker: NA
Text: with the states.

Speaker: NA
Text: We undertook as a Public Works Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee to talk to the state public works commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tees about this matter. It would probably be

Speaker: NA
Text: of no surprise to the members here to realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that even the client, being the state, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: preferred position did not insist on those

Speaker: NA
Text: subcontractual arrangements. We also found

Speaker: NA
Text: that only one state has legislation of any type

Speaker: NA
Text: that gives some protection, and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. It was found that, in its own

Speaker: NA
Text: way, that legislation could be manoeuvred

Speaker: NA
Text: around and made ineffectual.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following our visits to the state public

Speaker: NA
Text: works committees, I undertook as a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency-there is a notice of motion on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice Paper at this stage-to see whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth could do more. I have sought

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation to try to get a preference for

Speaker: NA
Text: payments to subcontractors in the case of a

Speaker: NA
Text: liquidation or bankruptcy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am also heartened by the response of one

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation in Australia that seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: its feet on the ground as far as this is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. Bisco, which is in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: has set out to supply a formula that not only

Speaker: NA
Text: secures payments to the contractor and even-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually the subcontractor but also, before the

Speaker: NA
Text: contract is put into place, provides security

Speaker: NA
Text: for payment which involves the client, the

Speaker: NA
Text: financier and the builder. There is an insis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence that that money is in place so that a

Speaker: NA
Text: bankruptcy will not occur because of a lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of funds. It also insists that the subcontractors

Speaker: NA
Text: are looked at in detail so that they can be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid from the funds out of progress payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: These people go further than just look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the normal argument of a subcontractor

Speaker: NA
Text: beefing against a contractor or a construction

Speaker: NA
Text: person. They have looked at security for

Speaker: NA
Text: payment across the board. The architect, the

Speaker: NA
Text: supplier of material, the subcontractor and the

Speaker: NA
Text: service provider all get a say. The security of

Speaker: NA
Text: payment which flows from that says that the

Speaker: NA
Text: contractor must, on payment, pay the subcon-

Speaker: NA
Text: tractors.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dispute resolution is very much a part of it,

Speaker: NA
Text: because at this stage dispute resolution is an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute myth. It can go on for years and

Speaker: NA
Text: years. A particular report in New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: proved the fact that building costs in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: are at least two per cent more than they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be because of the bad debt factor, and

Speaker: NA
Text: almost another one per cent more because of

Speaker: NA
Text: slow payment by contractors to the subbies.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it can be put in place, this would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: marvellous way of doing something for small

Speaker: NA
Text: business in Australia. Nothing exemplifies

Speaker: NA
Text: more the small business character in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: than all those service subbies and contractors

Speaker: NA
Text: across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It came to my attention recently that an

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation in Queensland is almost hiding

Speaker: NA
Text: itself behind the name of a Commonwealth or

Speaker: NA
Text: state department. It is writing to subcontrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors and contractors to say that if they register

Speaker: NA
Text: their name with the organisation for a fee of

Speaker: NA
Text: $175 it will place them on a preferment list

Speaker: NA
Text: for state and Commonwealth contracts. You

Speaker: NA
Text: would think it was a state or Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: department imposing yet another fee. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: private organisation rendering an account for

Speaker: NA
Text: $175 by saying that registration is obligatory.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no obligation. I believe that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should see it for what it is. It is a rort. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: written to the Attorney-General in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will mention quickly the republic debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who with anti-British prejudice argue

Speaker: NA
Text: the case for a republic are doing the cause no

Speaker: NA
Text: good. Until we clear the decks of the old

Speaker: NA
Text: myths-that we do not want to be under the

Speaker: NA
Text: control of Britain any longer, that Britain has

Speaker: NA
Text: exploited us and the whole raft of argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments-we will not have a rational debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was sitting beside someone on an aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: this week. While I was not persuaded to his

Speaker: NA
Text: view, he said that until we get this Irish, anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: British bigotry out of the argument we will

Speaker: NA
Text: not go anywhere with this debate. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: people who argue against the divorcement of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia from Britain must realise that

Speaker: NA
Text: divorcement has taken place over a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: years. It is now complete. If anybody now has

Speaker: NA
Text: an argument about British involvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: their affairs, it is the European Union. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a complete transfer in Britain's

Speaker: NA
Text: preferences and influence from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth to the European Community. People

Speaker: NA
Text: who argue that should then respond by giving

Speaker: NA
Text: me an argument why we should transfer our

Speaker: NA
Text: allegiances-if that is what they are-from

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain to the United Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that over the last four or five weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: we have had in this House a debate about

Speaker: NA
Text: how the United Nations is now controlling the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of Australia and the manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: we do things. It was necessary for the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to bring in legislation to protect itself

Speaker: NA
Text: against a treaty of the United Nations about

Speaker: NA
Text: the protection of the child. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: had to react against a UN treaty in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement its own sovereignty. It is happen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in many other ways. If we have a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country, irrespective of whether we are

Speaker: NA
Text: a republic or a monarchy, how we deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem depends on the manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are beholden as a sovereign country to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations. It is only in the last 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months that the Republicans in the US have

Speaker: NA
Text: said that they want to claw back that sover-

Speaker: NA
Text: eignty and will do whatever they can to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another aspect that interests me as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: changing the constitution is concerned is the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner in which the Republicans are looking

Speaker: NA
Text: for a balanced budget. They have already

Speaker: NA
Text: brought the President back from 10 years to

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years. I believe that, if there is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a change in the Australian constitution, it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be in that direction. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Text: Herbert-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science

Speaker: NA
Text: and Technology) (6.15 p.m.)-This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent opportunity for members to talk on

Speaker: NA
Text: issues affecting their own electorates. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: case, I also wish to talk about recent develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in the portfolio of industry, science and

Speaker: NA
Text: technology. The past 13 years have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: significant reform and development in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. The Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating) and the federal government have

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the leadership to tackle the impedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to reform and development. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has also tackled the issues that

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition found too hard.

Speaker: NA
Text: In government the opposition avoided tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. As a result the manufacturing industry

Speaker: NA
Text: was inward looking, uncompetitive and bereft

Speaker: NA
Text: of investment. Under this government, manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing exports have been driving economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. I repeat: in government the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided tax reform. As a result the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: growth industry was tax avoidance while tax

Speaker: NA
Text: levels for PAYE taxpayers and company tax

Speaker: NA
Text: were inequitably high. Under this government

Speaker: NA
Text: the rorts were stopped and the tax rates

Speaker: NA
Text: lowered.

Speaker: NA
Text: In government the opposition feared en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gagement with Asia and sought comfort and

Speaker: NA
Text: help from a distant and disinterested mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: archy. This government has provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership to create APEC. More than this, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has provided the integrity to make APEC a

Speaker: NA
Text: driving force for world economic reform,

Speaker: NA
Text: much to the benefit of Australia. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong,

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Howard) would undermine the achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and potential of APEC. His refusal to

Speaker: NA
Text: see a senior Vietnamese delegation typifies

Speaker: NA
Text: his approach. He is simply not capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing leadership for APEC. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition could not understand and

Speaker: NA
Text: would fear an organisation with the flexibility

Speaker: NA
Text: to contain the People's Republic of China,

Speaker: NA
Text: Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Speaker: NA
Text: The historic agreement reached by leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: of APEC at Bogor has been enhanced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent meeting in Osaka and commended by

Speaker: NA
Text: Vice President Al Gore. The importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: this agreement to Australia cannot be overesti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated. Without the achievements of APEC,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian firms would have been isolated

Speaker: NA
Text: from huge growth and Asian markets. The

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates of this growth are staggering. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the Asian food market is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: in the MCKinsey report on Asian food markets

Speaker: NA
Text: to grow to over $900 billion by the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000. A recent report from the Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications Economics

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated at $230 billion the accumulated

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian export market over the next 15 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Asian Development Bank estimates that

Speaker: NA
Text: over the decade of the 1990s around $US50

Speaker: NA
Text: billion will be invested in new power projects

Speaker: NA
Text: by Asia-Pacific nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The APEC agreements provide significant

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for Australian industry. But

Speaker: NA
Text: industry will also face the major challenge of

Speaker: NA
Text: having to compete in a free market environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in both regional and domestic markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry needs to be at world's best

Speaker: NA
Text: practice in virtually every respect within 15

Speaker: NA
Text: years in order to cope and to thrive under

Speaker: NA
Text: these circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has directed the industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: science and technology portfolio, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the department, to take a major

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this objective. Government industry policy

Speaker: NA
Text: is not directed at intervention or protection

Speaker: NA
Text: industry; government policy is directed at

Speaker: NA
Text: fostering innovation which leads to the cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of a competitive environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive firms. Science and technology

Speaker: NA
Text: make a vital contribution to innovation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government's annual support for R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: through the portfolio has reached record

Speaker: NA
Text: levels and now stands at over $1.2 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: At a meeting of OECD science ministers in

Speaker: NA
Text: September, the significance of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's commitment to R&D stood out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is one of the few OECD nations

Speaker: NA
Text: where expenditure on R&D is significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing. Australia stands in the top rank of

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD nations for expenditure by government

Speaker: NA
Text: on R&D. In our traditional area of weakness,

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure by business on R&D, Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: making very rapid progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members are well aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive consultations on innovation by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Cook). Both industry and the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search community have responded to the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge. The innovation statement to be

Speaker: NA
Text: released by the government will further

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance Australia's capacity for innovation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition has no policies on innova-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, or for that matter on any other area of

Speaker: NA
Text: industry policy. I brought this situation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of my good friend the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Ryan ( Mr Moore) in the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) in May this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It saddens me that the member for Ryan

Speaker: NA
Text: has, for whatever reason, been unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide any evidence of his thinking in this

Speaker: NA
Text: most important area of public policy. His

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessors as industry, science and technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy spokespeople for the opposition showed

Speaker: NA
Text: a readiness to defend vested interests and a

Speaker: NA
Text: narrowness of outlook quite incompatible with

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I caution the honourable member for Ryan,

Speaker: NA
Text: my good friend: last-minute electioneering is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a substitute for considered policy making.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry, science and technology policy is the

Speaker: NA
Text: engine of economic growth. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people will not accept a party that considers

Speaker: NA
Text: industry policy to be about handouts and

Speaker: NA
Text: role in achiev- political donations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this regard, I was deeply concerned by

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate on the matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: brought on by the member for Pearce ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Moylan) last week. She confirmed my state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in May this year that popularism and

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudice are the Liberal Party's guiding

Speaker: NA
Text: principles. She appeals to popularism as her

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse and justification for having no policies

Speaker: NA
Text: in such significant areas of small business

Speaker: NA
Text: policy as 'unconscionable conduct'. The Aust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ralian people have every right to be suspi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cious of a party that considers popularism as

Speaker: NA
Text: a substitute for policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are the opposition's policies for small

Speaker: NA
Text: business? All we can go on is its track record.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Leader of the Opposition was

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, paying tax for the wealthy became

Speaker: NA
Text: an optional extra. Is the opposition promising

Speaker: NA
Text: a repeat of its 1980s policies of greed? That

Speaker: NA
Text: is its nature. I caution small business to be

Speaker: NA
Text: suspicious of false promises. They are no

Speaker: NA
Text: substitute for the sound policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that have created excellent oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities for small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the major initiatives of the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government to assist small and medium sized

Speaker: NA
Text: business has been the creation of Auslndustry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effective implementation of Auslndustry

Speaker: NA
Text: is a major priority for the federal Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Industry, Science and Technology. Au slnd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ustry is servicing the needs of firms by

Speaker: NA
Text: providing ready access to the full range of

Speaker: NA
Text: federal and state government programs. A

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector led board of Auslndustry guides

Speaker: NA
Text: these efforts. In particular, Auslndustry is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing national leadership that has provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed cohesion and quality for a plethora of state

Speaker: NA
Text: government programs. The opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: said that enterprise improvement programs

Speaker: NA
Text: such as those administered through

Speaker: NA
Text: Auslndustry would be better handled by the

Speaker: NA
Text: states.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the era of APEC and global business, the

Speaker: NA
Text: states do not have the critical mass to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: and provide world standard business improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment programs. Anything less than world

Speaker: NA
Text: quality is a waste of industry's time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Auslndustry is one of the most successful

Speaker: NA
Text: partnerships between the federal and state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments and the private sector. I call on

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Ryan to provide bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support for federal leadership in this critical

Speaker: NA
Text: area. Auslndustry has assisted more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 firms this year-4,230 firms have

Speaker: NA
Text: phoned the Auslndustry national hotline since

Speaker: NA
Text: its launch in June, 2,800 firms have received

Speaker: NA
Text: advice and assistance through Auslndustry's

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise improvement programs this year

Speaker: NA
Text: and 2,200 firms have received R&D grants

Speaker: NA
Text: for tax concessions this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Access to government programs has also

Speaker: NA
Text: been facilitated by Bizhelp, which provides

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive national information on enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prise improvement programs provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: federal, state and territory governments. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, it is doing very well in the ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Bizhelp has been widely distri-

Speaker: NA
Text: buted not only within government but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: business agents such as banks, lawyers and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountants. More than 1,600 government and

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector organisations currently sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribe to Bizhelp.

Speaker: NA
Text: The business networks program is another

Speaker: NA
Text: major new initiative of Auslndustry. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been adopted from a very successful program

Speaker: NA
Text: run in Denmark. Its aim is to help small and

Speaker: NA
Text: medium sized firms to work together in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to be internationally competitive. There are a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of examples around the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The industry innovation program is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important program of Auslndustry. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to describe for honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers just how this program is transforming

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For years agricultural production in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ord irrigation area has lacked economic

Speaker: NA
Text: scale of production. The industry innovation

Speaker: NA
Text: program enabled an innovative high intensity

Speaker: NA
Text: mini-sugar mill to be designed and built at

Speaker: NA
Text: Kununurra. This mill has enabled an econom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic sugar industry to be established at the Ord.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members who take an interest in the sugar

Speaker: NA
Text: industry will know that the first crushing is

Speaker: NA
Text: under way. I can see that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson ( Mr Braithwaite) is in the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall that when he was shadow minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: primary industries he was very keen to see a

Speaker: NA
Text: sugar industry established in the Ord, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: expect his rapt attention as I relate the success

Speaker: NA
Text: of this new federal government initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Plans are now in place to expand the area

Speaker: NA
Text: under irrigation tenfold and to realise the

Speaker: NA
Text: dreams of the pioneers of north-western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I see that the Parliamentary Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary to the Minister for the Environment,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sport and Territories, the member for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory ( Mr Snowdon), is also in

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber. The new sugar mill and the new

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of the Ord irrigation scheme will

Speaker: NA
Text: go into the Northern Territory and create a

Speaker: NA
Text: new sugar industry in that very important part

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. The value of agricultural produccompetitiveness

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will increase from about $30 million per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum prior to sugar becoming established at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ord to over $200 million per annum once

Speaker: NA
Text: the full potential of sugar is realised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The industry innovation program works

Speaker: NA
Text: because it harnesses the innovative potential

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian industry. The Ord mini-mill was

Speaker: NA
Text: the creation of the bright young Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: based engineering group Schultz, Tait, Grieg

Speaker: NA
Text: and Associates combined with the project

Speaker: NA
Text: management skills of CSR and the Ord

Speaker: NA
Text: District Cooperative, an outstanding partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 150 per cent tax concession area of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry innovation program is supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: research across a wide range of industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For example, BHP's Project M has

Speaker: NA
Text: been described by the company as the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: single R&D project in the world steel indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. This new sheet steel process is designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide BHP with the technological edge

Speaker: NA
Text: to conquer rapidly developing Asian markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: More research in BHP, CRA and elsewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: is being technology supported to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: new, high intensity iron smelting. This could

Speaker: NA
Text: transform world steel making and make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a world leader in iron and steel

Speaker: NA
Text: production and technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not only in the resources area that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian companies are backing researcl"-

Speaker: NA
Text: and development. Four out of the nine Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian companies spending more than $50

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year on R&D are in the telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications sector. Australia's deregulated

Speaker: NA
Text: and dynamic telecommunications market has

Speaker: NA
Text: established Australia as a world centre for

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications research. (Quorum

Speaker: NA
Text: formed) The call of the member for Moore for

Speaker: NA
Text: a quorum was the longest speech he has made

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber in 1995.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me continue with my important re-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks. Last financial year the combined R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of the top four telecommunica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions companies was $429 million. The

Speaker: NA
Text: companies included Telstra, Ericsson, Alcatel

Speaker: NA
Text: and Optus. Telecommunications is not only

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's fastest growing industry but the

Speaker: NA
Text: fastest growing industry in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian government is determined to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that Australia's advantages and global

Speaker: NA
Text: are recognised by internation-

Speaker: NA
Text: al companies. To this end, we are embarking

Speaker: NA
Text: on new campaigns focusing on Australia as a

Speaker: NA
Text: regional centre for service support and R&D.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is succeeding in establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: new regional headquarters and research

Speaker: NA
Text: centres in Australia through a combination of

Speaker: NA
Text: measures designed to facilitate international

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to establish in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: program provides no benefits not available to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian firms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two weeks ago I had the privilege of

Speaker: NA
Text: launching the Australian office of TMI-Tele

Speaker: NA
Text: Media International. TMI is a wholly owned

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidiary of Telecom-Italia and is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's top 10 telecommunications com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies-I think it is No.6. It has been attract-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to invest in Australia by the rapid growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's telecommunications market and

Speaker: NA
Text: by Australia's strong telecommunications skill

Speaker: NA
Text: base. This company will bring new skills to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian telecommunications industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the ability to access new markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the policies of the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Australia has become a centre for R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: for many of the world's major companies. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, BTR Nylex, ICI, Alcoa, Effem

Speaker: NA
Text: Foods, 3M, Kodak, Merck Sharp and Dohme

Speaker: NA
Text: and Hoechst all have major R&D expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This contrasts with the record under the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bennelong as Treasurer. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Bennelong was Treasurer, the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment for industrial research in Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia was so hostile that industrial laboratories

Speaker: NA
Text: closed and expenditure by industry on R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually collapsed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Has the opposition now learned the value

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people place on industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: research and its importance in promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth? Has it learned how import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant pure science is to the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy? Not if you read the media releases of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Ryan, who also

Speaker: NA
Text: claims to be the shadow minister for industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and commerce. In a release dated 4 October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995, the member for Ryan misrepresents the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's regional headquarters and R&D

Speaker: NA
Text: centres program. He refers to the program as

Speaker: NA
Text: 'a government plan to disadvantage Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industry'. This is not the only misrep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentation of the matters, but it is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: shameful. In the body of the text the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Ryan mischievously suggests that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian taxpayers are subsidising foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: multinationals and that the program puts

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian firms at a disadvantage compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with foreign firms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is back to the future of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennelong's 1954 attitudes towards policy on

Speaker: NA
Text: industry research and development. I suspect

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Ryan knows that these

Speaker: NA
Text: claims are false and that he is prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: distort sound industry policy for his own base

Speaker: NA
Text: political purposes. These remarks demonstrate

Speaker: NA
Text: a latent hostility to foreign investment by the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah) (6.35 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: One can take some of the points referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by the previous speaker, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Herbert ( Mr Lindsay), but the fact is that he

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to understand that it is companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals which innovate, not governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: When governments try to get into the busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of innovation themselves, when they try

Speaker: NA
Text: to get into the business of picking winners,

Speaker: NA
Text: they find themselves in the difficulties I am

Speaker: NA
Text: about to describe.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that much of the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: Auslndustry is fine, splendid and commend-

Speaker: NA
Text: able work. I am sure that nearly all of those

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 companies Auslndustry helped deserved

Speaker: NA
Text: the help, but the fact is that Auslndustry

Speaker: NA
Text: through a careful, rigorous process, unlike

Speaker: NA
Text: process I am about to describe, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: simply cooked up between one businessman

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) up there

Speaker: NA
Text: at the businessman's house in Red Hill.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are three problems with the show-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground deal negotiated between the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Rupert Murdoch. First, it is an

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to pick winners in an industry which

Speaker: NA
Text: is commercial quicksand. Second, it is a $32

Speaker: NA
Text: million gift to one of the world's richest, if

Speaker: NA
Text: even one of the more deserving, men. Third,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the face of it at least, it appears to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: violation of most of the rules of due process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps there is a case to be made for this

Speaker: NA
Text: deal, but if there is it should be made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government and this deal should not be snuck

Speaker: NA
Text: through, as it were, buried in a vast appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government likes to boast about its

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the free market, about its pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: business attitude. There is much to commend

Speaker: NA
Text: in all that, but the fact is that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has reduced tariffs on manufacturing industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: damaging the battlers, the small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: and the workshops involved. It ha& reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies for agriculture, damaging and

Speaker: NA
Text: hurting many of Australia's small farmers. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has practised a form of wage restraint, inflict-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on some of Australia's poorest paid

Speaker: NA
Text: workers lower real wages today than they had

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1976. It has done all of this.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has shunned the search to pick winners

Speaker: NA
Text: when picking winners might have benefited

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst off in our society, yet it is strangely

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious to pick winners when we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about a business controlled by one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's richest men. In normal commerce,

Speaker: NA
Text: this government protests its desire to avoid

Speaker: NA
Text: the old ways of doing things, yet in one

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, the media, this government practises

Speaker: NA
Text: the art of intervention at every possible

Speaker: NA
Text: opportuni ty .

Speaker: NA
Text: These movie studios that under the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's plan are going to be established at the

Speaker: NA
Text: showground are an addition to an industry

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in fact, is suffering right around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. In the US, many movie studios are in

Speaker: NA
Text: economic trouble. The great Pinewood Stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dios in England are in fact in a state of semi-

Speaker: NA
Text: went mothballs. Movieworld on the Gold Coast has

Speaker: NA
Text: the just made its first profit after seven years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the industry that the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: now supporting a new entrant to-with a $32

Speaker: NA
Text: million handout.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are told that this show ground venture is

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact going to put Australia's movie industry

Speaker: NA
Text: on the map. When you look behind it, when

Speaker: NA
Text: you look to the fine print, it turns out that

Speaker: NA
Text: only 20 per cent of the projected revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: from this venture is going to be generated by

Speaker: NA
Text: movie maki .. g. We are told by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that this venture is going to provide lots

Speaker: NA
Text: of jobs for Australia's fine young actors and

Speaker: NA
Text: actresses. Well, maybe it will, but very few of

Speaker: NA
Text: them will be acting in movies and television

Speaker: NA
Text: productions. Most of them, if they are to get

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs in this venture, will be selling tickets and

Speaker: NA
Text: drinks because this is essentially a theme

Speaker: NA
Text: park, not a movie studio.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we look at theme parks, again we see that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are struggling everywhere. Dreamworld

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Gold Coast was, I believe, recently in

Speaker: NA
Text: the hands of a receiver. Let us look at

Speaker: NA
Text: Movieworld on the Gold Coast. Not only has

Speaker: NA
Text: it only just made a profit after seven years,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it required large subsidies from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland government in the form of payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax exemptions to get going. Luna Park in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney required large subsidies from the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government to get operational and that is now

Speaker: NA
Text: in receivership.

Speaker: NA
Text: In spending what is in effect $32 million of

Speaker: NA
Text: federal taxpayers' money, this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: venturing into commercial quicksand. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a whiff of Brian Burke and his petrochem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ical plant about this. There is a whiff of John

Speaker: NA
Text: Cain and the Victorian Economic Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Corporation and Tricontinental about

Speaker: NA
Text: this. There is a hint of John Bannon and the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Bank of South Australia about this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, News Ltd is a splendid com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany-it is an international success story-but

Speaker: NA
Text: even good companies can make bad invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The point is that the Australian taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: er should not have to subsidise any commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting. The Prime Minister likes

Speaker: NA
Text: attack the donkeys and the lemmings, as he

Speaker: NA
Text: calls them, in the superannuation industry. If

Speaker: NA
Text: this investment is so stunningly brilliant, if

Speaker: NA
Text: this is such a sure thing, why is the superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation industry not investing in it? Why do

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to have the federal taxpayer giving

Speaker: NA
Text: this $32 million gift to Fox Studios? Why is

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal going to survive and prosper?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is this proposal a goer when the others

Speaker: NA
Text: have been so problematic? On the face of the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence the government has provided, it

Speaker: NA
Text: looks as though it is because it is getting a

Speaker: NA
Text: bigger subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, this is not really a movie studio.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is more a theme park. This is more a

Speaker: NA
Text: venue for showing pictures rather than making

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Did the government subsidise Hoyts to

Speaker: NA
Text: knock down the Trocadero on George Street

Speaker: NA
Text: in Sydney all those years ago? Did the

Speaker: NA
Text: government clean up that site for Hoyts? If it

Speaker: NA
Text: did not do it for Hoyts, what is the justifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for doing it now for Fox? Why should

Speaker: NA
Text: the government give Fox an advantage it did

Speaker: NA
Text: not give to Hoyts?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at all the other cinemas around

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, all the other cinemas that Fox Stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dios at the showground is going to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: competition with. Did those small business-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, or even those big businessmen, get a big

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy from the government to clean up their

Speaker: NA
Text: site and put up their theatre? Of course they

Speaker: NA
Text: didn't. What about all the battlers who cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently have jobs in those picture theatres

Speaker: NA
Text: selling popcorn, ice-cream and tickets? What

Speaker: NA
Text: about them? Did the government think of

Speaker: NA
Text: them when it handed this $32 million to Fox

Speaker: NA
Text: Studios to put a business at the showground

Speaker: NA
Text: in direct competition with them, a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to their livelihood? I suspect it did not.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not in the business of criticising

Speaker: NA
Text: Rupert Murdoch. This is not Rupert Mur-

Speaker: NA
Text: doch's fault. This is the government's fault.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rupert Murdoch is a great Australian. Rupert

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch is an Australian who has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to the world, as well as someone

Speaker: NA
Text: who now wants to bring the world to Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia. Rupert Murdoch, indeed, is a former

Speaker: NA
Text: employer of mine.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian newspaper is a credit to

Speaker: NA
Text: Rupert Murdoch's patriotism. It is a credit to

Speaker: NA
Text: to his dream of a national newspaper. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: for years the Australian newspaper was kept

Speaker: NA
Text: afloat because of the constant subventions

Speaker: NA
Text: from the rest of the News Ltd empire. Rupert

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch did not ask for $32 million to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian going. He did not ask for $7

Speaker: NA
Text: million to clean up the Holt Street site. He

Speaker: NA
Text: did all this because he realised, first, that

Speaker: NA
Text: News Ltd could make a profit in the market-

Speaker: NA
Text: place and, second, that the Australian was

Speaker: NA
Text: worth supporting out of his pocket. I wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: why he is not showing the same confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: and the same faith in the Australian film

Speaker: NA
Text: industry as he showed in the Australian print

Speaker: NA
Text: industry all those years ago by supporting it

Speaker: NA
Text: himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand the Prime Minister's desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to be on the best of possible terms with Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch. I think it is only sensible that an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Prime Minister would want to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: to Mr Murdoch, would want to have dinner

Speaker: NA
Text: with Mr Murdoch, would want to listen to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch's advice. Do all of those things, but

Speaker: NA
Text: do not give his companies $32 million worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxpayers' money. Argue for Mr Mur-

Speaker: NA
Text: doch's support, reason with Mr Murdoch, but

Speaker: NA
Text: do not try to buy it with $32 million of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' money.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is part of the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: term and ongoing fascination with the media.

Speaker: NA
Text: Back in 1981 when he was the shadow cessful

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesman, I think, for minerals and energy,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister earned a few moments

Speaker: NA
Text: notoriety by standing up at a Labor conferthis

Speaker: NA
Text: ence and saying that what the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: needed was a couple of really vicious ad

Speaker: NA
Text: to give it an advantage in its struggle with

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser government. Edna Carew, the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's biographer, has talked

Speaker: NA
Text: long love-ins with the press gallery, those

Speaker: NA
Text: long gallery crawls of years ago when he

Speaker: NA
Text: would go through the gallery repeatedly,

Speaker: NA
Text: alternately soft-soaping the journalists and

Speaker: NA
