Text: threatening them with all sorts of terrible fates

Speaker: NA
Text: if they did not say the things he liked.

Speaker: NA
Text: Max Sutch, a celebrated Australian journallet's

Speaker: NA
Text: ist, published his famous memorandum

Speaker: NA
Text: describing the then Treasurer's meeting with

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax executives in which he said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's conversation was littered

Speaker: NA
Text: with threats, with references to 'our crowd'

Speaker: NA
Text: and with favours given in return for favours

Speaker: NA
Text: received. The most blatant attempt by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister to buy himself favourable

Speaker: NA
Text: media coverage was that other infamous

Speaker: NA
Text: Kirribilli House agreement-that between

Speaker: NA
Text: Conrad Black and the Prime Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: lead-up to the 1993 election campaign when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister said to Conrad Black that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would look at increasing his shareholding

Speaker: NA
Text: in Fairfax in return for what he described

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced coverage. When asked about it later,

Speaker: NA
Text: he said, 'I, the Prime Minister, am the judge

Speaker: NA
Text: of what is balanced and being the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister gives me that right.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that Rupert Murdoch

Speaker: NA
Text: bought. Rupert Murdoch's papers will call it

Speaker: NA
Text: as they see it, regardless of any deal.

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental thing to say about this

Speaker: NA
Text: million gift to Fox Studios is that, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's point of view, it is complete-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly wasted money. In fact, it reflects no credit

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Prime Minister and it reflects no credit

Speaker: NA
Text: on our Australian way of doing business.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dangling subsidies in front of Rupert

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch is rather akin to the British Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the 1970s repeatedly dangling

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies in front of British Leyland. It makes

Speaker: NA
Text: no sense to operate that way. It makes no

Speaker: NA
Text: longsense for the government of a successful

Speaker: NA
Text: company to treat the management of a suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: country in this way. It shows on the

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the government complete contempt for

Speaker: NA
Text: of the modus operandi of the company. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: whole deal suggests that we really do

Speaker: NA
Text: have a touch of the banana republicanism in

Speaker: NA
Text: men this government, that we are not so much

Speaker: NA
Text: the different from a Third WorId nation trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: buy our way into prestige projects with a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: about those of taxpayer largesse.

Speaker: NA
Text: I entirely support government funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: the arts. The arts are a worthy and a noble

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise, one which entirely deserves sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port from all sections of society, including

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government. But let's do it directly.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we want to give $32 million to the arts,

Speaker: NA
Text: give it to them directly. Let's not try to

Speaker: NA
Text: launder the money through Fox Studios.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's suppose for a few moments that $32

Speaker: NA
Text: million should be spent to promote the film

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, notwithstanding the fact that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: already a perfectly acceptable movie studio in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at MovieworId, notwithstanding the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that these businesses have had so much

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble making a profit in recent Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: How would we know that this particular deal,

Speaker: NA
Text: this showground deal, is the best way of

Speaker: NA
Text: the utilising this $32 million? We wouldn't,

Speaker: NA
Text: because due process has not been followed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were two other expressions of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: when the state government called for expres-

Speaker: NA
Text: as sions of interest in the show ground site.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps they had better ideas. Perhaps they

Speaker: NA
Text: could have done it for less and would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have needed this $32 million subsidy. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: never know because this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: can't be short-circuited the process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last time a government in power tried

Speaker: NA
Text: The to short-circuit due process was when the

Speaker: NA
Text: $32 former New South Wales Premier Nick

Speaker: NA
Text: Greiner tried to short-circuit normal public

Speaker: NA
Text: service rules and appoint his friend, his

Speaker: NA
Text: inconvenient friend, Terry Metherell to a

Speaker: NA
Text: public service job. We know what happened

Speaker: NA
Text: then. The former Premier Nick Greiner was

Speaker: NA
Text: labelled by the Independent Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Against Corruption as 'technically corrupt'.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, I am not for a minute blaming

Speaker: NA
Text: Rupert Murdoch, but I am saying that by the

Speaker: NA
Text: same criteria that rendered Nick Greiner

Speaker: NA
Text: 'technically corrupt' this government should

Speaker: NA
Text: be judged. This government on this deal

Speaker: NA
Text: should wear the same label.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we know from the good work of Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Richard Alston, nothing like due process has

Speaker: NA
Text: been followed. I quote from an article by

Speaker: NA
Text: Alan Ramsey. Ramsey has Alston saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of the $7 million and the $25 million,

Speaker: NA
Text: could you tell us on what basis those sums were

Speaker: NA
Text: determined, and when?

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Alston was cross-examining the head

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Department of Communications and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts, Mr Stevens. The article continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: Stevens: "They were negotiated between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and the NSW Government, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: was not privy to those negotiations."

Speaker: NA
Text: Alston: "Are you able to tell us when they were

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated?"

Speaker: NA
Text: Stevens: "I cannot give you an exact date, no."

Speaker: NA
Text: Alston: "Approximate will do."

Speaker: NA
Text: Stevens: "I really cannot give you it. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: was recently."

Speaker: NA
Text: Alston: "Recently! Are you able to tell us the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis on which those amounts were agreed? Are

Speaker: NA
Text: there any formal agreements relating to them? Any

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange of correspondence?"

Speaker: NA
Text: The sad fact-sad for the taxpayers of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia-is that he could not, and there were

Speaker: NA
Text: none. As I said earlier, there are echoes of

Speaker: NA
Text: Brian Burke, John Bannon and John Cain in

Speaker: NA
Text: all this. Even coming there through the

Speaker: NA
Text: background is that old farmer's voice of Joh

Speaker: NA
Text: Bjelke-Petersen, 'Don't you worry about that.'

Speaker: NA
Text: We are entitled to worry about this. This

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament has an obligation to worry about

Speaker: NA
Text: the spending of large amounts of taxpayers'

Speaker: NA
Text: money. If this all adds up, why isn't the

Speaker: NA
Text: government prepared to debate it and put in

Speaker: NA
Text: a separate piece of legislation, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: burying this thing in a huge appropriations

Speaker: NA
Text: bill?

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard it said that Fox would have

Speaker: NA
Text: won anyway had there been an open tender

Speaker: NA
Text: process. I suspect that is right, once the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had come out and endorsed it-just

Speaker: NA
Text: as I suspect the endorsement of Solly Lew's

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring of the Coles Myer group tended

Speaker: NA
Text: to give those proposals some credibility, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you like, some power, some public recogni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that they wouldn't otherwise have.

Speaker: NA
Text: How on earth can a government expect

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone else to act openly and above board if

Speaker: NA
Text: that government itself does not do so? How

Speaker: NA
Text: on earth can the government expect other

Speaker: NA
Text: people to observe due process, to act in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the rules, if it doesn't do so

Speaker: NA
Text: itself? This' government's attitude is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: rules are for other people. As far as this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is concerned, the rules are not for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Placido Domingo of Australian politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tum briefly to another subject. The Manly-

Speaker: NA
Text: Warringah Peninsula used to have a very

Speaker: NA
Text: successful youth access centre run by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Employment Service; yet it

Speaker: NA
Text: was downgraded. Its functions and staff were

Speaker: NA
Text: transferred to the Manly branch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Employment Service. Recent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly, there has been a further downgrading so

Speaker: NA
Text: that what was once a full youth access centre

Speaker: NA
Text: is now simply one staffer dedicating a few

Speaker: NA
Text: hours a week to the special needs of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed youth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to admit that youth unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Warringah peninsula is fairly low. But

Speaker: NA
Text: one reason at least for that could be the good

Speaker: NA
Text: work formerly done by the youth access

Speaker: NA
Text: centre. The problem with this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to taking away money from a

Speaker: NA
Text: service which is doing a reasonable job is that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is penalising success, it is penalising people

Speaker: NA
Text: for their good work. The error here is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: bad policy. The real error is rank hypocrisy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just a few weeks ago, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Education and Training ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Crean) made a major announcement which

Speaker: NA
Text: was designed to win back youth votes. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the aim of this program is 'to give

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians a chance to say how

Speaker: NA
Text: effective federal employment and training

Speaker: NA
Text: programs are and how they can be improved' .

Speaker: NA
Text: In my district, the message is loud and clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployed youth are saying, 'Thanks for

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing.' They are telling this government,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Thanks for nothing. Thanks for taking away

Speaker: NA
Text: even the little you had previously given us.'

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Text: Dunkley) (6.55

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-Honourable members will recall that

Speaker: NA
Text: last week I advised the House of concerns I

Speaker: NA
Text: have regarding a decision made by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioners administering the Frankston City

Speaker: NA
Text: Council. I will now take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: detail further my concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1987, Quayside Pty Ltd was established

Speaker: NA
Text: for a joint venture development between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston City Council and Galvin Construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Group Pty Ltd. Council's contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the joint venture was the land upon which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside Shopping Centre is now built. The

Speaker: NA
Text: land was valued at $25 million and council

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired a 49 per cent equity in Quayside Pty

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd by virtue of taking up 49 ordinary fully

Speaker: NA
Text: paid $1 shares. Quayside Pty Ltd borrowed

Speaker: NA
Text: $75 million from the Commonwealth Bank to

Speaker: NA
Text: build the shopping centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1988 I expressed my concerns that

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston City Council was unwise in com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitting itself to the joint venture to the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: that it did. Since this time many constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: have also expressed a similar concern to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fundamental issue is the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: residents and ratepayers of Frankston were

Speaker: NA
Text: exposed to a multimillion dollar loss of assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: At first glance it appears that Frankston city

Speaker: NA
Text: has already lost land valued at $13 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of avenues have been exhausted

Speaker: NA
Text: in an attempt to establish the true situation

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding council's involvement in the joint

Speaker: NA
Text: venture and the extent of the financial risk to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the residents and ratepayers of Franks-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton have been exposed. A group of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned local residents, which has considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: financial expertise, has made representations

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Victorian auditor-general, the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: ombudsman and the Victorian parliament's

Speaker: NA
Text: public accounts and estimates committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, not much information has been

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by the commissioners of the city of

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Friday, 17 November this year the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioners announced that under a settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with the Commonwealth Bank the joint

Speaker: NA
Text: venture with the Galvin Construction Group

Speaker: NA
Text: is being wound up. They said that the Franks-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton City Council would therefore suffer a one-

Speaker: NA
Text: off capital loss of the land contributed as its

Speaker: NA
Text: share of the joint venture in 1988, together

Speaker: NA
Text: with some administrative and legal costs,

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing its involvement in the project to an

Speaker: NA
Text: end.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commissioners also said that they had

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to the sale of Central Park and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Young Street car park as part of the settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the ultimate need for this sale being

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to the outcome of the sale of

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside.

Speaker: NA
Text: This decision by the commissioners raises

Speaker: NA
Text: many questions. The most fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: question has to do with the commissioners'

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to place Central Park on the property

Speaker: NA
Text: market. Central Park, which was previously

Speaker: NA
Text: known as Lawrey's Paddock, was sold to the

Speaker: NA
Text: former shire of Frankston and Hastings in

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1945. It is common knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: around Frankston that the land was acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: on the condition that it be kept for public use

Speaker: NA
Text: as a park and garden. However, despite many

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts I have been unable to locate a copy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the contract of sale, which would have veri-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied its having at least 19 conditions attached

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. As I said in a previous speech, I have a

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitor's letter which mentions the 19th

Speaker: NA
Text: condition of the contract of sale of Lawrey's

Speaker: NA
Text: Paddock. What were the other 18 conditions?

Speaker: NA
Text: Were there any more conditions? We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know. The contract of sale is not there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the current chief executive

Speaker: NA
Text: officer of Frankston city concedes that even

Speaker: NA
Text: he cannot find the contract of sale document.

Speaker: NA
Text: One has to wonder at how a document pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding details of the purchase of a piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: land which in 1945 was, and in 1995 still is,

Speaker: NA
Text: the most significant piece of land in Franks-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton city can be misplaced. (Quorum formed)

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are seeing here with this calling of

Speaker: NA
Text: a quorum is the stifling of free speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly the same as happens in Nazi Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the conditions attached to the

Speaker: NA
Text: sale of Lawrey's Paddock created a burden on

Speaker: NA
Text: the land which may be enforceable in equity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have tried to get the commissioners to act

Speaker: NA
Text: and save Central Park. They have known my

Speaker: NA
Text: views for a long time. They have decided in

Speaker: NA
Text: secret and in collusion with others to sell off

Speaker: NA
Text: the land that belongs to the people of Franks-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton without once putting forward the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who gave them the right to do this? Who

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed them? Well, we all know who it

Speaker: NA
Text: was: it was Jeffrey Gibb Kennett. These

Speaker: NA
Text: people will get their $60,000 to $100,000 per

Speaker: NA
Text: year and other perks for the next year or so,

Speaker: NA
Text: sell our assets and then just walk away. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will leave a city bereft of a green Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Park, a city without a living, breathing heart.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston will become an extension of some

Speaker: NA
Text: shopping magnate's portfolio. Therefore, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe that the commissioners have the

Speaker: NA
Text: moral right nor the legal right to place this

Speaker: NA
Text: land on the property market. I do not blame

Speaker: NA
Text: the commissioners for the mess our city is in.

Speaker: NA
Text: The blame lies with the former council offic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and the people they hired for advice. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the councillors of the time should

Speaker: NA
Text: share the blame. Only two objected to the

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement of the council.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another act of incompetence occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the cultural centre. Even in Mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nopoly, a game most children play, you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot put a house on mortgaged land. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the stupidity of council officers and

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers allowed the Frankston Cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre to be built on mortgaged land. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: 10-year-old child could have told them it

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be done. I have a question. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: did the Commonwealth Bank allow them to

Speaker: NA
Text: build on mortgaged land? Was it allowed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank to be able to put more leverage on

Speaker: NA
Text: the council in relation to Quayside?

Speaker: NA
Text: The commissioners keep patting themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: on the back on their good economic manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. They claim a surplus of approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: $5 million. Central Park is worth probably $3

Speaker: NA
Text: million to $4 million top. Surely we can pay

Speaker: NA
Text: out the mortgage instead of the bank collabor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating with, apparently, the owners of Quay-

Speaker: NA
Text: side to expand a shopping empire.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also have many questions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial details regarding the settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to by the commissioners. I call upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Minister for Local Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to immediately initiate an inquiry into all

Speaker: NA
Text: matters regarding the settlement agreed to by

Speaker: NA
Text: the commissioners. I urge the minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: demand immediate answers to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. The loan facility with the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank is not due to be repaid or

Speaker: NA
Text: refinanced until 30 June 2001 and the next

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduled catch-up interest payment of $4.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million is not due until 30 June 1996. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, why have the commissioners agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the liquidation of the joint venture given that,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the due diligence report, which

Speaker: NA
Text: they themselves requested the auditor-general

Speaker: NA
Text: to conduct, Frankston city has no liability for

Speaker: NA
Text: $4.6 million catch-up payment, and money is

Speaker: NA
Text: still available in the sinking fund to service

Speaker: NA
Text: the loan facility into the new year?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why have the commissioners stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are unable to contribute further funds to

Speaker: NA
Text: the venture when Frankston City's chief

Speaker: NA
Text: executive officer has said publicly that 'evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence of council's financial strength' includes

Speaker: NA
Text: investments of $13.8 million; that the due

Speaker: NA
Text: diligence report, carried out on instruction

Speaker: NA
Text: from the commissioners, states that 'there are

Speaker: NA
Text: significant funds totalling $8.6 million avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to the city which can be redirected'; and

Speaker: NA
Text: that Frankston City'S 1995-96 budget, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leased by the commissioners, reveals that for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995-96 a gross operating surplus of $5.170

Speaker: NA
Text: million is expected following an actual gross

Speaker: NA
Text: operating surplus of $14.388 million in 1994-

Speaker: NA
Text: 95? It has the money. Why does it not just

Speaker: NA
Text: buyout the mortgage? This is the question

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be answered.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why have the commissioners agreed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of an additional $9.3 million in

Speaker: NA
Text: break costs in 1995 if this payment does not

Speaker: NA
Text: solve the problem of the $4.6 million balloon

Speaker: NA
Text: payment during 1996? Why have the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners agreed to $9.3 million being added to

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt now, thereby increasing the total debt

Speaker: NA
Text: to $93 million, when the loan is not due to be

Speaker: NA
Text: repaid or refinanced until 2001? Why have

Speaker: NA
Text: the commissioners agreed to the forced sale

Speaker: NA
Text: of Quayside when the loan facility does not

Speaker: NA
Text: terminate until 2001 and Quayside is widely

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised-including by the commission-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers-as a desirable investment?

Speaker: NA
Text: Have the commissioners sought legal advice

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the burden on the Central Park site

Speaker: NA
Text: which appears to have been created by condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions included in the contract of sale when the

Speaker: NA
Text: land was sold to Frankston? Why did Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner MCCoy not disclose that break costs

Speaker: NA
Text: of $9.3 million had been incurred on 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995, thereby increasing the total debt to $93

Speaker: NA
Text: million, when 17 days later he is reported as

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that negotiations were 'drawing to a

Speaker: NA
Text: close'?

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that the Victorian Minister for Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has stated in correspondence to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that 'at no time has it been suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: council should acquire the debts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company', and given that the effects of deed

Speaker: NA
Text: entered into by the commissioners will be for

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston City Council to underwrite the

Speaker: NA
Text: losses of Quayside Pty Ltd, has the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: properly fulfilled his obligations, or have the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioners misled him too?

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that Frankston City has no liability

Speaker: NA
Text: for the $9.3 million break costs which have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the amount owed to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank, why did the commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to the break costs? Why are the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioners entering into this deed at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when Frankston City's exposure is capped at

Speaker: NA
Text: a maximum of the land mortgaged to the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank, valued we think at $10.8 million, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General's agent reports in the due

Speaker: NA
Text: diligence report that Frankston City does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a proportional share of Quayside's

Speaker: NA
Text: liability? Our liability is the land. Why are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to pay any more?

Speaker: NA
Text: Did the previous council disclose to the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government when it donated $3

Speaker: NA
Text: million to Frankston City Council for the

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural centre that the site for the cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: centre was mortgaged to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank? I cannot recall any letters coming to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. I never saw any. You

Speaker: NA
Text: never see much from the Frankston council

Speaker: NA
Text: anyway. But would the Commonwealth have

Speaker: NA
Text: given it this $3 million if it had known the

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural centre was to be built on mortgaged

Speaker: NA
Text: land?

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that any such non-disclosure may

Speaker: NA
Text: have constituted misrepresentation, why did

Speaker: NA
Text: the commissioners specifically exclude 'legal

Speaker: NA
Text: exposure relating to potential actions' from

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms of reference when it commissioned

Speaker: NA
Text: the due diligence report? It is a bit like the

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission over in Western Australia:

Speaker: NA
Text: this due diligence report had very tight terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of reference. What is the non-monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: default which has already occurred in the

Speaker: NA
Text: joint venturers' loan?

Speaker: NA
Text: Some specific questions related to the

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rate swap terminated on 30 June 1995

Speaker: NA
Text: are: when was the swap entered into? That is,

Speaker: NA
Text: was it at the same time or soon after borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from the State or Commonwealth banks?

Speaker: NA
Text: With whom was the swap entered into? What

Speaker: NA
Text: was the purpose of the swap? What are the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic terms of the swap agreement? Why was

Speaker: NA
Text: the swap agreement terminated? On whose

Speaker: NA
Text: advice was the swap terminated? Was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration given to restructuring the swap or

Speaker: NA
Text: entering into some other transaction to

Speaker: NA
Text: minimise the losses?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us imagine what the CBD of Frankston

Speaker: NA
Text: would be like if Central Park were sold to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gandel Group. This appears to be the group

Speaker: NA
Text: which will purchase. Bayside, Quayside and

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Park shopping centres will all be

Speaker: NA
Text: linked by a tunnel of shops coordinated and

Speaker: NA
Text: controlled by one group. Those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been silly enough to go into this complex will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a contract-and I have seen one-

Speaker: NA
Text: with page after page of the smallest writing

Speaker: NA
Text: you can imagine outlining conditions like a

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of your profits going to the owners

Speaker: NA
Text: of the centre, plus annual rental increases, CPI

Speaker: NA
Text: we increases, charges for improvements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: complex-which increase the value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: assets for the owner-and all the other

Speaker: NA
Text: charges and levies for a multitude of spurious

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons.

Speaker: NA
Text: It appears to me that this exercise we are

Speaker: NA
Text: acting out at the moment is set up for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase of Quayside by Mr Gandel. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: the talk around Frankston. You can see the

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise of this entrepreneur when you

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the crossover between Bayside and

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside. He actually got the council to build

Speaker: NA
Text: the crossover to give him the shops connect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing his centre to Quayside. It should have

Speaker: NA
Text: been the reverse. It shows the utter inexperi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of those involved in negotiations on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Quayside group. Mr Gandel

Speaker: NA
Text: could buy and sell them before breakfast. The

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioners were out of their depth, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are well out of their depth right now.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I suggested some time ago was to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ a very hard-nosed financial expert

Speaker: NA
Text: who had no connection at all with Frankston

Speaker: NA
Text: or a bank and use them as an advo¢ate for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Frankston. This was not done, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it appears to me that the commissioners are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting profit first at the cost of the Frankston

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you look at the media kit that was given

Speaker: NA
Text: to us by them, you can see that the bank has

Speaker: NA
Text: control of Central Park. I am sure they would

Speaker: NA
Text: be using this as a carrot for the purchase of

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside. Recently, the commissioners have

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that we will not be made aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: details of the budget for our city. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside kit has pages blanked out with

Speaker: NA
Text: 'commercial-in-confidence' written on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: How can we check the details of this deal?

Speaker: NA
Text: (Quorum formed)

Speaker: NA
Text: Who owns Central Park or the land that

Speaker: NA
Text: Quayside was built on? It is the residents of

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankston, like me. Why should we not be

Speaker: NA
Text: informed about the selling of our asset? We

Speaker: NA
Text: collectively own it. We paid for it. It is up to

Speaker: NA
Text: us or an elected representative of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: to decide to sell it, not political appointees.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a complex issue and it needs unbiased

Speaker: NA
Text: experts to give us a true picture as to what is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call on the Victorian Minister for Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to immediately obtain the true

Speaker: NA
Text: answers to these questions, and I urge all

Speaker: NA
Text: potential bidders of Central Park to wait for

Speaker: NA
Text: the disclosure of this information. I caution

Speaker: NA
Text: them on the purchase. From the information

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been given, there is no reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Park has to be sold. Until I receive an

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation as to why, I will continue to try

Speaker: NA
Text: to save Central Park for the residents of our

Speaker: NA
Text: city. Once the park is sold, there will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: way that future generations will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a park which was the vision of Sam

Speaker: NA
Text: Lawrey and the residents of Frankston of that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CLEARY
Text: Wills) (7.15 p.m.)-Last

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday in answer to a dorothy dixer about

Speaker: NA
Text: competition policy from Milton Friedman's

Speaker: NA
Text: love child, the member for Werriwa ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Latham), the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon.

Speaker: NA
Text: George Gear-who is probably his surrogate

Speaker: NA
Text: uncle-basked in the triumph of free market

Speaker: NA
Text: policies in the ALP. All the old icons-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Commission, the Hilmer report and

Speaker: NA
Text: the national competition policy-were

Speaker: NA
Text: wheeled out by the Assistant Treasurer. All

Speaker: NA
Text: this from the same person who attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: vainly to convince us that the free market

Speaker: NA
Text: policies of the government are in no way

Speaker: NA
Text: driving the sale of public utilities. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to believe that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I bet if you asked the minister to categori-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally oppose the sale of electricity and gas

Speaker: NA
Text: down in Victoria, he would not be so gung-

Speaker: NA
Text: ho. I bet he would get the shakes if you put

Speaker: NA
Text: that question to him. Nor would the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Werriwa who, if he is not a Tory rat, is

Speaker: NA
Text: surely a closet Tory. If he has not been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the coalition in this life, he must

Speaker: NA
Text: surely have been one in another life.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Assistant Treasurer blithely endorsed

Speaker: NA
Text: competition policy, seemingly oblivious to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the Hilmer report is splitting the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour movement as much as it is driving a

Speaker: NA
Text: wedge between the Liberals and the Nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: als. The only way the ALP acolytes can

Speaker: NA
Text: defend their competition policy is by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison with the so-called economic

Speaker: NA
Text: protectionism of the former Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: leader Black Jack MCEwen. The ALP Right

Speaker: NA
Text: is forced to resurrect MCEwen because the

Speaker: NA
Text: devotion of both parties to free market poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies is so transparent that targets are getting

Speaker: NA
Text: harder to find.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just about every problem modern Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: faces is traced back to MCEwen, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: become even more sinister in Labor mythol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy than Bob Menzies. This shows how

Speaker: NA
Text: vacuous and a-historical the Modern Right's

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the world actually is. Pig-Iron Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies, whose commitment to free trade in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1930s made him a pin-up boy with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese warmongers and whose attempts to

Speaker: NA
Text: destroy the communists in the 1950s made

Speaker: NA
Text: him a hero with reactionaries, could almost

Speaker: NA
Text: get a gig in the anti-collectivist right wing of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ALP in the 1990s.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ALP's use of retrospective morality

Speaker: NA
Text: and historical amnesia to defend an essentially

Speaker: NA
Text: New Right agenda is galling and intellectually

Speaker: NA
Text: deceitful. We never see the ALP right wing

Speaker: NA
Text: devotees of globalism citing the vote on the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion to decriminalise homosexuality moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by John Gorton in 1973 as an example of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reactionary origins of the present coalition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The noes included: Katter Sr, Beazley Sr,

Speaker: NA
Text: Billy Wentworth and Keating P.J. The ayes

Speaker: NA
Text: included: Crean Sr, Jenkins Sr, Staley and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair. How about that for a weird political

Speaker: NA
Text: vote!

Speaker: NA
Text: Maybe the revisionists would like to give

Speaker: NA
Text: us a theory about the state of mind of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current Prime Minister, the modernist P.J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating, 22 years ago and what that has to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with his policies today. To ascribe the birth

Speaker: NA
Text: of protectionism to Black Jack MCEwen as if

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries did not practice and still do

Speaker: NA
Text: not practice it is plain stupid. To claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: the modem coalition is protectionist again is

Speaker: NA
Text: plain stupid. Funny about that-don't we all

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the current Prime Minister describ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Leader of the Opposition as Captain

Speaker: NA
Text: Zero prior to the 1993 general election? What

Speaker: NA
Text: a transformation there must have been.

Speaker: NA
Text: A fact which the member for Murray ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lloyd) is keen to have made public, one the

Speaker: NA
Text: revisionists on the other side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: should know, is that it was Jack MCEwen

Speaker: NA
Text: who in 1957 established a trade treaty with

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan. Given the hostility towards Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: which existed in Australia at the time, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would probably qualify as a radical decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially, it involved the Japanese removing

Speaker: NA
Text: tariffs on Australian wool and quotas on beef

Speaker: NA
Text: in return for Australia abolishing a discriminawith

Speaker: NA
Text: tory tariff on Japanese imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, it might interest the revisionists to

Speaker: NA
Text: know that it was the ALP and some in the

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL who voted against Japanese trade. Arthur

Speaker: NA
Text: Cal well went absolutely feral not long after

Speaker: NA
Text: this. It was the likes of Fred Daly, Arthur

Speaker: NA
Text: Cal well and Jim Cairns who voiced their

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition to MCEwen's 1968 Customs Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, a bill to classify industries according to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they fell into high, medium or low

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff areas. In the eyes of the Labor diehards

Speaker: NA
Text: of the time, MCEwen was beginning to act

Speaker: NA
Text: like a free trader. No matter what the right

Speaker: NA
Text: wing acolytes want to argue, everyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: house knows that Daly, Cal well and Cairns

Speaker: NA
Text: were neither stupid nor dishonourable. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were interested in the jobs of working people

Speaker: NA
Text: and, dare I say it, the economic sovereignty

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These days no-one talks about real econom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ic sovereignty and if they do fall on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question they seem to want to argue that

Speaker: NA
Text: replacing the monarchy with a republic will

Speaker: NA
Text: automaticallv bring about cultural and eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic independence. The fact that our indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries are being confiscated by foreign capital

Speaker: NA
Text: at a rate of knots is never mentioned. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: today, despite what Paul Keating says about

Speaker: NA
Text: APEC, Prime Minister Mahathir of Malaysia

Speaker: NA
Text: refuses to give unequivocal support to the

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of trade barriers, the American

Speaker: NA
Text: government continues to substantially subsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dise agricultural production and the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister admits that barriers, tariff and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff, continue to be a serious obstacle to so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called trade liberalisation. How many count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries can we cite throughout history who have

Speaker: NA
Text: removed trade barriers to their own detriment?

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly not the Asian tigers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Herbert ( Mr Lindsay),

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I know is forced to do the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's free trade bidding, must surely have

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble keeping a straight face when he tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us that the export of elaborately transformed

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactures is compensating for the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: the domestic market. The parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary knows that imports have gone-to

Speaker: NA
Text: use the Prime Minister's expression-gang-

Speaker: NA
Text: busters and the increase of exports of ETMs

Speaker: NA
Text: has been from a minuscule base. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: our approach is that it has been basically

Speaker: NA
Text: unilateral, leaving local manufacturers to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete on a playing field that is not level.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot even institute social clauses into

Speaker: NA
Text: current trading arrangements. It is all very

Speaker: NA
Text: well to condemn child labour but try to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about it and the free traders will

Speaker: NA
Text: not have a bar of it. The response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: big players such as CRA is to further deregu-

Speaker: NA
Text: late the labour market and drive down wage

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. The problem is that the deregulating of

Speaker: NA
Text: the labour market and the legitimising of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: union labour started with this government and

Speaker: NA
Text: the concept of enterprise bargaining. On this

Speaker: NA
Text: score, the ACTU has a lot to answer for.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this government is committed to pure

Speaker: NA
Text: competition, why does it protect Optus by

Speaker: NA
Text: circumscribing the charges its competitor,

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra, can levy on domestic calls? Competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ideologues-the member for Watson ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Leo MCLeay) and the member for Werriwa,

Speaker: NA
Text: to name two--cite lower international and

Speaker: NA
Text: SID calls in Australia ad nauseam as the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of competition policy. The truth

Speaker: NA
Text: is that technology, not so-called competition,

Speaker: NA
Text: is the reason for any improvement in services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kenneth Davidson in the Age of 15 April

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995 went as far as to claim that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone charges are eight per cent over the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD average and are so because of Austel' s

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to see Optus survive.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this government is so committed to pure

Speaker: NA
Text: competition, why does it allow the public

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure of Telstra-infrastructure paid

Speaker: NA
Text: for by the taxpayer-to be used by Rupert

Speaker: NA
Text: Murdoch's Foxtel virtually scot-free? The

Speaker: NA
Text: truth is that Murdoch's pay TV juggernaut-a

Speaker: NA
Text: service we do not need and one that will not

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance cultural life one iota-is going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: funded out of the public purse. Murdoch's

Speaker: NA
Text: conquest of rugby league is not the by-

Speaker: NA
Text: product of free enterprise or competition

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. It is the action of a robber baron urged

Speaker: NA
Text: on by a compliant emperor who reckons he is

Speaker: NA
Text: a republican. Well may my good friend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Werriwa say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Rupert Murdoch's aggressive move into the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian market for sport content should be marked

Speaker: NA
Text: out as a first order concern for regulators.

Speaker: NA
Text: For as his ideological mate, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications and the Arts ( Mr Lee),

Speaker: NA
Text: retorts:

Speaker: NA
Text: Given his propensity to argue for market forces

Speaker: NA
Text: competition to rein in many other areas in the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, I suspect that the allocation of codes

Speaker: NA
Text: between one media owner and another could be

Speaker: NA
Text: more difficult to implement, despite the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: motives that are, no doubt behind it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowing a Murdoch takeover of rugby league

Speaker: NA
Text: in the name of competition is one thing;

Speaker: NA
Text: allocating $32 million towards the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: building a Fox pay television empire at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney showgrounds is another. This appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priation bill allocates $32 million to the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales government, $27 million of

Speaker: NA
Text: which is for the relocation of the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Agricultural Society and $7 million of which

Speaker: NA
Text: is for infrastructure costs associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of the Fox film studios at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Showgrounds. On top of that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government will grant tax concessions to

Speaker: NA
Text: Fox of more than $7 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no wonder New South Wales Inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent MP Clover Moore described this as

Speaker: NA
Text: 'a $70 million leg-up for a billionaire

Speaker: NA
Text: cornnanv' If thi., is ;t Q'overnment which

Speaker: NA
Text: believes in competition and is dead against

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind of subsidies Jack MCEwen dished

Speaker: NA
Text: out, why is it handing over a fistful of battler

Speaker: NA
Text: money to the Murdoch empire? Why is the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, which wants to quibble about

Speaker: NA
Text: Carmen Lawrence's costs in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: witch-hunt in W A, not attacking the obscene

Speaker: NA
Text: handout to Rupert Murdoch?

Speaker: NA
Text: Only one coalition member, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Warringah ( Mr Abbott), and a former mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, the member for Curtin ( Mr Rocher),

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking on this appropriation bill have raised

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of the Murdoch subsidy. I must say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Warringah certainly was

Speaker: NA
Text: not about to badmouth his former employer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Put this subsidy in the context of the infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure needs of the communities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Labor heartlands and all the guff about

Speaker: NA
Text: support for competition and opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies becomes a joke. In a time of great

Speaker: NA
Text: need this government has refused to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: money in the heartlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: One-off local capital grants gave us a

Speaker: NA
Text: leisure centre here and there back in 1993 but

Speaker: NA
Text: swimming is no substitute for a job. These

Speaker: NA
Text: capital grants, of course, were not revived in

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent budgets. If the sort of money

Speaker: NA
Text: dished out to Murdoch was allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sydney road refurbishment or to a community

Speaker: NA
Text: music centre in Brunswick, for example, we

Speaker: NA
Text: in the northern suburbs could create serious

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs and invigorate cultural life. Does our arts

Speaker: NA
Text: aficionado Prime Minister seriously believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that a Fox studio in Sydney will enhance the

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural life of Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: And what of the jobs? Is this venture about

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs or about a Disneyland fun parlour and a

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap pay television assembly line that will

Speaker: NA
Text: do little for, if not harm, the Australian film

Speaker: NA
Text: industry? When the Murdoch owned Herald-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sun set about destroying the last Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: ALP government the Labor movement was so

Speaker: NA
Text: outraged that it attempted to mobilise a

Speaker: NA
Text: movement to boycott the Herald-Sun news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper. Haven't things changed!

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than lampooning the past by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: retrospective morality and childish empiri-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism, the revisionists should be asking why

Speaker: NA
Text: this federal government is so obsequious in its

Speaker: NA
Text: dealings with the Murdoch empire and media

Speaker: NA
Text: mop:uls in general. It is a bit of a shame that

Speaker: NA
Text: I could not ask these questions earlier in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. Maybe then the spokespersons of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Right could have filed into the chamber to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer some of the questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the ALP Right is dead against tariffs on

Speaker: NA
Text: the grounds that they are an inefficient means

Speaker: NA
Text: of allocating resources and a tax on workers,

Speaker: NA
Text: how do they justify pork-barrelling the Mur-

Speaker: NA
Text: doch empire? Only someone who rats on

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor principles could defend this blatant

Speaker: NA
Text: misuse of the taxpayers' hard-earned money.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legal bill of the Minister for Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: drop in the ocean by comparison. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard all the arguments as to why the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should not receive Commonwealth funding,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they really have the terrible ring of

Speaker: NA
Text: partisan politics about them. If we adopted the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition's position on this question, ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: would be totally vulnerable, open to all kinds

Speaker: NA
Text: of manipulation and subject to compromise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quibbling about the issue is just another

Speaker: NA
Text: example of the selective morality which

Speaker: NA
Text: dominates this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is more to the point is why John

Speaker: NA
Text: Halden was so enthusiastic about lodging the

Speaker: NA
Text: Easton petition in the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. Doesn't he sound like a really

Speaker: NA
Text: decent kind of bloke? We have all heard

Speaker: NA
Text: about Senator Baume' s predilection for

Speaker: NA
Text: personal attacks but, fair dinkum, Halden

Speaker: NA
Text: makes him look like an angel. I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne Ports ( Mr Holding)

Speaker: NA
Text: will argue that John Halden had no option

Speaker: NA
Text: and that in any case it is not necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: disassociate oneself from a petition. Everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts that this explanation misses the point.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure there is any number of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House who would have avoided lodging

Speaker: NA
Text: that petition or would have completely dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: associated themselves from the petition. John

Speaker: NA
Text: Halden was not just a willing accomplice in

Speaker: NA
Text: the production of this petition; he was an

Speaker: NA
Text: agitator and an urger. I cannot believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone would seriously argue that poor old

Speaker: NA
Text: John Halden was the ham in the sandwich.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everyone knows it was a classic piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: political payback and the sort of activity that

Speaker: NA
Text: only discredits the parliament. What is worse

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the minute one side does it the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side sanctimoniously shouts, 'Shame! shame!'

Speaker: NA
Text: When the member for Kennedy ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Katter)-who sits behind me-accused the

Speaker: NA
Text: former senator Graham Richardson of knock-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing around with the bad end of town and the

Speaker: NA
Text: like, ALP members were the first to attack his

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity. It was the same when the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Deakin ( Mr Aldred) tipped a bucket on a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of public servants. I did not fancy that

Speaker: NA
Text: either. Didn't the ALP go ballistic when that

Speaker: NA
Text: happened? But when it was one of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: using the privilege of parliament it was

Speaker: NA
Text: another matter. That is one reason why the

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for Independents will continue to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease-not because there is anything special

Speaker: NA
Text: about being an Independent, but rather that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is something unsavoury about being a

Speaker: NA
Text: tribal party hack. Being a party hack and

Speaker: NA
Text: behaving like that is not particularly global,

Speaker: NA
Text: either. We often talk about being inward look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-well, the actions of John Halden were

Speaker: NA
Text: inward looking; they were not the product of

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who was into universal ideas or who

Speaker: NA
Text: had a global view of the world. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions of someone driven by a partisan

Speaker: NA
Text: payback regime that does nothing but discred-

Speaker: NA
Text: it this parliament and other parliaments in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jenkins)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the

Speaker: NA
Text: question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Remembers Essay Competition

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Text: Mackellar) (7.30 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight it is my privilege to read to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House the essays of two young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: who won the Mackellar Australia Remembers

Speaker: NA
Text: school essay competition. They are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: gallery tonight. Their travel has been provided

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ansett. The first essay is by Cheralynne

Speaker: NA
Text: Baker, aged 13, from Narrabeen Sports High

Speaker: NA
Text: School. Her essay reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: This year, 1995, is the 50th anniversary of the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Second World War which began in 1939

Speaker: NA
Text: when Germany first invaded Poland. A lot of the

Speaker: NA
Text: war I know nothing about but what I do know is

Speaker: NA
Text: that a lot of people died fighting for world peace

Speaker: NA
Text: against power-hungry, greedy countries. People

Speaker: NA
Text: fought to protect their countries and to have world

Speaker: NA
Text: peace. It is important that Australia remembers the

Speaker: NA
Text: brave men and women who fought to save their

Speaker: NA
Text: country and to protect their country men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women. They are what I call heroes and I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of people feel the same way.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the men and women who survived that war

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want to just forget about their mates and

Speaker: NA
Text: fellow comrades who died and suffered in the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we should remember. Lest we forget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why did we fight? Some people may think they

Speaker: NA
Text: were crazy for putting their lives on the line but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that was the bravest thing a person could do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The men and women who fought must feel great

Speaker: NA
Text: pride today to walk along the street on Anzac Day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately my grandfather was killed in the war;

Speaker: NA
Text: he trod on a mine. Fifty years on, we should think

Speaker: NA
Text: of all the families that lost their husbands, fathers,

Speaker: NA
Text: grandfathers. If we did not remember these brave

Speaker: NA
Text: people it would be like forgetting their courage and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sacrifices these people made during the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, it is important to remember the past and

Speaker: NA
Text: to realise how lucky we are to have our own

Speaker: NA
Text: country, speaking our own language, living in a

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic society and enjoying the lifestyle we

Speaker: NA
Text: have today.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the reasons why Australia should

Speaker: NA
Text: remember. Lest we Forget.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second essay is by Michael Hadzic, aged

Speaker: NA
Text: 12, from the Avalon Primary School. He

Speaker: NA
Text: writes:

Speaker: NA
Text: If we did have another war there would be total

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction. Parent and grandparents would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave to fight and there is no chance for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: live. There would be no survivors, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: no food. All the animals would get diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Did you know there are enough bombs to blow

Speaker: NA
Text: up the world 3 times over? People would evaporate

Speaker: NA
Text: or even melt onto the footpath-some would die a

Speaker: NA
Text: slow painful death. Chances are you would run out

Speaker: NA
Text: of food. You would have to go out of your home

Speaker: NA
Text: to look for food because you would have very little

Speaker: NA
Text: money, if any. There would be no power or clean

Speaker: NA
Text: water.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Victorian Cross was the highest medal given

Speaker: NA
Text: to people for extreme bravery. Very few were

Speaker: NA
Text: awarded this. This list of Victoria Cross has 12

Speaker: NA
Text: names for world war 1 and 20 for world war II. All

Speaker: NA
Text: together the list comes to a total of 81 names.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the people awarded the Victoria Cross put

Speaker: NA
Text: their life on the line to save other people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously wounded or seriously hurt. How many

Speaker: NA
Text: people would do those things today?

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Remembers ... the men of the Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian Navy. They did a remarkable job taking stores,

Speaker: NA
Text: firearms, ammunition and soldiers to the war zone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those ships had to sail through waters in which

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy submarines were hiding and hunting,

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting to torpedo any of our ships unlucky enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to get near them. Also the enemy airforce was

Speaker: NA
Text: ready to strike and drop bombs on to these ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Remembers the men of the Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Force. These men had to fly their planes over

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy territory dropping their bombs on enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: positions, on the land and the ships at sea, with

Speaker: NA
Text: fighter pilots engaging them in combat and anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft guns firing on them from the ground.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also remember ... the land Army. The

Speaker: NA
Text: women who took over from the men who went to

Speaker: NA
Text: war. They watered the soil and grew the crops to

Speaker: NA
Text: feed the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We remember ... Nurses who went into action

Speaker: NA
Text: to save our sick and wounded on the battlefield.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the Second WorId War we also remember

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the bombing by Japan of Pearl Harbour. It

Speaker: NA
Text: brought the United States of America into the war

Speaker: NA
Text: and brought the war closer to Australia. In Februa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ry, 1942, Japanese aircraft bombed Darwin, killing

Speaker: NA
Text: 243 and injuring 300. Darwin also suffered another

Speaker: NA
Text: 62 air raids.

Speaker: NA
Text: We remember... when 3 Japanese military subma-

Speaker: NA
Text: rines entered Sydney Harbour and sank the ship

Speaker: NA
Text: "Cuttabul". We particularly remember our men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women who became prisoners of the Japanese and

Speaker: NA
Text: were treated terribly.

Speaker: NA
Text: We really remember. .. that wonderful day when

Speaker: NA
Text: peace was declared. Then our men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: eventually returned home to start enjoying a normal

Speaker: NA
Text: life.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no winners in war, only losers. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why Australia or any other country should not get

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in another war like World War II.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are the words of two young people,

Speaker: NA
Text: aged 12 and 13, from my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackellar. I can assure you that, with young

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women like Cheralynne and

Speaker: NA
Text: Michael, the country is in the best of hands.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett Government

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: MCEwen) (7.35 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, as you come

Speaker: NA
Text: from Victoria, you would be aware that the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissars are now running local government

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria. It is a state where you have to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a political allegiance before you can be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to a hospital board or before you

Speaker: NA
Text: can be appointed to a water board. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: before you can do almost anything in public

Speaker: NA
Text: life in Victoria you must be a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party, a member of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: or favourably known to such people-to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent now that the Kennett government has

Speaker: NA
Text: hunted out and got rid of people in the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: areas who are not friendly to the Liberal·

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. For example, in Castlemaine people of

Speaker: NA
Text: strong community involvement have been

Speaker: NA
Text: thrown off the hospital board because they

Speaker: NA
Text: were not politically correct, and Jeffrey

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennett did not like that. On the Seymour

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital board, people who did not even apply

Speaker: NA
Text: for vacancies were appointed. This is the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of thing which we now accept as common

Speaker: NA
Text: practice in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that the rights of individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: have been taken away. The constitution has

Speaker: NA
Text: been changed more often by this state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment than in any previous time in Victoria's

Speaker: NA
Text: political history. By a simple majority vote in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian parliament, the Kennett govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment removed the rights of people to access

Speaker: NA
Text: the judicial system. I want this House to think

Speaker: NA
Text: about that. There is nothing more serious than

Speaker: NA
Text: removing the rights of ordinary citizens to

Speaker: NA
Text: access the courts of our land. Yet this is

Speaker: NA
Text: common practice and is occurring more regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly than in any other state in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kennett government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other day in this House I made com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments concerning the chief commissioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. At the time I made those comments

Speaker: NA
Text: there were common stories in Victoria both in

Speaker: NA
Text: the police force and elsewhere about how Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Comrie gained employment. I had a good chat

Speaker: NA
Text: with the police commissioner today. He

Speaker: NA
Text: assured me and I accept totally that his

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment was quite above board and that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no involvement by other people in

Speaker: NA
Text: his applying for the position of chief commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner and obtaining that position. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: made the comments in this House I stated,

Speaker: NA
Text: and believe very firmly, that he is a man of

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity and of high moral character. That

Speaker: NA
Text: has been borne out further, because in my

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with the chief commissioner today

Speaker: NA
Text: he clarified a few matters with me. He also

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned that he did not sign a Kennett

Speaker: NA
Text: contract. One was put in front of him and he

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to sign it. As far as I am concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: that puts Neil Comrie way up there.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that if a chief commissioner were

Speaker: NA
Text: to sign a Kennett work contract the separation

Speaker: NA
Text: of powers would be breached. That is what is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in Victoria. Senior people sign

Speaker: NA
Text: individual work contracts and are no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: independent as statutory appointments or

Speaker: NA
Text: senior public servants. Rather, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: are on contract they are under the control and

Speaker: NA
Text: whim of Kennett ministers. I find that abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely appalling. But I am more than pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to find that our chief commissioner refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: sign such a contract. As he said, he did not do

Speaker: NA
Text: so because that would have meant a breach of

Speaker: NA
Text: the doctrine of the separation of powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: So in my view Victoria is in safe hands

Speaker: NA
Text: with our chief commissioner. He is a person

Speaker: NA
Text: who applied for the position, earnt it on his

Speaker: NA
Text: own merits and deserves that position. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, that does not take away from the disas-

Speaker: NA
Text: trous nature of what the Liberal Party and the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party are doing in Victoria to destroy

Speaker: NA
Text: the doctrine of the separation of powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Katter-It is milder than what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government is doing in Queensland.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: It is exactly what they

Speaker: NA
Text: under did in Queensland. I am pleased the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman is there because he was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the most corrupt government this

Speaker: NA
Text: country has ever seen, where the separation of

Speaker: NA
Text: powers-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Katter- Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I have personally been accused

Speaker: NA
Text: of being corrupt and I want him to withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: that statement. I have been through six sepa-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate inquiries and every single one of them

Speaker: NA
Text: found me snow white.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Jenkins)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for MCEwen might

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw the offensive remark.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: The honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man perceives that I said he was corrupt,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I did not. But if he perceives that and

Speaker: NA
Text: his hearing is bad, of course I withdraw. But

Speaker: NA
Text: I would say to him that I did not say that. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is the confusing nature of Queensland politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: No wonder the Queensland government was

Speaker: NA
Text: such a disaster, when members like the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman were ministers in that

Speaker: NA
Text: government. So we see that in Victoria that

Speaker: NA
Text: which Fitzgerald warned Australia not to do

Speaker: NA
Text: is now standard practice. That which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fitzgerald inquiry pointed out was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: way for governments to run we now see in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare Agencies: Funding

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Bendigo) (7.40 p.m.)-I raise

Speaker: NA
Text: with the House this evening the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that our welfare agencies are having

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. Fortunately the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security ( Mr Baldwin) is at the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this morning's Bendigo Advertiser the

Speaker: NA
Text: headline read, 'Funding cuts hit Salvos.' The

Speaker: NA
Text: accompanying article stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Salvation Army in Bendigo is facing a battle

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise funds to cope with a rise in demand for its

Speaker: NA
Text: services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The army's divisional commander, Major Wesley

Speaker: NA
Text: Collinson, said right across Australia, the army's

Speaker: NA
Text: units were feeling the pinch of the recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result, funding for the Bendigo region had

Speaker: NA
Text: been cut by about 10 per cent in two years ...

Speaker: NA
Text: Major Collinson said the army's Red Shield

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal raised about $30 million this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Army commanding officer, Captain David

Speaker: NA
Text: Tolputt, said it was now becoming more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to raise charity dollars in Bendigo.

Speaker: NA
Text: Captain Tolputt said a majority of Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: people had the misconception that the recession

Speaker: NA
Text: was over.

Speaker: NA
Text: The recession is not over. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security should take note of the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: I am raising. In 1992 on the Sunday program,

Speaker: NA
Text: to be exact on 6 December 1992, the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Keating) made a promise to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community. That promise was:

Speaker: NA
Text: So let me say to you, Laurie-

Speaker: NA
Text: I guess he was referring to Laurie Oakes,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunday program-

Speaker: NA
Text: that for every dollar that the voluntary agencies like there

Speaker: NA
Text: St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, the Salvation

Speaker: NA
Text: Army collect for material assistance, the Commonruption.

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth will match for the Christmas appeals.

Speaker: NA
Text: That promise has never been kept. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: Advertiser article, Captain David Tolputt

Speaker: NA
Text: further reported as saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: It seemed people now thought that charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions like the Salvation Army did not need

Speaker: NA
Text: much funds as they needed in previous years.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said people were wrong. The recession might

Speaker: NA
Text: have been over for some, but not for the thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of Bendigo people who queued for food, clothing

Speaker: NA
Text: and other services at the army's various facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in Bendigo. Captain Tolputt went on to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: recession among the poor in the Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: remained as crippling as before and their needs

Speaker: NA
Text: great.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said there was no sign of a respite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Captain Tolputt maintained the army's family

Speaker: NA
Text: support service in Bendigo had provided food and

Speaker: NA
Text: clothing to at least 3,000 people a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we have the Prime Minister of this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: making the public statement on the Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: program on 6 December 1992:

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say to you, Laurie, that for every dollar that

Speaker: NA
Text: the voluntary agencies like St Vincent de Paul ...

Speaker: NA
Text: the Salvation Army collect for material assistance,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth will match for the Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: appeals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has broken that promise,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is an absolute disgrace. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Security, who is sitting at

Speaker: NA
Text: the table, takes note of not only my comments

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight but also the comments of independent

Speaker: NA
Text: persons: a major commanding the Salvation

Speaker: NA
Text: Army and the local army commanding officer,

Speaker: NA
Text: both describing the difficulties they are

Speaker: NA
Text: having with funding for very needy people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bendigo electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor, Mr Ray

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Text: Kalgoorlie) (7.45

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-Today in question time the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Keating) made a comment

Speaker: NA
Text: which I found personally offensive in that he

Speaker: NA
Text: made snide remarks about the Burke govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I was a big critic of the Burke govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, mainly on matters of style. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe the Burke government was corrupt.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had a $30 million royal commission set

Speaker: NA
Text: of up that broke every rule of due process and

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness and that at the end of the day found

Speaker: NA
Text: was no corruption in the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: People went to gaol arising out of that cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to take up the cause of Ray O'Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nor, one time leader of the Liberal people,

Speaker: NA
Text: was who I believe was very unfairly gaoled. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was charged with receiving a cheque. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: not have time to read it all but I have here a

Speaker: NA
Text: as letter from Brian Tennant, who is a social law

Speaker: NA
Text: reform campaigner in Western Australia. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is very well known and, it is conceded, takes

Speaker: NA
Text: a very keen interest in this sort of thing and

Speaker: NA
Text: does a good job. I want to deal here with the

Speaker: NA
Text: judge's statement and his summing up. His

Speaker: NA
Text: region Honour said, with regard to cheques:

Speaker: NA
Text: as 'So there is no evidence as to the cheque. There

Speaker: NA
Text: can't be. There was no longer existing any evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence as to what the deposit slip said in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: that cheque. There is nothing on the face of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheque itself to s-y what account it went into' -it

Speaker: NA
Text: makes one wonder.

Speaker: NA
Text: His Honour goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Any lies that Mr O'Connor, if he did tell lies, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I would suggest to you that he did not . . . I would

Speaker: NA
Text: think that you should be very reluctant and slow to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to draw any inference that Mr O'Connor is

Speaker: NA
Text: guilty because he told lies ... There is no evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what happened to the National Bank cheque

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn by the Bond Corporation. We don't know

Speaker: NA
Text: positively that it was the cheque attached to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Buckley's memo. There is no evidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheque coming into Mr Connor's possession.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody said they saw the cheque handed to Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor and Mr O'Connor had denied it. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was no evidence that the cheque was banked.

Speaker: NA
Text: He goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: There was no need for Mr O'Connor to steal

Speaker: NA
Text: $25,000 to pay his income tax assessment because

Speaker: NA
Text: he made the necessary financial arrangements with

Speaker: NA
Text: his banker. There is no evidence that the cheque

Speaker: NA
Text: was banked on the 19th April and if the cheque

Speaker: NA
Text: was for a campaign account, nobody ever checked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party accounts to see if it was deposited

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: NA
Text: It goes on and on. The judge's references here

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly are saying to the jury: 'It is too dan-

Speaker: NA
Text: gerous to convict.' I would say to this House

Speaker: NA
Text: that the reason Mr O'Connor got convicted

Speaker: NA
Text: was not the evidence. The evidence should

Speaker: NA
Text: have exonerated him. He was convicted

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the feeding frenzy built up over

Speaker: NA
Text: this whole WA Inc. royal commission. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: a feeding frenzy which was prompted very

Speaker: NA
Text: much by the West Australian at the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I might just add that, while I was a critic of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Burke government on matters of style, it

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be on the record that the Burke

Speaker: NA
Text: government's financial record was very good.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was second only to the state of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason that the Labor Party in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land was able to do so well is because Bjelke-

Speaker: NA
Text: Petersen left every government instrumentality

Speaker: NA
Text: with hollow logs stuffed with money. So in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia we had enormous benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: arising from the Burke government's handling

Speaker: NA
Text: of the collapse of the stock market in time. In

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the Burke government bailing out

Speaker: NA
Text: Rothwells, it should also be remembered that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were acting on the advice of the auditor;

Speaker: NA
Text: they were acting on the advice of those

Speaker: NA
Text: to people deemed to know something about cash

Speaker: NA
Text: flow, people like Bond and Holmes a Court.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is to Senator Crichton-Browne's credit

Speaker: NA
Text: that he said to me that you would never hear

Speaker: NA
Text: a word out of him because in his view any

Speaker: NA
Text: government would have acted that way and if

Speaker: NA
Text: it happened again governments would do it all

Speaker: NA
Text: over again. He was. of course, quite right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike many other people in the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, Crichton-Browne kept his word. I could

Speaker: NA
Text: go on at length on the judge's view on this

Speaker: NA
Text: trial. I believe that Ray O'Connor deserves a

Speaker: NA
Text: new trial and, if I were Mr O'Connor, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly have it before a judge be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause juries in this emotional state cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: relied upon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Newsagents

Speaker: Mr SMYTH
Text: Canberra) (7.50 p.m.)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak on behalf of Australia's 4,500 news-

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies-4,500 businesses that employ

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 staff and contribute $3 billion worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of turnover to the national accounts. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: main, they are family businesses. Newsagen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies add to our community, to the viability of

Speaker: NA
Text: shopping centres. If you take them away, you

Speaker: NA
Text: damage those shopping centres and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses in that community. They offer

Speaker: NA
Text: community value because often the centre-

Speaker: NA
Text: piece and the character of your shopping

Speaker: NA
Text: centre is set by the tone of the news agent. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is there at the crack of dawn delivering his

Speaker: NA
Text: papers and he is there most nights when the

Speaker: NA
Text: shops are closed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Newsagencies offer significant public

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit. They do this through access to infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation at a low cost. They provide a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant range of magazines. This cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed under a different system. This

Speaker: NA
Text: system is viable because of its low cost-and

Speaker: NA
Text: it works. To change or modify it will destroy

Speaker: NA
Text: it and Australians will lose access to our news

Speaker: NA
Text: media.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current system ensures access to all the

Speaker: NA
