Text: news. If you live in Canberra, in the morning

Speaker: NA
Text: on the lawn you can have the Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: Times, Sydney Morning Herald, Telegraph

Speaker: NA
Text: Mirror, Age, Herald-Sun, Australian or

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Financial Review home delivered

Speaker: NA
Text: before 7 o'clock. It is on your lawn and you

Speaker: NA
Text: are informed. If that current system was to

Speaker: NA
Text: end, you would have to deal with three or

Speaker: NA
Text: four different delivering agencies which could

Speaker: NA
Text: not provide that sort of service for anywhere

Speaker: NA
Text: near that cost. We would end up talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: monopolies and restrictions on the access of

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians to the news.

Speaker: NA
Text: Newsagencies provide a service and they do

Speaker: NA
Text: it at great cost to themselves. The average

Speaker: NA
Text: news agent works 80, 90 or 100 hours a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am perhaps the only member of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified to speak on this because my family

Speaker: NA
Text: owned news agencies for 25 years. We deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered every day that we were charged with;

Speaker: NA
Text: and we delivered as a family business. By

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so, we built a rapport with our com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity that, dare I say it, helped me in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra by-election.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am here tonight to say that the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the continuation of the current

Speaker: NA
Text: system of distribution for newspapers and

Speaker: NA
Text: magazines with one accredited news agency

Speaker: NA
Text: for a particular territory. We believe that this

Speaker: NA
Text: system provides a significant public benefit in

Speaker: NA
Text: its provision of a low cost, effective home

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery service for daily morning news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers, as well as facilitating the widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: availability of a broad range of publications.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the main, these family businesses do this

Speaker: NA
Text: with low profit margins. Anything that dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: turbs those territories that underlie these

Speaker: NA
Text: newsagencies will disturb the whole viability

Speaker: NA
Text: of a significant sector of Australian small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. The coalition recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: successful small business enterprises such as

Speaker: NA
Text: newsagencies are the base from which our

Speaker: NA
Text: national recovery must be built.

Speaker: NA
Text: I put it to this House that we should all

Speaker: NA
Text: support the news agency system because, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the main, these ladies and gentlemen provide

Speaker: NA
Text: an honest, decent service and they do it at

Speaker: NA
Text: great personal expense in terms of the time

Speaker: NA
Text: they put in and the amount of investment they

Speaker: NA
Text: have tied up in it. Any undercutting of the

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty of the territories will destroy a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular and definite public benefit. It

Speaker: NA
Text: to this House to ensure that the Trade Prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices Commission guarantees the rights of all

Speaker: NA
Text: news agents to survive in their current form

Speaker: NA
Text: and guarantees the rights of all Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: have access to their news media.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Homelessness

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Text: Newcastle) (7.53

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)--I rise to express my anger and frustra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at the continuing habit of Senator Camp-

Speaker: NA
Text: bell of using my name, quoting me falsely

Speaker: NA
Text: and imputing false conclusions on what I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been saying in recent months around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Back in June I had the privilege of

Speaker: NA
Text: tabling a report on aspects of youth homeless-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness from the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This report is a major document and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quires detailed and complex understanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of that I wrote to the minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: requested him to delay his response as it was

Speaker: NA
Text: important for the community to read and

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to the report. Since then we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: public forums in most cities-Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane Alice Springs

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin and, last week, Newcastle. These

Speaker: NA
Text: forums have allowed people in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: to understand the report and to go to its

Speaker: NA
Text: detail. The responses coming from the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity have been quite substantial.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Campbell keeps insisting that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government promised to respond in three

Speaker: NA
Text: months. He constantly attacks the government

Speaker: NA
Text: for delaying the response-and uses my name

Speaker: NA
Text: in the process. He knows that I have stated

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly on more than one occasion that I

Speaker: NA
Text: asked the minister not to respond too prompt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly because that would not give time for the

Speaker: NA
Text: community input which is so important. So he

Speaker: NA
Text: is aware of what I said and he is aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the minister was asked to do. For him to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue in this way is quite reprehensible. It

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates a lack of understanding and empathy

Speaker: NA
Text: for the youth sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is also aware, as the report points out,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the major issues involved are essentially

Speaker: NA
Text: state issues. The Commonwealth has some

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, but it is primarily with the

Speaker: NA
Text: states. It is important to go to the dimensions

Speaker: NA
Text: of this problem in order to understand it. As

Speaker: NA
Text: at the last week in May last year, on the best

Speaker: NA
Text: is up figures available-from David MACKenzie and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chris Chamberlain, who are now accepted as

Speaker: NA
Text: being the most reliable sources of data-some

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000 young Australians under the age of 18

Speaker: NA
Text: were notionally homeless, not living with

Speaker: NA
Text: their families or in a secure relationship. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: them, just over 20,000 were receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: young homeless allowance. In

Speaker: NA
Text: one-third of these young people were not

Speaker: NA
Text: being paid at the homeless rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: That gives a lie to the claims by many that

Speaker: NA
Text: the homeless allowance has acted as an

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive to and has encouraged children

Speaker: NA
Text: leave home. The report nailed that one very

Speaker: NA
Text: firmly and clearly. At the same time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: report also pointed out that in 1992-93 there

Speaker: NA
Text: were substantiated cases of abuse against (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: 22,300 young Australians in that year, a

Speaker: NA
Text: figure which is horrific in its dimensions. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a figure which is also greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people receiving homeless allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. So each year a greater number of

Speaker: NA
Text: neglect and abuse cases are being produced

Speaker: NA
Text: than currently recei ve the allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those people who have been going around

Speaker: NA
Text: the countryside in recent weeks talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the allowance as an incentive are apologists

Speaker: NA
Text: for abusers. What they are doing and saying

Speaker: NA
Text: is covering up child abuse, pretending it is

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring and blaming the children who

Speaker: NA
Text: the victims of these breakdowns.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a superb cartoon in the news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper last week showing a man and a woman

Speaker: NA
Text: in a boxing ring with boxing gloves on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beside them was a child being carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: a stretcher. The child is the real victim

Speaker: NA
Text: many family breakdowns, yet when that child

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks some support from governments we are

Speaker: NA
Text: told by politicians such as the member

Speaker: NA
Text: Farrer ( Mr Tim Fischer) in recent weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: radios around Australia that the allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: an incentive. Whoever is doing that is apolo-

Speaker: NA
Text: gising for abusers, denying abuse is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place and blaming the kids, who are the

Speaker: NA
Text: victims of what is happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that this is not primarily a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth responsibility. In recent times

Speaker: NA
Text: the states have also shown that they undercannot

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that. So I am delighted to have received

Speaker: NA
Text: an invitation to address next month the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Council on Employment, Educarationalism,

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Youth Affairs. That makes it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: me that the state ministers are interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: finding solutions-unlike the opposition. It

Speaker: NA
Text: means that state ministers are prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: down with the Commonwealth and talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the ways this report may be implemented in

Speaker: NA
Text: some form. Issues contained in the report may

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, then become relevant.

Speaker: NA
Text: This report is a long-term report about a

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term problem and will require a long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term response. Any idea that this somehow is

Speaker: NA
Text: an instant solution is nonsense. It was never

Speaker: NA
Text: to proposed that way. I am confident that over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next two or three years, if the states

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperate, we as a country can make serious

Speaker: NA
Text: progress on the cause of these problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: Power Lines

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah) (7.58 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: Killarney Heights in my electorate Optus are

Speaker: NA
Text: going down one side of the street stringing

Speaker: NA
Text: their pay TV cable on power poles and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney Electricity are going down the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the street burying their 11,000 volt

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution lines. The good news is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: top tier of the wires on the power poles is

Speaker: NA
Text: not disappearing; the bad news is that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: are new tier on the bottom from Optus and

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Optus say that they will go underground

Speaker: NA
Text: when the 240-volt delivery wires go under-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground, but the bad news for the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: on Sydney is that Sydney Electricity have no

Speaker: NA
Text: of so plans-not ever, not now, not next year-to

Speaker: NA
Text: underground those 240-volt wires. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: stuck with a tangle of wires and poles far into

Speaker: NA
Text: for the indefinite future. The only way that

Speaker: NA
Text: on Sydney Electricity will underground those

Speaker: NA
Text: is things is if local government pays for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not here to apportion blame; I am here

Speaker: NA
Text: to appeal for reason. Telstra say they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: give Optus access to their wires at anything

Speaker: NA
Text: other than what Optus think is an extortionate

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. Optus say that they cannot afford to go

Speaker: NA
Text: underground. Sydney Electricity say they

Speaker: NA
Text: put all their wires underground be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the profits have to be high and the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices have to be low. If that is economic

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not make much sense to

Speaker: NA
Text: to me. I call for a local summit of Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Electricity, Optus and Telstra, in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate, to try to ensure that 21 st century technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: sit ogy is not delivered by 19th century means.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 8.00 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Filing to move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes the Prime Minister's recent derogatory

Speaker: NA
Text: comments about the ability of superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: fund managers to adequately control and

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise contributors' funds;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) believes these comments have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: intentionally to destabilise the public's faith in

Speaker: NA
Text: private superannuation managers;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) recognises that the ACfU is seeking to control

Speaker: NA
Text: an ever increasing proportion of the superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation of Australian workers;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) believes that the government and the ACfU

Speaker: NA
Text: are therefore actively working toward the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation where the union movement will

Speaker: NA
Text: control all occupational superannuation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) given that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) estimates have indicated 10 years of such

Speaker: NA
Text: control by the ACTU could effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: allow the union movement to buy, lock,

Speaker: NA
Text: stock and barrel, the 100 biggest companies

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) past experiences with Labor's control of

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation funds, as instanced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: WA State Government Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Board-

Speaker: NA
Text: requires the Prime Minister to apologise for, and

Speaker: NA
Text: retract fully, his statements and assure the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public that control of the vast pool of

Speaker: NA
Text: money his occupation superannuation policies

Speaker: NA
Text: will create will never be given over to the union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Gallus to present a bill for an Act to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose a curfew and related restrictions on

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft movements at Adelaide Airport, and

Speaker: NA
Text: for related purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following answers to questions were circulated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Service Medals: Requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2587)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott asked the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 28

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What are the eligibility requirements for the

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) current Australian Service Medal and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Service Medal 1945-75.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Which categories of service personnel would

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify for the Australian Service Medal 1945-75.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Are there differences between the eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements for the Australia Service Medal 1945-

Speaker: NA
Text: 75 and current Australian Service Medal; if so, (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: what are they and (b) why.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The current Australian Service Medal accords

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition for service in non-warlike military

Speaker: NA
Text: operations which occurred after 1975. The Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian Service Medal 1945-75 recognises military

Speaker: NA
Text: service in prescribed peacekeeping or non-warlike

Speaker: NA
Text: operations for the period 1945-75 where recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: has not previously been extended through an award.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) All Service personnel who meet the eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria for the various Clasps to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Medal 1945-75 will receive medals. Details

Speaker: NA
Text: of Clasps which have been approved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government for the Australian Service Medal 1945-

Speaker: NA
Text: 75 are:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Clasp 'Japan' to recognise Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: served during the occupation of Japan from 3

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1945 to 28 April 1952. The eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: period is 90 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Clasp 'Korea' to recognise service during the

Speaker: NA
Text: period 1953-57. The eligibility period is 30 days

Speaker: NA
Text: service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Clasp 'Thailand-Malaysia Border' (later

Speaker: NA
Text: changed to be called clasp 'Thai Malay') to recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nise Australians who served on anti-terrorist

Speaker: NA
Text: operations between 1 August 1960 and 16 August

Speaker: NA
Text: 1964 in the Thailand Malaysia border area. The

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility period is 30 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) Clasp 'Thailand' to recognise Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel serving at the Royal Thai Air Force base

Speaker: NA
Text: at Ubon and the members of 2 Field Troop

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: RAEME and other Australians who participated in

Speaker: NA
Text: Operation 'Crown'. The eligibility period is 30

Speaker: NA
Text: days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) Clasp 'PNG' to recognise service in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory of Papua New Guinea from the formation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Pacific Islands Regiment on 16 February

Speaker: NA
Text: 1951 until the independence of Papua New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: on 16 September 1975. This applies to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: nationals of all Services, including RAN personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: posted to HMAS Tarangau and attached vessels.

Speaker: NA
Text: The eligibility is 180 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) Clasp 'Kashmir' to recognise service from 13

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1948 to 13 February 1975 with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, including the Military Group in India and

Speaker: NA
Text: Pakistan and the United Nations IndiaJPakistan

Speaker: NA
Text: Observer Mission. The eligibility period is 90 days

Speaker: NA
Text: service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (g) Clasp 'W. New Guinea' to recognise service

Speaker: NA
Text: from 3 October 1962 to 30 April 1963 for Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian personnel serving with the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Temporary Executive Authority force in West New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea. The eligibility period is 30 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (h) Clasp 'Indonesia' to recognise service from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 August 1947 to 1 January 1949 and from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 1949 to 30 April 1951 for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel serving with the United Nations Good

Speaker: NA
Text: Offices Commission and the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission for Indonesia. The eligibility period is

Speaker: NA
Text: 90 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) Clasp 'Middle East' to recognise service in

Speaker: NA
Text: various United Nations Peacekeeping missions in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East during the Period 1948 to 1964.

Speaker: NA
Text: The eligibility period is 90 days service.

Speaker: NA
Text: (j) Clasp 'Berlin' to recognise Australian involve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the Berlin Airlift during the period 26 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1948 to 30 September 1949.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Australian Service Medal 1945-75 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the current Australian Service Medal both accord

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition for service in non war-like operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Differing periods of eligibility apply for different

Speaker: NA
Text: Clasps to the Medals to reflect the differences in

Speaker: NA
Text: both types of service and the conditions associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with that service.

Speaker: NA
Text: JobSkills Program

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2625)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Wakelin asked the Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment, Education and Training, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 20 September 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Are participants in the JobSkills Program who

Speaker: NA
Text: are married without dependent children financially

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged by their participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What proportion of JobSkills participants are

Speaker: NA
Text: financially disadvantaged by their participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What is the standard allowance for (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: JobSkills and (b) New Work Opportunity partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pants.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) If the allowances referred to in part (3) differ,

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) and (2) No participants in the JobSkills

Speaker: NA
Text: Program who are married and without dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: children are financially disadvantaged by their

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. Both members of an unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: couple are treated as individuals and can establish

Speaker: NA
Text: a personal entitlement to Job Search Allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: (JSA), Newstart Allowance (NSA), Youth Training

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowance or Partner Allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) New Work Opportunities (NWO) program

Speaker: NA
Text: participants are paid a training allowance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of allowance depending on the skill level of

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks being undertaken on the project. The weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: training allowance rates for adults are $270 at skill

Speaker: NA
Text: level C, $315 at skill level Band $333 at skill level

Speaker: NA
Text: A.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The differences in the allowances payable to

Speaker: NA
Text: JobSkills and NWO participants reflect the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences in the programs. Adult participants in NWO

Speaker: NA
Text: projects must have generally been unemployed and

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of JSAlNSA for at least 18 months. The

Speaker: NA
Text: JobSkills program caters for participants 21 years

Speaker: NA
Text: of age and older and is generally available after 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months unemployment and receipt of an income

Speaker: NA
Text: support benefit from the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security. In addition, to suit more disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: clients, there are more flexible training options

Speaker: NA
Text: available under the NWO program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Zito, Mr Francesco

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2662)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cations and the Arts, upon notice, on 27

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Francesco Zito of Hillcrest, South Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: who suffers from asbestosis claimed to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: contracted as an employee of Telstra, formally

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecom.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is it a fact that Telstra has accepted responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for Mr Zito's condition but has refused to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: him a lump sum compensation or an ex gratia

Speaker: NA
Text: payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What action will he take on Mr Zito's behalf.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lee-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) No. I have not received representations from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Zito or his legal representatives on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Yes. Telstra has advised that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation Act 1988 (SRC Act), it accepted liability

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mr Zito's condition. Telstra continues to make

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation payments for medical and like

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra has also advised that, under Section 24

Speaker: NA
Text: of the SRC Act, there is no provision for a lump

Speaker: NA
Text: sum permanent impairment payment to be paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Zito. Telstra, as a licence holder under the SRC

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1988, has no alternative but to comply with the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra has further advised that it will not make

Speaker: NA
Text: an ex gratia payment to Mr Zito because Telstra

Speaker: NA
Text: considers such a payment would be in breach of its

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations under the SRC Act and its conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of licence.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Telstra is responsible for the day to day

Speaker: NA
Text: running of its affairs, including compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: related matters and makes its own commercial and

Speaker: NA
Text: management decisions within the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative requirements and Government policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra has advised me that, Mr Zito is entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to seek a hearing before the Federal Administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeals Tribunal to review the decision of Telstra's

Speaker: NA
Text: Reconsideration Delegate that there was no entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under the SRC Act for Mr Zito to receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: lump sum payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that there are formal avenues available to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Zito in this matter there is no basis for me to

Speaker: NA
Text: intervene on Mr Zito's behalf.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tweed Valley Fruit Processors:

Speaker: NA
Text: Enterprise Agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2670)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bradford asked the Minister for Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial Relations, upon notice, on 28 September

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the Government objecting to the enterprise

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement involving forgone entitlements to sick

Speaker: NA
Text: leave in return for increased wages which 29

Speaker: NA
Text: employees of Tweed Valley Fruit Processors

Speaker: NA
Text: entered into after protracted negotiations; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: why.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Text: The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes. The Commonwealth intervened in an appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Automotive, Food, Metals, Engineering,

Speaker: NA
Text: Printing and Kindred Industries Union against the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the implementation of an enterprise

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibility agreement (EFA) at Tweed Valley Fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: Processors Pty Ltd on the grounds that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner at first instance failed to apply the "no

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage" test correctly.

Speaker: NA
Text: A Full Bench of the Australian Industrial Rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Commission quashed the approval of the EFA

Speaker: NA
Text: on 26 October. In doing so it agreed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth submissions that the Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: at first instance incorrectly applied the "no disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage" test. The Full Bench noted that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner erred in finding that the approval of

Speaker: NA
Text: the EFA would not result in a reduction in any

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements or protections. In addition to paid sick

Speaker: NA
Text: leave, the Full Bench identified a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions in award entitlements. These included

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to bereavement and jury service leave,

Speaker: NA
Text: overtime rates, annual leave loading, meal breaks,

Speaker: NA
Text: hours of work, wages for junior employees, public

Speaker: NA
Text: holidays and redundancy pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of particular concern to the Commonwealth was

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision in the agreement which allowed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospective cashing out of sick leave. The Full

Speaker: NA
Text: Bench decided, consistent with Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions that whilst it is possible under the "no

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage" test to trade off award entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of an overall package, the public interest

Speaker: NA
Text: element of the test was intended to protect well

Speaker: NA
Text: established and accepted community standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as sick leave.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: No payments were made to Kamppi Construc-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mines: Production and Export

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2713)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cleary asked the Minister representing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: Does Australia produce and export mines and

Speaker: NA
Text: mine components; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) to which countries are mines exported,

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) in what quantities are they exported and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) what part does the Minister's Department

Speaker: NA
Text: play in the trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia does not manufacture or export land-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines and there are no records of the export of

Speaker: NA
Text: landmines from Australia. Landmines can be made

Speaker: NA
Text: from a wide variety of common materials like steel

Speaker: NA
Text: or plastic, and may incorporate components like

Speaker: NA
Text: detonator> and explosives with both military and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-military application. Australian exports of

Speaker: NA
Text: military detonators and explosives are controlled

Speaker: NA
Text: under Regulation 13B of the Customs (Prohibited

Speaker: NA
Text: Exports) Regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government is committed to the elimination

Speaker: NA
Text: of all anti-personnel landmines as an ultimate goal.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in the absence of widespread internation-

Speaker: NA
Text: al support for a total ban as evidenced at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Inhumane Weapons Convention Review Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: held in Vienna from 25 September to 12 October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995, the Government is advancing a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: other proposals, which include tight restrictions on

Speaker: NA
Text: international transfers of mines and a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: moratorium on the export of the long-lived anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel landmines that are killing and maiming

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senior High Schools

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2715)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Vocational Education and Training, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 19 October 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the success

Speaker: NA
Text: of senior high schools throughout Australia, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Does the Commonwealth recognise the role

Speaker: NA
Text: of senior high schools in providing a halfway house

Speaker: NA
Text: between the discipline of high schools and the

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom of universities and T AFE.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Do senior high schools provide greater

Speaker: NA
Text: subject choice and diversity for students than Year

Speaker: NA
Text: 7-12 high schools; if so, to what extent is greater

Speaker: NA
Text: choice advantageous to students.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) While the Commonwealth has an important

Speaker: NA
Text: role in identifying national priorities and strategies

Speaker: NA
Text: for schooling, the Statesrrerritories and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government school authorities are in the best

Speaker: NA
Text: position to determine the most appropriate structure

Speaker: NA
Text: for upper secondary schooling in their jurisdiction.

Speaker: NA
Text: In many States, this comprises a number of options

Speaker: NA
Text: including senior high schools. Providing options for

Speaker: NA
Text: senior students would contribute to higher Year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: retention rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) A study, 'Subject Choice in Years 11 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 12', conducted by the Australian Council for

Speaker: NA
Text: Educational Research in 1993 indicated that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an association between the number of students

Speaker: NA
Text: in Year II & 12 and the extent to which students

Speaker: NA
Text: were able to study the subjects which they wished.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, the study found that larger schools

Speaker: NA
Text: provided a wider choice of subjects for students.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the data also suggested that most schools

Speaker: NA
Text: (except for the very small) provided coverage

Speaker: NA
Text: across all Key Learning Areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Private Schools: Funding

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2716)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Vocational Education and Training, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 19 October, 1995:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Does the Commonwealth provide capital and

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrent funding to private schools dependent upon

Speaker: NA
Text: annual funding from other sources.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has his attention been drawn to major

Speaker: NA
Text: changes proposed for John Paul II Senior High

Speaker: NA
Text: School at Marayong, NSW.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is the Commonwealth consulted about major

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to schools similar to those referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: part (2).

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Has his Department been consulted about the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes referred in part (2).

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Is it a condition of the provision of Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth funding to private schools that parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: students be consulted about major changes: if not,

Speaker: NA
Text: why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Free-The answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Commonwealth does provide capital and

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrent funding for non-government schools. For

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 70 per cent of non-government schools,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth is the major source of recurrent

Speaker: NA
Text: funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) and (4) The New South Wales Catholic

Speaker: NA
Text: education authorities have notified the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Employment, Education and Training under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's New Schools Policy of a possible

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring of secondary schools within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Diocese of Parramatta to take effect from 1998.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notifications for 1998 were required by 31 October

Speaker: NA
Text: 1995. However, formal applications are not re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired until February 1996 and no application has

Speaker: NA
Text: been lodged at this time in respect of the notifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The approved authorities for all non-govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schools in receipt of Commonwealth funding

Speaker: NA
Text: are required to give advance notification to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and later lodge a formal application

Speaker: NA
Text: for funding of changes such as extension to another

Speaker: NA
Text: level of education, relocation to a new site and

Speaker: NA
Text: opening a new campus. Such changes are assessed

Speaker: NA
Text: for funding eligibility. Changes such as amalgama-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with another funded school or separation to

Speaker: NA
Text: form two schools are also required to be notified

Speaker: NA
Text: but they are generally not the subject of a formal

Speaker: NA
Text: application nor assessed for funding. The assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for eligibility for Commonwealth recurrent

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of non-government schools proposing to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake changes looks at matters such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: demographics of the catchment area and the likely

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the change on existing schools in the

Speaker: NA
Text: catchment area.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) The Commonwealth is not involved with the

Speaker: NA
Text: internal management of schools so consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with parents and students is not a specific

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is unlikely however that

Speaker: NA
Text: ges could be successfully implemented without the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the school community.
